It had been divided up into larger rooms. Studios. Walls had been removed to allow for open spaces. There were bright lights set up. Little else was in the room except for a large bed and a couch was off to one side. Officers on the scene were a bit shocked at what greeted them. A fifteen year old girl was being filmed with a man, while several other men stood naked to one side waiting their turn. Disgusted, one of the officers had to restrain a fellow officer from punching one of them. They were happy to put such scumbags in jail. No problem. Detectives flowed up and into the house. The sun waned. Patrol officers set up a barricade nearby to keep the neighborhood away. Computers, films and expensive camera gear were all seized. Night oozed into the next morning. Detectives sealed the doors. Construction personnel boarded up the windows. They were done.   Turnabout The skateboarders drove down an alleyway and pulled to the side. Charlie and Eddie had heard about the house from a kid who went to a local school. He had been there the summer before when the Van Nuys police raided the "Porn Palace". It was the name that the kids gave the old house. It had been boarded up all year. Disrepair. Neglect. The kids knew that there was an old swimming pool in the back. One of the neighbors had told people that the porn actresses once sunbathed naked there. He watched them through a fence. Charlie and Eddie didn't care what had been done in the past. They only concerned themselves with the future. Turnabout. They soon pulled themselves over a fence and found what awaited them. It was a massive mess. Someone had drained the pool and cleared out the remaining contents of the home. All of it was in the pool.   Charlie and Eddie couldn't quite believe the work that they had ahead of themselves. They made phone calls. Help arrived and within a few hours, most of the debris was out of the pool and stacked in the back alleyway. The skaters could see that the transitions were good. The pool had a straight face wall with round carveable corners. The corners were amazing and everyone was anxious to try them out. It was growing late in the day and the crew agreed to come back the next day and drain the remaining filthy water. They'd skate it and have fun.       The crew managed to get the muck, filth and debris out of the pool. The 'Porn Palace". Cleansed of its seediness, sin and vice. The old pool raised its plaster face to the sun. Charlie and Eddie talked quietly while the skin of the pool dried in the warming light. They shook their heads about the pools history. Life is crazy sometimes. "Who would've thought? A porn house?" [caption id="attachment_19788" align="aligncenter" width="532"] Eddie Mighty Moreno[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19789" align="aligncenter" width="532"] Charlie Blair[/caption] They skated and took what the pool offered up. Possibilities. The afternoon sun grinned down on them as wrongs were made right. A Karma debt had been repaid. A cloud that once lingered overhead... was now, long gone. Thank you to Deville for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Dust
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_19809" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bulldog[/caption] The wind blew. Dust hung in the air and bit at my lungs. I stood beside the truck on a hillside, looking down into a narrow valley. It was still and nothing moved except the wind. Far to the west, a ridge of dark rock spilled over and out of my view. The faces of the stones were split and cracked. Sun. Heat. Eternal elements. A white sun. Palms scraped the sky. Green fronds. The only splotch of color on an empty palette. It was like the artist forgot the other paint in the color scheme. Tan. White. Brown. Little else. [caption id="attachment_19810" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Andy Neal[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19811" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Scott Cooper[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19812" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kevin Burke[/caption] In the middle distance, I could see a ribbon of concrete cresting a rise. Freeway. Encroaching civilization. The end of peace and quiet. People. Ignorance and all of its problems. I walked a short distance as I spotted a ranch home tucked away in a narrow stand of trees. I glimpsed the white plaster and blue tiles that could only be one thing: pool. It appeared empty. Forlorn. A hole in the ground that awaited happiness. My friends and I could provide such a thing. Happiness comes in all forms. You can buy it in bottles. You can get it in pills. Choose wisely. That happiness is short-lived. The element becomes everything. Your life is dust.  Then you'll wish for something you can no longer find. "Like the way you cry for a happy ending..." I know. I know. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_19813" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ripperside Shawn[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: This text scream.... Like sliding wheels on concrete and i can hear it even here in freezing Québec Canada.

item.title: Grant Brittain BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Grant Brittain picked up a camera at the ripe old age of 25 and started shooting his friends skateboarding at the Del Mar Skate Ranch. The "Ranch" was a skatepark in a small beach town north of San Diego, California that he managed in the early 1980s, and it was there that he honed his photographic skills. After blowing massive amounts of film, he took every photo class Palomar Junior College had to offer. And with that, he felt he finally learned how to manipulate his 35mm camera.
While at college, an influential instructor introduced Brittain to the vast world of photography, and set him on his creative path. In 1983, Grant was asked to contribute skate photos to the premiere issue of TransWorld SKATEboarding magazine and became its founding Photo Editor and Senior Photographer.
Over the past twenty years, Brittain has helped TransWorld grow into the most popular skate mag in the world, and has captured the best skateboarders of the last two decades in photos that have become classics. He has also taught some of the best skate photographers, past and present, and helped them develop their own work. He hopes that they have gotten as much inspiration from him as he gets from them.
Over the years Brittain's personal work-abstracts, portraits, landscapes and travel images-seems to draw from the opposite energy of his action images. His "off hours" are consumed by a search for calmer and more serene subjects. Still lakes at night and solitary desert forms are among the subjects of his diverse personal work. Some of his portraits of well-known athletes even manage to divulge a more reflective side of their personalities.
Few photographers have pursued so wide a range of subjects and styles. But few individuals find themselves so central to such an active community, where one's perspective is just a notch askew of the rest, and where movement and progression is the norm. Grant Brittain's body of work reflects his deep involvement in an emerging youth culture, as well as his escape from it. Grant and a group of the skateboarding elite talent have left TWS and started The Skateboard Mag, check it at: theskateboardmag.com and at shops and newsstands

item.title: Craig Stecyk III BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
As a result of familial and neighborhood connections in the Venice and Santa Monica areas of Los Angeles, Stecyk grew up around car “customizers” and auto-style progenitors like George Barris, Dutch Darrin, Gil Ayala, Ed “Big Daddy” Roth, Von Dutch Howard, Phil Hill, Dean Jeffries and Ed Iskenderian, as well as legendary surfers and board builders Dave Sweet, Dale Velzy, Miklos Dora and Greg Noll. In the late 1970s, as an original member of the “Dogtown” skateboard gang in Southern California, Stecyk changed the look and attitude of skateboarding forever. He began his career as a surfboard designer and graphic artist while working out of the small Zephyr surf shop. Stecyk is considered one of the first to incorporate many outlaw elements of surf and skate culture into the equipment and attendant gear.
He is perhaps best known as a documentary photographer. His articles and photo essays of the 1970s for Skateboarder magazine set a standard for throngs of rebellious individualists to follow. This original documentation of the mid 1970s Dogtown scene altered the lives of a generation, inspiring confidence and encouraging the rebel instinct to flourish. It was through his photographs that the modern skateboarder archetype was brought to light. Since then, Stecyk has continued his documentary recordings, immersing himself in Southern California’s surf, hot rod and low rider scenes. In 1993, he curated the highly successful exhibition, Kustom Kulture, at the Laguna Art Museum, which featured such seminal underground artists as Robt. Williams, Von Dutch and Roth. Stecyk also organized Surf Culture: The Art History of Surfing, was a founding member of the Juxtapoz magazine collective, and was the production designer and writer of the Sundance Film Festival award-winning Dogtown and Z-Boys.

item.title: Glen E. Friedman BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Glen E. Friedman (born 1962) has long been considered a vital part of the modern cutting-edge subcultures. His photography goes far beyond simply documenting the scenes and key players of the skate, punk and early hip-hop cultures; he provides firsthand insight into the science of defiance that drove the progression and art of the participants.
Working with such rebellious artists as Fugazi, Black Flag, Ice-T, Dead Kennedys, Minor Threat, Misfits, Bad Brains, Beastie Boys, Run-DMC and Public Enemy as well as classic skateboarding originators such as Tony Alva, Jay Adams, Alan Gelfand, Duane Peters and Stacy Peralta. among others, Friedman has been in the right place at an extraordinary number of appropriate times. He’s not only provided the definitive portraits of many of these people, but also has helped define the moment and movements he was caught up in. His process was much more incendiary than it was documentary. According to Henry Rollins, “The bottom line is that he was there at the beginning of so much cool stuff in so many different areas it’s not funny.” Glen E. Friedman’s captivating images demonstrate his remarkable eye for raw reality, talent and aesthetic beauty. Considered legendary by many, he is, without doubt, one of this generation’s most discerning and important photographers. Friedman has documented like no one else. Born in North Carolina while his father was serving a short stint in the Army at Fort Bragg, Friedman and his family soon returned to northern New Jersey, where Glen spent a large part of his childhood off and on. When his parents divorced, his mother took him and his younger brother to live in California. At this point in time he would spend the school year in Los Angeles and then visit his father in the New York City/New Jersey area during vacations, until the situation was reversed for his last two years of high school. Never a great student, Glen always got by and was one of those kids about whom the teachers said, “If he’d only apply himself a bit more he’d be an ‘A’ student.” Even from a young age he always seemed to have his own agenda; as a nine-year-old he held a very aggressive anti-Vietnam War stance, and at ten proudly supported George McGovern for president on his clothing. He always stood up for the rights of his friends, particularly those more shy than himself, and from an early age he could not stand by to see others taken advantage of in any way. When his mother remarried and they moved to the affluent area of Brentwood in West Los Angeles, Glen was thrust into a frustrating world of “blue blood” elitists and spoiled brats, which quickly led to him discovering a crew of older kids from outside this neighborhood. Friedman’s childhood was largely spent hanging out and skating in the legendary West L.A. schoolyards of the area affectionately known as DogTown. His friends were beginning to be featured in magazines as top skateboarders, but Friedman felt the images failed to capture the true essence of what he was witnessing on a daily basis. Sharing the skaters’ attitude–that they were completely able to redefine what the sport was–he thought that even though still in junior high school, he could do a better job behind the camera. In the spring of ’75 he took a photography class with his “Pocket Instamatic” and refused to use a more professional 35mm camera, not simply because he did not own one, but also because he would be afraid to break or lose it, and of course with the Pocket Instamatic he could still hang out and skate without much concern. He started snapping pictures of his friends and even submitted them to skateboard manufacturers hoping they would use them in advertisements in SkateBoarder magazine, thinking at the time there was no way he could go directly to the editorial staff of skateboarding’s leading publication. Forgetting for the most part about his class assignments, he learned all about cameras and the basics of good photography, but continued shooting only the subjects he wanted to, hence gaining a “D” in “Photography 1.″ In the fall of 1976, Friedman discovered an empty swimming pool, and corralled a few friends (the infamous Jay Adams among them) into riding it so he could take pictures with a borrowed 35mm camera. He showed the results to a freelance SkateBoarderphotojournalist (C.R. Stecyk III) he met at the local schoolyard, who put the eighth-grader in touch with the magazine’s editor. SkateBoarder published the first photos Glen ever submitted, one as a full-page subscription ad (just months after he got that “D”), and he soon became the magazine’s youngest staff member. The magazine was having an effect on youth culture worldwide, and in turn Friedman became somewhat of an underground cult figure for being one of the main contributors of the hardcore action, and a very young contributor at that. It was here that Friedman began learning the realities of the photography world, and began setting his path for the years to come. Several years later Friedman began to shoot photos at the punk shows he was attending. It was inspiring to him to be so close to the bands and their intense energy. Glen was passionately loyal to his subjects, and relentlessly devoted to winning them exposure in order to expose others to the ideals of these artists, at first in the skate magazines, and later in fanzines and music magazines. Proto-punks such as Black Flag, Bad Brains, Minor Threat and others received some of their first national and international media documentation through Friedman’s work. The political views and progressive perspectives of the hardcore punk bands educated Friedman. He attempted to gain them exposure in major news and music publications as well, to no avail at the time. It was the DIY (do it yourself) work ethic he picked up from hanging out and working with Black Flag that got Friedman, in 1982, to self-publish his photo-zine MY RULES. It sold 10,000 copies and was the largest-selling zine of the era. In 1983 Friedman broadened his artistic scope and produced Suicidal Tendencies’ debut album. He became their manager and of course handled all of their photography, promotion and marketing. By 1984 he had helped to direct and edit their first video for “Institutionalized,” the song he produced, and relentlessly promoted it until it got them on MTV, the first hardcore punk band ever to be in rotation on the channel. Despite the album he produced eventually becoming the biggest-selling hardcore punk album of the decade, conflicts between Glen and the band arose and he quit, deciding to stay away from that sort of involvement in the music world. Friedman continued thinking of new outlets for his enthusiasm and work, soon meeting up with old friends the Beastie Boys on their first trip to Los Angeles, now as a rap group instead of a punk band. On this trip he created some of the most memorable Beastie Boys photos ever taken, and was introduced to Rick Rubin and Russell Simmons, who loved his work, attitude, understanding of and interest in the culture of hip-hop. By 1985, Friedman was photographing all the Def Jam artists, all the while attending college classes at UCLA up until 1986, working on a self-prescribed course of general education by studying what he felt would best broaden his knowledge. In 1987 he made the decision to move back to New York full time. His early documentation of Run-DMC, Public Enemy, Ice-T, L.L. Cool J and the Beasties brought hip-hop to a wider audience, thanks in part to the connections he had made in the music business with the punk bands. His work achieved fame as record covers for many of the decade’s finest in hip-hop and punk. Many of his photographs are recognized as the subjects’ definitive portraits. In 1986 Glen began reading flyers and pamphlets given to him by punk friends, educating him to the environmental and health concerns associated with a typical American diet. Glen had grown up eating meat and the normal junk food fare of his age group–in fact he at one time loved eating at fast food chains, and was happy to eat a “bloody steak” on occasion. By 1987 he had begun to read the book Diet for a New America; before he was finished, he had completed making the transition to a vegan diet and lifestyle, which he still practices and actively promotes to this day. Throughout the rest of the 80′s and early 90′s Friedman was making a living shooting musicians and solidifying his reputation as one of the most important photographers emerging from this new milieu. With this notoriety he became even more outspoken about his own political views, and began influencing many of those subjects and others who were around him or seeing his work. People began to notice that all of these cultures Glen was involved in promoting were having a large influence on the culture as a whole. The work he set out to do with all of these individuals was inspiring legions. By 1994, Friedman had published FUCK YOU HEROESon his Burning Flags Press imprint, beginning a path of fiercely independent artistic production. A collection of his work spanning 1976 to 1991, HEROES looked at the pioneering leaders of the skateboarding, punk and hip-hop subcultures that he was so much a part of. Its title, though offensive to some, signifies his subjects’ bold, forthright, heroic rejection of reactionary social standards. His second book, FUCK YOU TOO: The Extras & More Scrap Book, was published in 1996 (and was subsequently updated in 2004). The FUCK YOU ALL exhibition, combining photos from both of those first two books, brought Friedman’s work to major cities around the world, beginning in 1997 at the Institute of Contemporary Art in London, then on to Sydney, Tokyo, Florence, Rome, Milan, Sicily, Berlin, Stockholm, Chicago, Washington DC, Philadelphia, Los Angeles and in more recent years to Antwerp, Krakow, Dublin and San Francisco. In 1998, Glen followed up with the publication of The Idealist: In My Eyes – Twenty Years, which he considers the artistic summation of his photography, a perspective on his own artistic aesthetic that at times diverges greatly from his other known work but gives the viewer an insight into his personal vision. This book was revised in 2003 to include an additional five years of photography, as well as comments written specifically for this book by a few more subjects who had also inspired him, including Ralph Nader and Professor Cornel West. In 2000, the book DogTown – The Legend Of The Z-Boys was co-authored with C.R. Stecyk III, and edited and designed by Friedman. Glen’s film credits, co-producer and creative consultant, barely touch on the major influence he had on the 2002 feature-length documentary DogTown and Z-Boys, which won the audience choice award for Best Documentary at Sundance and additional awards at several other festivals. He also appears as one of the main commentators in the film itself. In 2004 Friedman created the “Liberty Street Protest” for millions who visit the former World Trade Center site from around the world, to see at Ground Zero in New York City. Its provocative anti-war sentiment, made up of 27 huge window banners in an 11-story building, was displayed through the republikkkan convention of that year, and received attention worldwide. His book RECOGNIZE was released in 2005, an artistic statement that shocked and surprised many, garnered critical praise but has still only been seen by a small percentage of those who know his more popular work. 2006 saw Friedman collaborating with old DogTown friend Jay Adams to edit and design the book JAY BOY. Made up entirely of early photographs taken by Jay’s stepfather and Z-Flex founder Kent Sherwood, the book provides a unique insight into the life of one of the defining figures of modern skateboarding. Before becoming a father in 2007, Glen put the finishing touches on and soon after released Keep Your Eyes Open -The Fugazi Photographs of Glen E. Friedman, a collection of his live and portrait work of his good friends, and one of the independent music scene’s most influential acts. In 2009 Glen had his first ever career retrospective open at Shepard Fairey’s Subliminal Projects gallery in Los Angeles. The success of this brought about another collaboration with now-infamous street artist/propagandist Shepard Fairey and Glen E. Friedman, adding to the several projects they’d already done in previous years (and continue to do) that have used Glen’s iconic images. In 2010 some half dozen original prints of Glen’s covering all aspects of his oeuvre were requested, and subsequently accepted into, the Photographic History Collection of the National Museum of American History at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington D.C. And most recently original prints of his work were acquired for the photography collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City and the Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

item.title: Art Brewer BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Art Brewer was born in Laguna Beach, California and has never abandoned the area…except to travel. Beginning in 1968 as a principal staff photographer for SURFER Magazine, his life has been filled with journeys, most of them to the world’s vast panoply of islands, where he has produced everything from journalistic coverage to celebratory location work. A self-taught photographer who once took a seminar from Ansel Adams, Art has circled the globe countless times chasing the world’s best waves and the surfers who chased them. Brewer is distinguished among his peers for his collection of surfer portraits. Over his 40-year career, Art vast body of work has been celebrated in numerous outlets as diverse as Rolling Stone, Sports Illustrated, Esquire, and Playboy as well as celebrated in Masters of Surf Photography: Art Brewer. In the language of images, the photographs of Art Brewer are known for speaking with penetrating truth, enlivened with edgy wit.

item.title: Warren Bolster BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: In 1972, he started to be published in and became associate editor at Surfer Magazine from 1976-77. During his time at Surfer Magazine, he was given the task of resurrecting Skateboarder Magazine by Steve Pezman, at the time publisher and editor of Surfer. Skateboarder Magazine had released only four quarterly issues in 1964-65, and then ceased publication. When the skateboard craze subsided, the magazine was dropped due to low sales. In 1976, with the advent of the urethane wheel revolution in skateboarding, which provided greater traction and speed, Bolster had six months to get Skateboarder Magazinerunning again. As an associate editor, he teamed up with Kurt Ledterman, the other associate editor at Surfer Magazine. Secretary Chris Maxwell (nicknamed Max Criswell by Kurt) made the final member of a trio that would become the re-creators of Skateboarder Magazine. Photographically, Bolster was among the first to use fish-eye lenses, motor-drive sequences and strobes while documenting California's skateboarding culture. For example, Ty Page's multi-faceted, rapid-fire technique and footwork were nothing short of incredible. After trying many times to photograph his footwork, Bolster was forced to purchase a new $3,000 high-speed camera to catch him on film to publish in the August and September 1977 issues of Skateboarder Magazine. Superstar professional skateboarder Tony Hawk said the magazine was the only one worth reading at the time. "The pictures were always dreamy and left me full of disbelief…. If it weren't for SkateBoarder, I would have never realized what was really possible on my four-wheeled plank," Hawk said in the book The Legacy of Warren Bolster: Master of Skateboard Photography. Bolster remained a staff photographer for Surfer Magazine until 1992. He moved to Hawaii in 1978, where he established himself as an accomplished and widely published freelance surf photographer. Bolster was constantly on the lookout for new angles, shooting from helicopters and often using a deck-mounted camera to get spectacular photos from behind the surfer, or photos from in front of the surfer’s board. However, for non-surfers, one of Bolster's best known images is the un-broken wave that formed the cover image of Ride's classic shoegazing album Nowhere. As a free-lance photographer, Bolster often struggled financially between assignments. He was known for putting himself dangerously close to the action he was photographing, often colliding with his subjects or their speeding platforms. He had endured at least a dozen surgeries and many broken bones participating in and documenting surfing activities. As a result, Bolster battled chronic pain and addiction to a painkiller. "I almost destroyed myself to give a larger life to the sport," he wrote in The Legacy of Warren Bolster: Master of Skateboard Photography, a 2004 book. He also suffered from long bouts of depression. Nonetheless, despite his health issues, Bolster remained on the cutting edge of surf photography. Nine days before his death, Bolster was injured when his car was rear-ended in a serious collision. He died at the age of 59 on September 6, 2006, of a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

item.title: Jim Goodrich BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Jim Goodrich got his start in skateboarding in 1976 as a skateboarder. When a skateboarding accident sent him to the hospital with a broken arm, it started him on a path that changed his life. He began shooting photos of his skate buddies while recovering from the accident.

In 1977, he met Warren Bolster, the editor of Skateboarder magazine, and soon afterwards was hired as a staff photographer at the magazine. For many years he photographed the wealth of top skate talent around the world and chronicled the golden age of skateboarding. He later went on to work as manager and team coach at Gullwing Products, then as managing editor at TransWorld Skateboarding magazine.

Jim’s love of skateboarding had originally drawn him into photography, and now the love of his work over thirty years later has brought him back into the skateboarding world. His biggest stoke in skateboarding now is experiencing the new generation from a fresh perspective, and seeing others enjoying his work.

“Skateboarding is more than just a lifestyle and passion for me. As I look back on my years in the industry, I again realize that though I left the skateboard scene many years ago, skateboarding has never left me.”

item.title: Mofo BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Rabble-rouser, carouser and ornery visionary, Mörizen Föche was the man behind the lens, behind the magazine, by which all other skateboard publications are measured. AKA, Mofo, Photo Editor, Art Director, graphic designer and photojournalist of Thrasher Magazine from it’s early beginnings in 1981 through its first decade of existence, he helped define the Skate & Destroy lifestyle with words and photographs of its quintessential proponents. Mo’s articles and artwork captured the imagination of a generation of skaters and pointed the way for their sons and daughters to follow. As a vocalist/producer Mörizen Föche originally created and directed Thrasher Magazine‘s Skate Rock compilation series, and was ultimately responsible for identifying the musical phenomenon in a series of magazine articles, and is credited with coining the term “Skate Rock”. In 1983, MoFo approached the members of the seminal San Jose skate punk band Los Olvidados about forming a new band. MoFo suggested the group don Indian masks.

item.title: I am Ozzie
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: My name is Ozzie and I am fifty-one years old. In the mornings when I awaken, my body adds at least a decade to that number. Mileage... I am broken like a misused toy. A giant child beat the shit out of me for a few decades and stuck me back on a ragged shelf. No kids my age want to play with me anymore. Probably for the better, I suppose. I don't wish to involve myself in their type of activities. I never have. I've been at odds with everything around me my entire life. I didn't get that particular chip installed... the one that makes you "Give a damn." I guess I did try it their way. Societal norms. I joined the military, went to college, became a respected member of society. I had nice cars, money, praise heaped upon my shoulders by work colleagues... I'd end up with a pistol in my mouth every weekend. Grave indifference: my own. I was quite unfulfilled with the trappings of my successful and respected place in society. I had started skateboarding in 1973. Steel wheels. Chunk of flat wood. If you threw a baseball at me, I'd whimper and be unable to catch it, but once I stood on a skateboard, I found out something...  I could ride! I sold my soul immediately. Not a second thought. Years flew by. I never stopped skating and never will. I watch the sport change and change again. It comes and goes. I stay. It is the only thing that brings me comfort. Panacea. I've never been sponsored, never been a pro and never been paid to ride my skateboard. I can only do about ten or fifteen tricks. I've never won a contest. My best finish was 3rd in an amateur vert contest. It matters not one damn bit. I'll always skateboard because it is hard-wired into my DNA. It is who I am. A few years ago, I got sober and that helped me understand my past and grow from it. I am now whole and healthy. My mind is my own. I don't smash through life... I am at peace. Thank you to those out there who understand and relate. I write the Blue Tile Obsession for you. X Ozzie

item.title: Wynn Miller BIO
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Wynn Miller’s career has spanned over thirty years, both as an award winning advertising photographer and photojournalist. His late 1970’s work, capturing skateboarder Tony Alva and his fellow Dogtown skateboarders, has achieved iconic status. Miller’s exhibit, Freshjives Mad Dog Chronicles, has traveled the world with showings in Tokyo, Paris, Los Angeles and New York. In contrast to his work with Tony Alva in the 1970’s, Miller was also documenting a year in the life of an East Los Angeles street gang known as “Arizona Maravilla”. He immersed himself with the crew, earned their trust and was allowed to photograph them on their own turf. This allowed for a previously unheard of level of access. Miller, a Los Angeles native, studied photography at Santa Monica College and UCLA. He lives happily on the Westside, hanging with his two daughters and teaching his new grandson how to surf.

item.title: George Powell
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
George Powell and Stacy Peralta have always supported my deal. At Woodward Skate Camp, Mission Valley Skate Park and up to the present day, they have been there for me. George has been making great skateboard products for a very long time. I rode my first set of white Bones in 1978. I ride Bones still. He's motivated to engineer and deliver the best skateboarding products that he can. Check out this documentary that Stacy put together. - Ozzie
[embed]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6vcC_Y2z1ps[/embed]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looks like such a fun place to work. Makes me happy to be supporting Powell Peralta. I run mini logo trucks on my street and pool setup, Bones wheels on all 4 of my boards, have a McGill funshape for my pool setup, and Swiss Super 6's in my street, pool, and big bowling boards. Great company making great stuff, and at least a lot of it is being done in California. pretty cool. Keep it up George!

item.title: Vans Combi / Intro
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The skateboarding boom of the mid to late 1970's ushered in a time that has yet to be duplicated or surpassed. Skate parks, equipment, tricks and the overall aesthetic of skateboarding was developed in a few short years. Skatepark design was taken from the hands of contractors with little knowledge of skateboarding and placed in the hands of skateboarders themselves. Skaters assisted in drawing up plans and overseeing construction and it accelerated the sport in a vertical direction. Pools. Bowls. Pipes. Competitions began to be held in these vertical arenas and skateboarding flourished. The tricks increased in difficulty and technicality accelerated. Legends were made in a span of five short years. Yet, in the blink of an eye, the skateparks began closing. Injuries. Liability. The wonderful skatepark era of the 1970's had died. Skateboarding went from concrete skateparks, pipes and bowls and disappeared into backyards. Home-made wooden half pipes sprouted up in backyards, but many skateboarders simply quit. Without a skatepark, most were unmotivated to develop their own spots or simply lacked the knowledge to build something. For many years there was little new blood being infused into skateboarding's vertical veins. Street skating had become the norm and the vertical and bowl riding aficionados of yesterday were relegated to backyard ramps or the private made-to-skate bowls built by the few hardcore purists.
Fast forward. 1997. Vans Shoe Company decided to open a retail store in an Orange County, California mall. They also decided to build an indoor skatepark as well. Steve Van Doren decided to bring back an icon of the 1970's skatepark era: The Pipeline Combi Pool. It was a massive undertaking. On November 27, 1998, the Vans Combi Pool held its opening night. The older skateboarders of the 1970's era finally had a place to call home. Sessions were regular and they were heavy. On any given evening, there would be a packed house and almost all of the skaters on the deck were over thirty years of age. They couldn't know it at the time, but the Combi pool that they were skating was the start of something beautiful. The Vans Combi would help usher in an entire new era of bowlriding.
Liability laws were changed in the late 1990's and cities began building skateboard parks all over California. These parks had street areas and bowls. Accessibility. With the new skateparks, a resurgence began. Young skaters learned about bowl riding, carving and vertical. Some took the technical aspects of street skating and applied them to the skate park bowls. Hybridized. New blood filled old veins. The sport felt alive again. Skateboarding thrived. Bowl riding contests were still relegated to the Basic Bowl contest, Marseille contest in Europe and the Soul Bowl contest held in Huntington Beach each summer. In 2005, Vans stepped in and held the first Vans Protec Pool Party at the Combi pool in Orange, California. It would be the starting point, in which bowl riding contests would reach their former 1970's era popularity and eventually eclipse it.

item.title: Omar Hassan / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Back in the early 1990's, skateparks were obsolete. I rode streets, pools and anything else I could find. Kelly Belmar and Chicken built pools at the houses where they lived. Those two pools really helped our community in Orange County. We had our own scene and our own crew. Pool skating wasn't marketable so we just did our thing. Steve Alba was really the only guy out there finding backyard pools all of the time. He always had pools. It has a great deal to do with where you live. The first skatepark I ever rode was Pipeline. We were groms. One guy would go and the next would say "After" and someone else would say "After. After." and so on... we learned etiquette. Pro skaters would show up and we would sit down and watch. That was how we learned. There was more respect. I grew up skating pools and we had to have respect for the homeowner, the older guys in the crew and the Pro's. Skateboarding has come very far. It is acceptable to the mainstream. We were outcasts. Underground.
Once Steve Van Doren started building the Combi pool, I was stoked. It was where I lived. I was there often while they built it. My friends were on the crew. The old Pipeline Combi was hard to ride. It was gnarly. It had huge coping and a good deal of vert. Tony Hawk, Steve Caballero and Chris Miller tore that thing apart. The Vans Combi ended up being lumpy. The coping was huge and stuck out, but after a while, you just skated through it. You had to put in the work to skate it well. It made you adapt. The Pipeline Combi was challenging in the past and the Vans Combi was as well. This is what made it rad. The thing about the Combi pool is that sessions were made up of only the people who really wanted to ride it. It was bumpy, slippery... it was difficult. We loved it. When Vans first did the Protec Pool Party, they didn't know the impact it would have on skating. No one knew that it would do what it did. It brought back Miller, Grosso and everyone else. It gave them a resurgence.
The Protec Pool Party had a Jam format which allowed a skater to be creative. A skater can freestyle, flow, paint a picture, use the pool. It came from the Marseille, France bowl contest. Like the Combi pool, there are so many lines. The Jam format gives a skater a chance to really be creative... it highlights the best riding of the individual skater. The energy it brought made the event. Back at the beginning, there was nothing to really gain from entering. We respected and pushed each other. I liked the first couple of contests. It was awesome. Everyone threw their cards on the table. There were different characters. Red Scott. Jimmy the Greek. All had different styles and approaches.
After a few years, the format switched to timed runs, like in a vert ramp contest. Once they changed the format, it changed the contest. Skaters began using strategy. When there is strategy, it is less exciting. People started coming out and training for the contest. Skaters realized that the Combi pool contest was gnarly. The skateboard magazines started covering the event as well. There weren't many pool contests back then so the Protec Pool Party became the proving ground for pool skaters. A few years ago, Vans had the Combi pool refurbished. I'm down for change, but it feels like it has a vert ramp element to it now. It became easier for skaters to drop in and rip. It is still the Combi pool, but it is easier... I suppose my favorite contest is the first Protec Pool Party. I had no idea of how gnarly it would be. I was watching videos of past Pipeline Combi contests and seeing Chris Miller and everyone ripping. As contest day approached, I just put a great deal into it and sure enough, the energy and the contest was through the roof.

item.title: Lance Mountain / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
A good deal of credit can be placed at the feet of Rick Carge. He was responsible for building Chicken's and Belmar's pools. At the time, nothing else was really going on. In 1997, when Steve Van Doren decided to bring back the Combi pool, we thought, "Why built that thing again?" Once it was built and Vans started putting money into the contests, people started figuring it out and it really changed things. Over time, skaters started riding the Combi pool better. I find it interesting that it was the older skaters from the original Pipeline Combi that showed the younger skaters how it should be ridden. Skateboarding needs change. In recent years, Vans decided to change the Combi pool again. We smoothed out the surface and reshaped it. We wanted to make it friendlier and better. It would advance skateboarding as a whole.
An entire new generation came up with that pool. Skateboarders around the world are still asking for a comparable pool and that tells me something. The Pipeline Combi was special because it came and went before it was mastered by very many people.I think the Protec Pool Party contests are great. But once people realize that the contest is an avenue to success, it changes things. Money changes it all. The early Protec Pool Party contests were exciting. Not everyone entered yet. I didn't mind the Jam format though it shut some skaters down. The first year wasn't as attended but each year it increased in participation. I like these contests as it brings out the highest level of skating and the best in each individual. You get to see people charging hard. A whole crop of young skaters grew up in that pool. Josh Borden, Chris Russell, Austin Poynter, Tristan Rennie, Cory Juneau... so many. The Combi contest is art. It is a venue to see people express themselves.

item.title: Chris Miller / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I think because the original Pipeline Combi pool was so much a part of my early skating life, that I didn't think the Vans version being built could ever live up to it. I remember thinking, "Should they build that?" Once completed, I never really skated it too much. I remember that I kept comparing it to the old Pipeline Combi pool of my youth. The Vans Combi was slippery and lumpy and a lot of the old lines didn't work. Basically, I didn't appreciate it for what it was. When Steve Van Doren started having the Protec Pool Party, I really wasn't interested in skating in it. Lance Mountain was like, "Come on. It'll be fun." He convinced me. I started riding it more and figuring it out. I began to appreciate the pool for being its own thing and not a 'replica', but something new inspired by the old.
The first Protec Pool Party was really cool. I thought of it as a one off. I figured it was a cool event and it was over and wouldn't happen again. I have been to so many contests over the years, but the Protec Pool Party was really special, it had such a great vibe around it. It was really skateboarding appreciated by skateboarders. The contest was very unique and successful from the start. I didn't realize it would develop into what it did.
I love the Protec Pool Party because it is such a gathering. The energy at that contest is truly incredible. At the same time though it's that energy that elevates the level of skating during the contest itself. You get to see Steve Caballero, Rune Glifberg Pedro Barros and others take runs that they'd never do in just a normal session... everyone pushes their own level.
The Combi itself was refurbished a few years ago. I liked the old plaster version but I must say that the new improvements make it so much better. New lines opened up and it is no longer slippery. It is perfect. The whole reason that there are so many rad kids is because that pool is so perfect. The shape is great and the lines are endless. Kids are getting better all of the time. The most important thing to come from the Vans Combi and the Protec Pool Party is that it ignited an entirely new generation of bowl skaters.

item.title: Eric Nash / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was actually a bit confused when Vans built the Combi pool and brought it back. When I heard about it being built, I had a hard time picturing a pool of its size inside a warehouse. I didn't know what to make of it. The night of the first session, I was so stoked. All of the original guys came out. It was a bit gnarly. The Pipeline Combi was insanely difficult to ride but the Vans version was a bit nicer to skate. I enjoyed the new Combi pool for different reasons. We would acid-bath it to diminish the slickness of the plaster surface. After they refurbished it a few years back, I think it's amazing. They closed in the channel and this added more lines. The new surface is smooth and grips so... that is the main thing. It is much better. At the first Protec Pool Party, I watched. I was stoked. The contest brought back line skating, carves and tricks. There are so many lines in the Combi pool and they vary from rider to rider. It is an open canvas for each skater that drops in. It shows creativity, flair and style.
The early Protec Pool Party contests were really just jams and sessions. The energy level was straight through the roof. I don't recall such a cool atmosphere at a contest... ever. You can sit and watch skaters completely elevate their own game. There is no doubt that the Jam format is exciting. There is an awesome madness to it all, but people were getting hurt. Changing the format to timed runs brought the level down a notch but it is probably better for the contests longevity. I must admit that I love the practice sessions. It is awesome to see my friends and brothers. The last few years, there has been a huge influx of new blood. Young skaters ripping. It is so good to see. The young overtake the old. It is a good thing.

item.title: Mimi Knoop / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Around 2003, I went up to the Vans Combi and rode it with Brian Fick. I sucked at skating and while I was warming up, I broke my wrist. I was in a cast for three months. I told myself that I'd skate it again, get a grind and then never ride it after that. I went up and rode after I healed up and then the Protec Pool Party was announced. I started riding it more often but had a love/hate relationship with it. I soon fell in love with the Combi pool. The first Protec Pool Party was awesome. It was electric, authentic and different. I rode with Cara-Beth Burnside and Lyn-Z Adams Hawkins. The contest escalated each year and we got to know the pool better. After a few years, it became a bit less exciting. A whole new crop of riders, both male and female, began competing. Early on, it was more core people involved. The dynamic of the contest changed. In 2010, the Combi pool was refurbished and Steve Van Doren split the girls into a separate contest. I came up with the name and logo. Participation has increased every year, as have the number of spectators. The refurbishing of the Combi pool helped younger skaters get better in a shorter amount of time. It became much more user-friendly. With parents supporting the kids, better parks and more participation, it is changing the entire thing dramatically. Vans has championed the girls contest from the start. Every year we try to improve aspects of the contest. This past contest was the most crowded and the overall ability level was higher in all of the riders. It is really rad to see it happening.

item.title: Steve Caballero / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was excited to be able to ride the Combi pool again. I rode the original at the Pipeline skatepark in the 1970's. Steve Van Doren was having them bring the Combi back and they were going to modernize it. The original Combi was the gnarliest and best ever. I lived up north and I couldn't wait to skate the new Vans version. When I did ride, I was a bit disappointed to see that the shallow end wasn't bigger. The vert ramp behind the pool was fairly close and I thought that maybe there were space restrictions... Initially, I thought the Vans Combi was pretty good but I found it slippery. It had lumps and imperfections in the surface. I rode something smoother up north and when I came back the next time, I really noticed it. It was scary.
The original Protec Pool Party was more like a demo for Vans retailers as a gift to the people who supported Vans. It was for the annual sales meeting and was invitation only. When the contest started, it wasn't really a snake session but it became that way in later years in the Pro division. There would be two Pros riding at the same time. It was exciting to watch. The Masters division started to be that was as well. One year, I collided with Lance Mountain and knocked off his shoes. They had to change the format. No one wants to see friends get hurt. The refurbishing of the Combi pool has been amazing. It is the smoothest, most perfect pool ever. It was great that they filled in the channel too. It opened up new lines. The Combi pool contest really showcases bowl riding and the best in skateboarding.

item.title: Lincoln Ueda / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I rode the Vans Combi pool right after it was completed. I came to California in 1998 and Vans was my home park. I grew up skating big transitions in Brazil and the Combi pool was similar in size to what I was accustomed to. I recall that at the start, the Combi pool was very slick. We all got used to it though. The coping was big too. I remember that. I've skated most of the Protec Pool Party contests except two. If I recall, I was injured at the time of one contest and traveling during another. Otherwise, I ride in them. Where I grew up skating, there were no real hips like the Combi pool has. No vert hips. The Combi pool is the first place I learned how to ride them and learn the tight corners. I'm still trying to figure it out.
The contest level is now so much higher than it was at the start. The first two years were the most fun for me. I remember making it into the finals and during the finals I only took one run. It was a full on snake session. I was looking around and couldn't believe what I was seeing. I was just watching these guys ride. Bob Burnquist, Tony Trujillo, Bucky Lasek, Rune Glifberg... it was exciting. It was chaos. The format was changed after a few years as it was getting crazy. In the Combi, you can generate so much speed...and people couldn't get the lines they really wanted. It had to change. Once Vans refurbished the pool, it changed the whole game. The new surface, coping and removal of the channel opened up lines and allowed skaters to be more creative. It is night and day now. The new kids coming up have great bowls to skate now and more of them. They are hybrid skaters that can ride everything. It is a natural progression. Evolution.

item.title: Tristan Rennie / Combi FINAL
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I was around six or seven years old the first time I rode the Vans Combi pool. I went there with my dad and Steve Alba. It was very slippery. It was huge. The first time I rolled into the little channel, I hit the hip and just flew to the flatbottom. I didn't really like it as it was so big for me. I had skated Fontana South and Upland so when I skated the Combi pool, I just rode it and didn't really think about it in relation to the other places. I never went enough to get used to it. After the refurbishing, I started riding there more often. I heard that if you signed up to be in the AmTec contest, you could skate there for free leading up to the event. I signed up and rode it often. Once I got on the A List, I really went to the Combi often. That is when I started figuring it all out. The pool didn't feel so big anymore. I had grown up watching old Pipeline Combi videos and hearing the stories of how gnarly it was from everyone. It is crazy to think that we are still skating a similar designed pool all these years later. When the Vans Pool Party occurred this past year, I entered. I didn't have any pressure on me as I didn't think I could win and no one else did either. It was just cool to be in there skating with everyone. I was quite surprised when I won.

item.title: Brian Patch / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was living in Orange County and riding Chicken's, Belmar's and the Basic pool. It was what we had. I also had the 'Clockwork' or Soul bowl which was a ten foot deep bowl with a hip. We were also riding Tony Hawk's Birdland vert ramp in Costa Mesa. Those were the times and that is what we had to skate. The Vans Combi was built and opened in 1998. It was my home park. I rode it regularly. Once it opened and the newness wore off, it was sometimes hard to get a session in the Combi. If you were going to skate the pool, you had to bring the people with you that you wanted to ride with. Often, the pool just sat there empty in the corner. When Vans held the first Protec Pool Party, no one knew what to expect. I and a few others had an advantage because we rode it regularly. The Vans Protec Pool Party was the first time that big money had been put on the line. It attracted interest. I think some guys thought they could come out and vert ramp the pool but the Combi opened their eyes. You can't just show up and ride it like that. It'll hurt you.
Myself, Bob Burnquist, Omar Hassan, Rune Glifberg, Chris Miller, Jeff Grosso and the others were familiar with where to get speed and draw lines. We knew because we rode it. We put our time in. I came away from that first Protec Pool Party amazed. First, it was the best event I had ever been to. I recall seeing the media coverage of it and it was like a half page blurb. It was astounding that they held a contest in a replica of the Combi pool, complete with all of these legendary skateboarders and newer riders and the media didn't deem it worthy to even mention. Strange. Whatever the case may be, it was awesome. Ever year it has grown. The Jam format made it a Battle Royale with Dave Duncan on the Mic as Master of Ceremonies. He encouraged the Gladiatorial "Get in There" type of excitement. I would drop in with three other riders, fend them all off and then do my line and run. That's how it was. Eventually, people started colliding and it was changed.
They would also repair coping, tiles and acid bath the pool before contest day. I recall that the pool was so lumpy, I spent hours deep into the night in the pool with a sander, grinding down the lumps in an effort to decrease its wavy surface. It helped. Over the years, the event has changed. Things must. Being as the Combi is somewhat close to the original at Pipeline, the skateboard industry is concentrated here and the limited seating for the event, has all helped it in the end. It is attended by the hardcore skateboarders. Those that know the history of the pool, the event and its participants. That makes it a special event.
Since the refurbishing, it is even easier to skate. More friendly. At one time, the Legends and Masters were the most exciting thing to watch. Lately, the Amtec is just as exciting. The kids are ripping. The skill level is increasing. I recall that fifteen years ago, I'd walk into Vans and look over at the Combi, hoping someone would be there to session it. It often sat empty. I think, what if this contest hadn't happened? If it wasn't for Vans holding the contest, would the Combi pool still be here? Would it be bulldozed with a street course on top of it? I don't know. I know that our hats are off to Vans for putting it on the line financially and in business. The Vans Combi pool has made a huge difference.

item.title: Cara Beth Burnside / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I rode the original Pipeline Combi pool when I was very young. I think I was eleven years old. It was huge. When I heard that Vans was building the Combi again back in 1998, I was stoked. I thought it would be cool to ride that shap again. I had been riding Belmar's and Chicken's pool in Orange County. I really like Belmar's pool. I spent most of my time there. We had these two pools and the Basic Clover pool. That was it. I attended the opening night at Vans but I didn't ride. It was all blown out with everyone trying to get in there. I waited until it wasn't such a big scene and then I skated it. I liked it.
Once Steve Van Doren announced the Protec Pool Party, it gave me a reason to go to Vans and ride the pool more often. Everyone would gear up for the day and meet at Vans for a session. Mimi Knoop, Jen O'Brien and I would head up there and skate with all the guys. There would be ripping sessions going on. The first Protec Pool Party was so fun. At the time, competitive bowl riding was gone. It was done. The first couple of years, the Protec Pool Party was super rad. The vibe was different. It became super-competitive. People train for the contest now. They train. We never did such a thing before. We just got together and rode. There was nothing to win. It happens in everything. It evolves.
It is awesome to see all of the young girls skating and ripping. The refurbishing of the pool by Vans really helped too. I like the new Combi alterations but I still liked the old one. I liked the little roll-in channel. There are so many young girls participating in the contest now. Younger too. The more girls participating, the better overall. I have realized that it is more important for me to mentor the younger girl skaters than compete. In doing so, I can possibly help support them to excel at a higher level. I think that it is important.

item.title: Zach Miller / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
My first experience with the Vans Combi pool was the plaster version. I recall going up there for skate camp when I was about fifteen years old. I hated it. I actually didn't like that pool. The pool was lumpy, slippery and very hard to ride. It was gnarly. Secondly, I just felt that I had to skate it well because of my family name and all... It was a pressure that I put upon myself. I mean there are banners all around the room, it’s hard not to feel some kind of pressure. Avoiding that pool was just my way of dealing with it.
At the time they resurfaced the Combi pool, I had already turned sixteen and was driving to skate parks more. Up until then, I almost only skated vert. Once I started driving, I really began to ride concrete parks, pools and bowls.
When the Combi was refinished, I began riding it and applying myself. I learned how to skate it. I wasn't invited to ride in the Protec Pool Party that year but Lance and Grosso told me to keep going up everyday and skating anyway. Right before the contest, I was given a 'Wild Card' entry into it. This would be my first Pro Bowl contest ever. I was stoked but I was nervous too. The Combi contest is the most important event for me. It is one of the most respected contests by the industry, the hardcore skaters and I have a family legacy hanging above me on the banners overhead. I forsure give 110% effort when I skate that place.
It’s funny, The Combi went from one of my most hated pools to my favorite... It is fast and definitely has the most lines. I think last year was a bit of a strange event, as the guys that normally rule the pool like Rune Glifberg, Pedro Barros and Bucky Lasek, all over-extended themselves and derailed. Everyone was pushing their own limits so hard that it all came apart for them. The younger skaters stayed on their runs and did what they did. I’m predicting that is not gonna happen again.

item.title: Jen O' Brien / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Around the time that the Vans Combi was built, I rode for Vans. Cara Beth Burnside and I would ride Chicken's and Belmar's pools. If I recall, I was at the ribbon cutting ceremony at the mall when they began building the Vans Skate Park. After it was done, I remember Dave Duncan, Omar Hassan and I getting some of the first rides in the Combi. It was big, slick and gnarly... and it was in a shopping mall. That pool was like an ice skating rink. I grew up skating steel vert ramps in Florida so I was accustomed to such a surface. In the beginning, the Protec Pool Party contests were more of a grass-roots event. Everyone came out. It was quite a gathering. It would be Lyn Z, Mimi, CB, Nicole Zuch, Holly Lyons, April Woodcock and all of the Oregon girls... The event brought back competitive bowlriding and was the next evolution. Over the years, it grew more and more exciting. I'm proud of where the girls are at right now. The Combi and the contest really opened up the doors for girl skateboarders. I feel privileged to have seen it all from the beginning.

item.title: Austin Poynter / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The first time that I rode the Combi pool at Vans it was the plaster version. It is the first pool that I ever hit tiles in. I had nothing else to compare it to. I mostly rode vert ramps. The Amtec contest really helped. It forced me to get in there and figure out how to really ride the Combi pool. A skater must put time into it. It is big and difficult. When it was resurfaced and they filled in the shallow end channel, I think it opened up more opportunities. I love riding the Combi pool. I can skate it anyway I want. There are endless lines. As far as the Combi contest, riding Pro was a bit surreal. It is hard to put into words. My dad would bring me up on contest day and I'd watch from the bleachers. Now, I'm actually in the contest riding with riders that I've always looked up to. I was standing next to Bucky Lasek as he dropped in and I knew it was my turn next...

item.title: Josh Borden / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Vans was my first skatepark. I was a local rat. My mom worked across the street and I would get dropped off and spend the day skating it. I loved the slick, lumpy version of the Combi pool. It made it special. I don't think people remember just how gnarly that pool was. You couldn't just show up and rip that thing. It is very cookie-cutter now. I'd be there skating and Salba, Omar, Grosso, Lance, Black Label Tom, Belmar and Duane would come in. I'd skate with all of them because I was always there. I have been to every Vans Protec contest. I didn't ride in the first one but I got in the second year as a 'Wild Card'. The contest, vibe and skating were awesome. Everyone was going for it and you had to just get in there and snake. Bob Burnquist and Brian Patch were in my heat. I was thinking, "I gotta go against these guys!?" That year, I kick-flipped into the pool from the deck. Because it was a Jam format, I could do it several times until I made it. That format really amps it up. Crazier stuff happened with that format. I spent a great deal of time riding the original plaster version of the pool. A skater had to put in the work. Since it is refurbished, it made the lines easier.

item.title: Alex Perelson / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The first time that I rode the Combi pool, I remember thinking, "...and people actually ride this?" I'd just ride the vert ramp instead. Eventually, I went up to practice for the Protec Pool Party to try and figure it out. I had the help of those that had ridden it before. I recall it being slippery much of the time. I know that I rode it in a vert ramp type of skating but now when I go there, I try to ride it like a bowl. I feel that this is the way it was meant to be skated. I like the event and feel that it is the best one of the year. Everyone attends and the energy is great. I love to watch Rune Glifberg, Jeff Grosso, Bob Burnquist and Chris Miller. After the pool was refurbished and surfaced, I think it made it much easier for kids to come in and ride. I think that it is a travesty that a nine hundred was done in the Combi pool. The Combi pool should be ridden with style and power and I think that a nine hundred goes against the very nature of bowl riding. A few things that I really have enjoyed are Rune's back tail shuvit through the corner, Pedro Barros skating and Jeff Grosso's performances every year. Overall, I feel that this event really helped legitimize bowl riding contests once again.

item.title: Rune Glifberg / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I never had the opportunity to skate the Upland Combi at the Pipeline Skate Park, but I rode the Vans plaster Combi while it was being built. I recall Dave Duncan taking us there and we cruised around before it had any coping. I had moved to Huntington Beach from Denmark in 1994. Chicken's and Belmar's pools were what we rode regularly. Those pools were my introduction into pool skating. We had to use copers at the time. I believe that this was before 'Salba Sauce' and Chicken and Belmar were trying to protect the coping on the pools they built in their backyards. I could already skate vert ramps but riding these pools and the backyard pools that Remy Stratton took me to was a humbling experience. It opened up a whole new genre of skating for me. I have to admit that I liked the Vans Combi, but not at first. The pool was slippery and gnarly. Once the Protec Pool Party was announced, I started practicing and riding more. It took me awhile to figure that pool out.
I feel that the first three years of Protec contests, were the years where I really developed the lines I use now. I don't recall looking at the old videos of past Pipeline Combi contests to try and figure out lines for the pool. I concentrated on trying to develop my own approach to skating the pool and I added technical tricks to my lines early on. I think that kick-flip back side lipslides and other technical tricks helped set me apart from other skaters that rode the Combi pool regularly. In the first several contests, I loved the open Jam format. It was dangerous but... we knew and respected each other in those early contests. We knew each other well and rode together often. It was controlled and respectful snaking. I feel that this format really showcased bowlriding. It allowed me to try tricks that I may have been a bit inconsistent with, like a Cab heelflip. Even if I didn't make it in my first attempt, I could come back and try again. I think this format raised the level of the contest.
The first Protec contests were like a session at the Nude Bowl back in the day. There were like twenty or thirty guys in the shallow end, all vying to get in there and take a run. Everyone was ready and waiting for the guy to fall so they can get in there... That was how the early Protec contests were. Then, guys started complaining because they couldn't really deal with that form of snaking and sessioning. The format was changed and it changed everything. It became a consistency game. Vans decided to resurface and change the pool a few years ago. California Skateparks came in and did the entire thing over. After the resurfacing, the pool definitely got better. Personally, I rather liked the bumpy old pool. I loved the little roll-in channel too. The subsequent changes in the format and the pool brought a different feel to the event.

item.title: Coliseum
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_19963" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jerry Valdez[/caption] August 1977. The city baked under the angry glare of the sun. Smog. Pollution. A yellow haze hung in the air like a bad reminder: "Don't breathe too deeply." Cars jostled for position on the freeways and the streets were crowded as always. Concrete. Humanity. A frantic-paced world of chrome, glass and sweat. Jerry Valdez and Kent Senatore cut down an offramp from the 110 freeway. They slipped the car into traffic and moved into the sun driving up Exposition Boulevard. The Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum squatted on the left side of them like a giant statue to the gods. Its sprawling parking lots were empty and the team pennants and banners hung lifeless in the hot summer air. Jerry lit another joint and inhaled deeply. Ted Nugent wailed away on the stereo as he handed the smoking weed to Kent. They were headed to the Coliseum Bowl. The neighborhood had changed in the ensuing years since the city had built the Coliseum. Poverty reigned now. Houses sat vacant. Liquor stores flourished and drug dealers peddled their vice to an ever-hungry population. Escape. Despair. They both knew that there were awesome pools to be found in the ghetto's of Los Angeles. They drove around and found them. They kept it positive and real. Kent laughed as Jerry made faces and yelled out of the car at a few teenage girls walking nearby. They pulled up to the pool. Kent helped get the brooms and buckets out of the car. The house sat boarded up. Life had left this place a long time ago. Jerry and Kent pulled old furniture and a bathroom sink out of the deep end. It was a beautiful square pool and the mid wall transitions looked perfect. A few local kids cruised by and watched. Once Jerry and Kent started riding, the local kids grew excited. This is what skateboarding is all about! Jerry pulled frontside grinds as a few local thugs came to the pool. They tried to intimidate but Jerry wasn't having it. They kept riding and the drug slingers left them to their pool. This one lasted for a short while only to be replaced by others. Shelf life then no life. Bulldozers reduced the property to rubble. This image and Jerry's memories are most of what remains. It seems that it is all we'll ever need. Thank you to Jerry Valdez for the memories and Bill Sharp for the image. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Napoleon
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Napoleon is the name of a turkey. He lives on a farm in San Diego county. He is the bird and he runs those grounds... There is a pool there. I found it on a hot summer morning last year.

item.title: Dave Duncan / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The 1990's was a good time in action sports. I was the head foreman for a crew of guys. We'd build all of the ramps and street courses for he Vans Triple Crown series. It was Vans and skateboarders. One hundred percent skating. Vans was doing really well and they decided to start building skateparks and retail stores in malls. The first one selected was in Orange, California and I was asked to help with the project. I told them that I thought we should put in bowls and I instantly thought of the original Pipeline Combi pool. I had ridden there in the 1980's and had watched all of the contests from that place over its lifetime. I had watched many of the local rippers like Steve and Micke Alba, Chris Miller, Lester Kasai, along with other legendary pool riders- Neil Blender, Lance Mountain, Christian Hosoi, Duane Peters, Eddie Reategui and others. They ripped that place. It was gnarly.
On the Vans Triple Crown Tour, I had always watched and wondered how modern pro's like Bob Burnquist, Rune Glifberg, Omar Hassan and Bucky Lasek would skate the Combi pool. When Vans gave us the go-ahead to bring back the Combi pool at the new Vans park, I knew that building that pool again, would be a way to link the past with the present. My good friend Rick Carje had built Kelly Belmar's, Chicken's and Basic Bowl in Orange County. He would be the one in charge of building the Vans Combi pool. We kept it plaster, tiles and coping. I really wanted a classic 1970's skatepark pool and it came out good.
After a few years in operation, Vans decided to hold a pool contest in the Combi. We had been doing the Soul Bowl and Trifecta contests but the Protec Pool Party would become a thing all its own. The Soul Bowl and Trifecta contests had been a place to bring back the Legends like Duane Peters, Steve Alba and others. I thought, "What could be a more appropriate venue than to have them skate in the Combi pool at the Protec Pool Party?" The first Protec Pool Party was insane. We had a Jam format with everyone just getting into the pool and riding. Guys were just going for it. It was a classic jam format with three guys in the pool at once.
People started colliding and stuff so the format was changed. I think we did an introduction run for each rider, a ten minute jam and then an exit run. Eventually, as pool building progressed, Vans had the pool refurbished by California Skateparks and it is the best pool in the world. The original Pipeline Combi pool was only around for a few years but it had a massive impact on the skateboarding world. The Vans Combi has already been around longer than that and its legacy is still being written. Generations of skateboarders are coming up riding the Vans Combi pool and it will be interesting to see it change the discipline of pool riding.

item.title: Brian Patch / Combi FINAL
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was living in Orange County and riding Chicken's, Belmar’s, and the Basic pool. It was what we had and it was a dream come true for me. Being from the mid-west, I was used to driving to different states to get a vert or round wall session. I was also in charge of the “Clockwork Bowl”, “Soul Bowl” which was an indoor ten foot deep bowl with a hip. We built a sixty four foot wide mini in there and it was also known as “The Hub”. We were also riding Tony Hawk's Birdland vert ramp in Costa Mesa. Those were the times and that is what we had to skate and we were loving it! The Vans Combi was built and opened in 1998. It was my home park. I rode it regularly. Once it opened and the newness wore off, it was sometimes hard to get a session going in the Combi. If you were going to skate the pool, you had to bring the people with you that you wanted to ride with. Often, the pool just sat there empty in the corner. Kids were scared to step to it and no one was very welcoming to them. When Vans held the first Protec Pool Party, no one knew what to expect. I and a few others had an advantage because we rode it regularly. The Vans Protec Pool Party was the first time that big money had been put on the line. It attracted interest. I think some guys thought they could come out and vert ramp the pool but the Combi opened their eyes. You can't just show up and ride it like that. It'll hurt you.
Myself, Bob Burnquist, Omar Hassan, Rune Glifberg, Chris Miller, Jeff Grosso and the others were familiar with where to get speed and draw lines. We knew because we rode it. We put our time in. I came away from that first Protec Pool Party amazed. First, it was the best event I had ever been to. I felt like I had been through some sort of religious experience! A revival of the great days of the big park pool comps I grew up watching that made me want to accept skateboarding as my savior. I recall seeing the media coverage of it and it was like a half page blurb. It was astounding that they held a contest in a replica of the Combi pool, complete with all of these legendary skateboarders and newer riders and the media didn't deem it worthy to even mention. Strange. Whatever the case may be, it was awesome. Ever year it has grown. The Jam format made it a Battle Royale with Dave Duncan on the Mic as Master of Ceremonies. He encouraged the Gladiatorial "Get in There" type of excitement. I would drop in with three other riders, fend them all off and then do my line and run. That's how it was. Eventually, people started colliding and it was changed.
They would also repair coping, tiles and acid bath the pool before contest day. I recall that the pool was so lumpy. The standard practice in the pool pouring business was to shot crete the form of the pool, let it cure, then plaster it. The final step was to fill the pool with water and let it settle and cure. This technique allows all the walls to be pressed by the pressure of the water. It usually leaves the walls wavy. The Combi was no exception. I kept bugging Steve Van Doren to let me in there with a grinder to smooth out as much as possible. I remember one year in the pre comp, Combi prep night, I got my wish fulfilled. We started at closing and I had built a jig that hung over the coping that held me up on the tranny and vert to reach what I couldn’t from the flat. I spent hours deep into the night in the pool with a sander, grinding down the lumps. My back was wrecked but i knew I only had that moment to do as much as I could while Steve Van Doren was wanting to go home to his family. Finally, at four in the morning, he cut me off.
It helped a lot. It was smoother and faster. I thought people would be so stoked on the new surfacing and not too many people even noticed. It was a nearly thankless effort but I”d do it all over again. Over the years, the event has changed. Things must. Being as the Combi is somewhat close to the original at Pipeline, the skateboard industry is concentrated here and the limited seating for the event, has all helped it in the end. It is attended by the hardcore skateboarders. Those that know the history of the pool, the event and its participants. That makes it a special event.
Since the refurbishing, it is even easier to skate. More friendly. At one time, the Legends and Masters were the most exciting thing to watch. Lately, the Amtec is just as exciting. The kids are ripping. The skill level is increasing. I recall that fifteen years ago, I'd walk into Vans and look over at the Combi, hoping someone would be there to session it. It often sat empty. I think, what if this contest hadn't happened? If it wasn't for Vans holding the contest, would the Combi pool still be here? Would it be bulldozed with a street course on top of it? I don't know. I know that our hats are off to Vans for putting it on the line financially and in business. The Vans Combi pool has made a huge difference.

item.title: Fruit Bowl Revisited
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
One day, Tony Alva and I were driving in Orange County. We were going someplace I no longer remember, but it was probably skateboard related. We were sitting at a red light on Brookhurst and he calmly points to his right and states, “That’s where the Fruit Bowl was.” I was quickly rendered inept as I followed his gaze. No longer watching the lights and traffic, I peered around as he pointed to some condos in the nearby distance. TA continued, ” My dad once lived over in those condos. They were built on the site of the Fruit Bowl…”. A car horn brought me back from his reverie and I stabbed the gas pedal to get through the green light that had changed. Traffic was moving. [caption id="attachment_8886" align="aligncenter" width="404"] Doug Schneider[/caption] [caption id="attachment_8879" align="aligncenter" width="584"] David Hackett - side stairs[/caption] [caption id="attachment_8892" align="aligncenter" width="500"] Doug Schneider[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19977" align="alignnone" width="2048"] Chris Saglin[/caption] I asked TA how the pool received its name, Fruit Bowl. “It was at a rundown mental hospital”, he grinned. Recently, I spoke with David Hackett about his first time visiting the pool and he told me that he caught a ride there,  as he was too young to drive. He was really stoned that visit, but remembered that there were at least fifty people there. ” It was a heavy scene. Waldo Autry was king there. He ruled the place. He did ‘forever figure -eight′ carves and frontside and backside carves over the stairs that were on both sides of the pool.” David Hackett said that TA and Jay came to the Fruit Bowl. Both rode really well, pulling edgers and Jay tried hand plants on the wooden tombstone extension.
