[caption id="attachment_19983" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Adams Image: Welman[/caption] “If you didn’t have pool skills and couldn’t rip, you sat in the shallow end. You watched. It was a gnarly scene there.” David told me to talk with Steve Olson as he had ridden there early on. I phoned Steve Olson and he added a bit of history as well. “I was one of the first people to drain the Fruit Bowl. Guys that I knew, rode their bikes in it. One guy named Willy and some others. It was insane! The pool was not a bust and lasted like six months until it became a party spot and the police finally shut it down.” [caption id="attachment_8889" align="aligncenter" width="584"] TA[/caption]
[caption id="attachment_19976" align="alignnone" width="2048"] Wally Inouye[/caption]
Thanks to everyone for their memories . Thanks to Scott Bunnell for the epic photographs. Thanks to Wally Inouye, Mr. Welman, Bobby Smith, Warren Bolster R.I.P., David Hackett and Jim Goodrich for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey Ozzie - thanks for writing this article. I was one of the locals that lived a few blocks from the Fruit Bowl so my buds and I were there daily and remember the great sessions when the Dogtown guys and others came through. I'll never forget the week I finally got up on to the tiles carving backside. What made that week more significant was one evening riding my bike up that long driveway that was completely demolished by the city, only to get to the pool and see it all caved in. Man, I was stunned and pissed at the same time. Thanks Garden Grove for such a bone-headed decision as they ruined one of the greatest pools in skate history.

item.title: Bucky Lasek / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I was at the Vans Skate Park for opening night. We rode the Combi pool and the vert ramp. I recall the pool being lumpy and a bit difficult. It was difficult to get comfortable with. We would drive up to Vans and skate it periodically. Sometimes, I'd skate the pool and work on things. I was filming for a Birdhouse video and that was when I began putting difficult tricks together and lines. I began to feel more comfortable with the pool. It was definitely something I had to always step up to. I had to really attack the pool. A skater couldn't just come to the Combi pool and rip. It was gnarly. That pool bit back hard.
When they started having the Protec Pool Party, I entered some of the early ones. I think that on the first year that I entered, I took only two runs in the final. The second year I entered, I took three runs. The Jam format was crazy. I would be dropping into the pool and riding with three or four people. I had to keep trying to put together a line while I was looking over my shoulder to see where the other skaters were. It was chaotic. Once people started running into each other, they changed the format. Up to that point, I think it was a "Did you see what just happened?" type of event, rather than a pool contest. Spectators were getting caught up in the excitement of the near collisions. In my opinion, that style of format lowers the standard of skateboarding, because skaters are focusing on not colliding with each other, rather than doing their very best individual skateboarding. If it's a timed open Jam format, it becomes quantity over quality.
I like that they changed the format. I think it let a skater show what he can do. It allowed a skater to ride and not just survive. When Vans refurbished the Combi pool, it made it easier to skate. It is a better pool and one of my favorite places to ride. However, I believe that refurbishing the pool also took away what that era was about. In the plaster version of the Combi pool, it was gnarly. You had to really ride the pool. You had to go all-out to ride it well. The pool wasn't giving it to you. The refurbishing makes it easier to get everything. That is the real difference.

item.title: Mimi Knoop / Combi Final
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Around 2003, I went up to the Vans Combi for the first time with Brian Fick. I sucked at skating at the time, and while I was warming up, I broke my wrist. I was in a cast for three months. I told myself that I'd never skate that hellhole again. A few weeks after my cast came off, the first ever Protec Pool Party contest was announced. I started riding it once again, but I definitely had a love/hate relationship with the place. But, I soon fell in love with the Combi pool. The first Protec Pool Party was awesome. It was electric, authentic and just had a different feel to it compared to other events at the time. I skated with Cara-Beth Burnside, Lyn-Z Adams Hawkins, Jessica Starkweather, Kim Petersen among others. The contest escalated each year and we got to know the pool better.
Over the span of a few years, the vibe of the contest changed a little bit; maybe it morphed into something else? Less raw and electric, and more like a place to learn and perfect bowl skating. A breeding ground of sorts. A whole new crop of riders (both guys and girls) began competing each year. In 2010, the Combi pool was refurbished and Steve Van Doren split the girls into a separate contest. I came up with the name and logo for the “Combi Pool Classic”. Participation has increased every year since, as have the number of spectators.
The refurbishing of the Combi pool helped younger skaters get better in a shorter amount of time. It became much more user-friendly, although still challenging in it’s own ways. With parents supporting the kids, and more local parks popping up, we started to see more participation on all fronts. Vans has championed the girls contest from the start. Every year we try to improve aspects of the event to make it better. The most recent Combi Pool Classic (Jan. 2015) was definitely the most crowded and we saw that the overall ability level of the girls was higher than ever. It has been awesome to see the progression and evolution of skateboarding over the past ten years at the Combi.

item.title: Lizzie Armanto
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The first time I went to the Vans park and saw the Combi pool, it seemed pretty daunting. Its size. Its shape. The Combi pool is unlike anything else so its difficult to draw ant comparisons. It was bumpy and had big, gnarly coping as well. I learned 50-50's and rock-n-rolls in that old pool. I was at a Bucky Lasek Skate Camp. I was so sketchy at the time. I still cannot believe I did those things in that slippery old pool. The 2009 Protec Pool Party was my first contest ever. I was obviously smaller and younger then. Everyone at SMA was urging me to compete. SMA was my sponsor at the time. Before the contest, everyone was snaking. I stood over in the shallow end corner ready to drop in for like thirty minutes. People just kept going. All of the sudden, I was moved aside by someone and they dropped right in and snaked me too. The skater popped out and introduced himself. "Hi. I'm Dave Duncan." It was the first time I ever met him. Later, I heard people giving him shit for it...
I recall getting 9th place that day. I remember seeing the banners with the names on them. I had a strange far-fetched goal to get my name on one of them. "Someday..." I thought. The next year, I won the Protec contest. But they had separated the girls out of the Protec Pool Party and gave us our own event. No more banners. I guess I'll have to get over that one. Once they resurfaced and changed the Combi pool, I basically lived there. It became my local park. I progressed much faster. I don't think I'd really be where I am if it wasn't for the Combi pool. There is nothing like it. The attitude of the people that it draws are what make it special. The people that skate it.
I have to say, I've taken my worse slam at the Combi and I know I'm not alone. Ive heard other people say it. The pool can make you pay. This past year, Poppy Starr slammed. She was down in the pool and I was the first one in with her. She had blood gushing out of her head so I covered it up with my jacket. I told her, "I don't want o freak you out or anything, but you slammed in the Combi, you're bleeding all over and you look really rad..." Poppy just smiled. What other young girl in the world could smile about such a thing? Skateboarders.

item.title: Rick Carje
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
RCMC was my company. Rick Carje Masonary Contractors. We even had an AC/DC type logo and everything. I started doing concrete work during the summers in high school. Once I graduated, I kept at it and eventually began to build swimming pools in the late 1980's. I always wanted to build skateboard parks. I had been a skater since the early 1970's so it was a natural direction for me to go. I worked with Dave Duncan over the years building ramps all over the place. I helped build Kelly Belmar's pool, then Chicken's pool in Huntington Beach. Soon after that, I started building skateparks. While I was in Long Island, New York building a skatepark, Dave Duncan called me. I was with my tiny crew which consisted of my brother Kyler and Tim Trudell. Duncan explained that Vans was building a skatepark at a mall in Orange, California and he wanted to bring me in to build the pool and the concrete areas.
I flew back for a meeting and some of the Vans people were there as well. We generated the idea of building a replica of the original Pipeline Combi pool. We spoke with Don Hoffman of the original park and got some overviews of the pool. We laid them over blueprints of the Vans park and put them over the space requirements. We squeezed it, altered it and fit it in behind the vert ramp. Chicken, Duncan, Chuck Hults, Kelly Belmar and I brainstormed on what size radius to use for the corners. What transitions would be best. What would be the ultimate that would fit in the space requirements? We kept fine-tuning the drawings. The original timeline gave us three months to finish the park and with a crew of like twenty-five guys, we finished the Combi pool itself in about a month.
We dug it to perfection, thinking at that time, it was the best way to achieve the ultimate bowl. We cut wooden templates and sprayed the shell of gunite in a day. It was a monster of a bowl. Coping and tiles were set soon after and then the plaster guys came in. I was down in the bowl with the guys troweling along side them while the rest of the crew looked on and helped keep it as flawless as possible. After that, it was out of our hands. It was hard to wait it out. We filled the pool with water after the plaster was done and it sat for three weeks to cure. To add to the stress, the mall management moved the grand opening forward and we were told we had three weeks to finish the rest of the park. That's why the black-bottom bowl never really worked out well. We were rushed to completion. There was pressure to finish it all. I think I slept in my truck every night during those last few weeks. It almost killed me.
I think the last few nights before opening, we drained the pool with these huge diesel pool pumps. We drained it into outdoor sewer inlets. A hose burst at one point and started flooding the parking lot. 10,000 gallons of water... everywhere. Sometime around dawn, it was empty. At that point, we were working two crews, day and night in order to complete the park on time. The night work crew were the first to ride it. I can't tell you who took the first run. We were delirious at that point. Exhausted.

item.title: Jami Godfrey
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The winter is in full grip here on the East Coast but the desire to ride transition is stronger than the cold weather. While on the left coast for The El Gato Classic, it seemed to me that there is a sweet skate spot around every corner.  Back home on the right coast, opportunities to skate are fewer and far between – especially for a fifty year old with two active kids and a business to run. When it was listed I would be attending The El Gato Classic, Brian Finn reached out to me to see if I wanted to skate.  He built a huge vertramp in his warehouse. I gladly accepted his offer and made several trips to his house to get back into skating again after a long hiatus from skating vert. For me, everything seemed new again since my skating sessions were few and far between over the past twenty years.  Brian's ramp is big and gnar. Over two feet of vert is not the way to ease your way back into the challenges of skating. The sessions were fun – just me Brian and Anthony Anastasio. There was no pressure, just three friends enjoying that feeling of weightlessness on vert. At first we were all a bit rusty, but soon we were all getting back in to the swing. After three or four sessions at Finns ramp, Anthony mentioned that friends were building a pool in a warehouse. He showed me and Brian a picture of this virgin pool that was still curing. From the picture, I knew I wanted to ride it. This pool is reminiscent of the pools that spoiled me during my days as a full-fledged Bones Brigade airman. It's also the reason I faded from skating for so many years! No concrete. No curves to carve for decades faded my desire to challenge Isaac Newton’s laws of gravity for many years! [caption id="attachment_19850" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jami Godfrey - El Gato Classic[/caption] It’s Eddie Elguera that reconnected me with this lost love.  The invitation I received from Eddie to go to his reunion of my Gold Cup Series competitors sparked a flame. I asked Anthony if we could go up upon my return from the El Gato Classic. I was fresh home from California with some great pools and loads of old friends to stoke me. I made the effort to get a group to skate this fresh new pool. I contacted Anthony, Brian, Tom Boyle, & Charles Treece. All were hopeful to skate, but in the end it was just me and Brian that were able to commit. With Anthony unable to skate, Patrick Guidutti reached out to us since he has access to the key.  The last time I skated with Patrick Guidotti was also the first time -  almost two years ago at Falls Township public skatepark in Bucks County, PA.  Patrick’s style and bag of tricks was bewildering to me, especially since we were riding a mini ramp that he rips like it’s a vert ramp.  I was stoked for the chance to see him ride this new pool and grateful that he invited us to go along.   It was February 12th and winter was still torturing the Right Coast!  Brian and I met on the PA Turnpike to start our journey for a two hour drive to this fresh secret pool. The ride with Brian passed quickly as we drove through some heavy snow squalls and spoke of my recent sojourn out West. We spoke of many we knew from our past like Tom Groholski and how he blazed on at skating long after I took a hiatus from skating. We spoke of Sean Miller and how the rest of the world was discovering his talents just prior to his tragic death. Brian Spoke of Tom Boyle and how he lives so close to him yet rarely skates! I told Brian that I knew we'd get to skate with Tom soon. Just a few winter sessions with good friends is all it took for me to realize why I still skate. At fifty years of age, looking back, I realize the talents I mastered as a teenager have withered a bit, but I can still do it and do it cautiously!  In 1980, no one thought that some of us would still skate, but if you can do it why lose it!   As we got to the supposed location of  this warehouse we called our host Patrick and there was no answer from his phone. We knew we were in the right area but we were just not sure which door was the right one. The door that held secrets from the throngs of other skaters that wanted to skate a pool. We came this far and were not going to turn around just yet. Finally a man opened one of the many warehouse doors in this alley where we stood freezing. I asked him if he may know of a secret pool in one of these warehouses. He quickly replied that it was just three doors down from this one. [caption id="attachment_19853" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jami[/caption] I banged hard on the door for several minutes. Finally a man with a full beard answered my knocking.. He asked who I was since my board was still back at the car. I told him I was a friend of Patrick Guidotti and anxious to skate.. He introduced himself as Rob and was the key master as well as the pool’s originator. I entered the warehouse and was awed by its existence. Before me a left hand kidney sits in the front of the warehouse and a nice standard mini ramp lies in the rear.  It was twenty five hundred feet of pure joy hidden in this unassuming warehouse . It was close to 9:30 when we got there and a session was already in full swing. The only one I knew skating was Patrick, but he was not the only one utilizing the bowl to its full potential. [caption id="attachment_19854" align="aligncenter" width="439"] Patrick[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19855" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bob[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19856" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ray[/caption] Brian and I quickly got our gear on and went straight to the pool. Each concrete pool is unique and hence its attraction!  I was under the assumption that most of the fellow skaters were locals to this privy pool. Turns out Bill Pribble and his friend Ray Conklin were from the Washington DC. Area and drove five hours for the lore of new carvable concrete. A guy named Chris -- I didn’t get his last name -- was another rider that night and he possessed a smooth, clean style that got my attention. Corey Rubin was also a new friend that rounded out this private session. [caption id="attachment_19858" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chris[/caption] [caption id="attachment_19857" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey[/caption] All in the warehouse felt a warmth and closeness even those not skating. A good skate session is like a good party. We all made new friends, shared smiles, and felt the buzz of the energy that our bodies and wheels had made. This is often the case with a good pool session. People that don’t even know one another seem to feel a closeness just from their abilities as fellow skaters. Here at this session I only knew Patrick and Brian yet we all shared in the energy of the moment. We admired the lines and styles that are inherent to each skater. After two hours of skating we all felt a bit younger in our heads from the energy we created indoors. At close to midnight on a week night with kids and wives waiting for us, it was time for Brian and I to wrap up our session. We said our thanks and good-byes and were all pleased with the course that our night had taken. As we opened the warehouse door to the biting chill of the windy twelve degree night a smile came to my face knowing that the desire to skate can overcome anything – even the cold grip of winter! I anxiously await the next opportunity to skate this spot again knowing it will be there for another session. I am hopeful to share with both new found friends and those I have yet to meet! Thank you to Jami Godfrey for the words and John Falls for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: is this the same dude that has a huge 3 pocket bowl in his backyard just outside washignton D.C. if it is we hit that thing on the way back to montreal from north carolina .awsome

item.title: Grosso / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I went to Vans when they dug the hole for the Combi pool. Bringing back the Combi pool was an amazing concept. At that time, if you rode transitions at all, there was really nothing to ride. It was all gone. Parks were done. There were pockets of places. Portland, Huntington Beach. If you lived near Huntington Beach, you had Chicken's and Belmar's pools. They built pools in their own backyards. There were also vert ramps here and there. Steve Van Doren decided to build skateparks. Rick Carje had a mason business and he received the bid for the job. Dave Duncan, Tim Trudell, Chicken, Kelly Belmar, Chuck Hults... they were all in there trying to help. They sat down and brought the Combi to life. John Lucero and I thought it was a crazy idea. Why bring back something that was already made? The people started digging. I recall arguments. The 'Cock & Balls' bowl was supposed to be a knockoff of the old San Juan pool. Early on, we were disenchanted. Too many cooks in the kitchen. All we wanted was really cool shit. We rode old skateparks and we wanted something rad.
Walking onto the job site, I saw the square shallow end had been dug out. It was way too small. "You done digging the shallow end"? Carje said that it was how it was going to be. I had to shut up. I didn't know anything... which I thought was funny. Carje, Belmar, Chuck and Chicken made a pendulum to cut the walls. They really came together to try and build it right. Ultimately, they got it done. It was under insane circumstances. Mall management. Steve Van Doren was trying to get it done by launch date. There was stress all around. Opening night came and we all gathered together and rode it. It was quirky. The only similarities between the old Pipeline Combi and this one was the shape. Otherwise, it was completely different. Both pools had personalities. Lumps and bumps. Imperfections. Overall, it was great. Skateparks were back. It did really well at first. Steve Van Doren saw how he could bring skateparks back through retail stores at malls and he sold the idea. Vans built parks in Washington DC, Orlando, Bakersfield, Detroit, Ontario, Milpitas, Arizona, Orange, Texas and Colorado. The parks became better and better.
During the same period, the Oregon guys were building DIY spots. Skateboarding was fairly demonized. Laws were changing though and becoming less restrictive. Dreamland, Grindline and California Skateparks began building parks all over. Early builders learned in a trial by fire. They built some crappy stuff but they learned from their mistakes. They would modernize the skatepark bowl designs. We don't ride like we rode in the 1980's. Skateboarding evolved and park design had to move with it. The Vans collection of skateparks began closing. Most of the retail space was too expensive and with free skateparks popping up every few months, skaters simply went to the free parks rather than pay at a Vans park. After the Z -Boys and Dogtown movies, there was a groundswell of enthusiasm for transition skating. Transition skaters were pushed into the mainstream. Steve Van Doren closed the other skateparks but kept the Orange location with its Combi pool. It was close to Vans Corporate offices.
Steve had always supported skateboard contests and he envisioned a Combi contest like the kind he remembered from the early days. He decided to have the Protec Pool Party contest. Vans owned Protec helmets, so it was named accordingly. Tylenol was one of the first sponsors of the event. I don't think Steve received too much support at the beginning. There was a pretty big prize purse announced so people started really showing up to practice. Contest day was magical. The energy was incredible and everyone left the Vans park with a buzz from the event. The first couple of years were gnarly. Dick measuring. Posturing. In the Masters event, the joke started about the contest being for 2nd Place as no one could touch Chris Miller. People came out of the woodwork. Mike Smith, Buck Smith, Eddie Elguera, Eric Nash. It became a pilgrimage.
The Protec Pool Party jump-started the heart of pool skating competition. The wars between Rune Glifberg and Omar Hassan were epic. It was like a flashback to the Christian Hosoi and Tony Hawk wars of the early 1980's. Rune would try to out-tech Omar and he would just answer back with another crazy run. Everyone threw down, every year. Steve Van Doren built it and started us rolling again. Every year we would repair coping and tiles just before the Protec Pool Party. Around 2010, Lance Mountain was working with California Skateparks and Steve Van Doren approved a refurbishing of the Combi pool. It was our home park and we wanted to give it new life. We filled in the channel, smoothed out the transitions and resurfaced the entire pool. It made the pool much more user-friendly. It was not as slippery and dangerous. A whole new generation of skateboarders are able to ride the Combi pool and the Combi pool contests have only become better and better each year.

item.title: Steve Alba / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Rick Carje started building the Combi at Vans. It wasn't quite the same shape really. They didn't ask for our opinions. Kelly Belmar came up with the pendulum idea to cut the walls and Carje made it his own and ran with it. The pendulum worked well and does to this day. The hip could've been better and the shallow end bigger. The Vans Combi was plaster, like a real pool. The original Pipeline Combi was modeled after a pool. Both versions were gnarly. In the Badlands, we grew up skating all sorts of pools. We really looked for huge square pools. Euclid square, the L-Pool and the Skull Bowl, which was in Ontario. At the Ontario airport, was an old staging area for the war. It was disused. There were barracks and there was a huge pool for the troops. We'd ride the pool regularly. All of the Badlands skaters loved flatwall and square pools and this is where the original Pipeline square pool idea came from. We combined the best of a round pool with a really good square pool. Hence, the Combi. I find it interesting that when the Vans Combi was plaster, imperfect, lumpy and slippery, I made the cut at almost every Protec Pool Party. After the refurbishing, it became much easier to skate. I also find it interesting that guys who didn't skate backyard pools, couldn't skate the Vans plaster version as well either.
The early Protec Pool Party contests were very exciting. It was more like a jam. Everyone was just riding hard. It is not like a session anymore. Timed runs make for waiting and the atmosphere becomes stale. The new refurbished Combi is good but its not like a pool now. It is more of a bowl. There are more young kids riding the Combi now that it has been refurbished. Its perfect so kids can get in and ride without working through all of the imperfections.
The contest format itself is problematic. I prefer the Jam format as it is exciting. They could do a ten man final, Jam format without the snaking... no order at all. A skater can drop in whenever. It would still be manageable. There are also the different generations to deal with. Skateboarding has changed dramatically. Pro's, Masters. Legends. Now that the prize purse has increased, it is bringing people out. Its become more of a consistency thing and not a pool thing. At the start, it was only the hardcore few. The sessions leading up to the event are always the best. At one session, you will see, Nicky Guerrero, Jeff Hedges, Pat Ngoho and Mike McGill. The next session will be Tony Hawk, Jeff Grosso and Peter Hewitt. It goes on and on and the sessions grow heated. The Protec Pool Party is the biggest event of the year. Vans built it and they keep giving back each year.

item.title: Lance Mountain / Combi Final
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The OG Combi pool, given to skateboarding by the Hoffman's was at the Pipeline Skatepark in Upland, California. It was special because it came and went before it was mastered by very many people. The Combi pool was skated hard for around three years and then skateboarding changed and moved on to ramps. There it was much easier for skateboarding to progress-- trick wise --due to smooth, larger transitions. Use of carving, lines, and how you linked and performed tricks, took a back stage to progression. After a few years drought there were a few contests before the closing days at the OG Combi. There were approximately fifteen to twenty Pro's left on earth at that time. We really were scared to come back to that monster of a pool after the ease of the growing ramp scene. It was a proving ground of sorts and an ode to the beauty of how pools were skated. Many years went by without concrete being poured to skate. The thought of it ever happening again was a dream.
A good deal of credit can be placed at the feet of Rick Carje, Chicken and Belmar for building private backyard pools. At the time, no other skatepark pools were really going on. In 1997, when Steve Van Doren decided to bring back the Combi pool, some thought, "Why built that thing again?" Once it was built, it was slow going at first. Sessions were mostly locals and older guys remembering the good old days. Vans started putting money into the contests, which started a bigger interest and draw. It really changed things. Over time, skaters started riding the Combi pool better. Most-- if not all --of the lines done in the OG Combi translated or adapted. The older skaters from the original Pipeline Combi showed the younger skaters how it should be ridden. Skateboarding needs change. In recent years, Vans decided to change the Combi pool again. We smoothed out the surface and reshaped it. We wanted to make it friendlier and modern. That we made it better has been argued by the skaters that can skate more challenging style pools. We felt that the changes would advance skateboarding as a whole and in a public setting.
Difficult advanced moves were being done by the new generation in the old lines. The contest had Masters, which were Pros who had skated contests in the OG pool and modern Pros as well a girls. An entire new generation came up with that pool and yet another generation are now riding it. Skateboarding rules and that it has no rules or limits is what sets it apart. Skateboarders around the world are still asking for a comparable pool and that tells me something. Each year the contest increased in participation. I like these contests as it brings out the highest level of skating and the best in each individual. You get to see people charging hard. The Combi contest is art. It is a venue to see people express themselves.

item.title: Eric Nash / Combi FINAL
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz

item.title: Christian Hosoi / Combi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I didn't really think too much of it when I heard that Vans was bringing back the Combi pool. I was riding streets and once in awhile we'd hit up Chicken's or Belmar's pool. After it was done and open, I stopped by there one day. Steve and Alex Olson were there riding together. I think Alex was about eleven or twelve years old. I thought that it was rad that Olson had his kid there with him. We all rode the black-bottom bowl and then I carved around the Combi pool a bit. I was riding small street wheels. It was a plaster surface and it was slippery and bumpy. I thought, "Who made this thing?"
However, the pool brought back all of these memories for me of the original Combi at Pipeline Skate Park in Upland. That pool had steep transitions, big, rough gnarly coping... it separated the men from the boys. When I went to Upland back then, I wanted to be one of the men. Thinking back on the Gold Cup contest at Upland, I realized just how gnarly it was. The vibe was super competitive but fun. The Combi pool brought that out. Flat walls, corners, hips. The Combi pool tested your abilities and the new Vans Combi did the same. A skater's heart and soul.
The Protec Pool Party contests brought the skate family together. The atmosphere. The stoke. That event brings back the same vibe as those early bowl riding contests from back then. Steve Van Doren opened other parks and though many closed, he kept the Combi for its historical significance. Once they refurbished it a few years ago, it is perfect. That pool has an even stronger legacy now. Those that were there at the original Pipeline Combi know it and those that were never there, can live those days vicariously through us. This is what makes the event so great. Vans heard the skaters and answered them.

item.title: Combi Intro
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The Combi pool. Cavernous. Gray and imposing. A gigantic concrete hole in the ground that is filled with speed, power and pain. You drop in and take what it gives you on any particular day. An ultimate proving ground. The original Combi pool was fashioned from the minds of several Badlands skateboarding legends. The Badlands riders loved to skate the huge plunge pools around Upland and Ontario. In their formative years, they learned to skateboard on the yawning flat walls, rounded corners and hips of the defunct swim club pools they frequently had at their disposal. These skaters would become pioneers in vertical and over-vertical skateboarding. Not only did they ride the huge public pools, but they also rode the Mt. Baldy spillway and pipe located nearby. One could say that vertical terrain is in their bloodline. Once the Pipeline Skate Park opened in Upland, they continued to push the known barriers of the times.
When Stan Hoffman decided to build a new pool, the skaters brought forth their best ideas. Steve Alba, Tom Inouye, Chris Strople, Tay Hunt, Lee Gahimer and others, sat down and gave their input. They loved the huge corners, long flat walls and hips of the pools they rode in their younger days. Why not combine them together? The Combi pool was born. In the ensuing years, the original Combi was both pain and pleasure for many early skate pioneers and upstarts. The pool was steep, rough and gnarly. It was no joke. Scars still remain. Not only did these skaters ride the Combi, but they mastered it as well. Contests of the time were a 'put up or shut up' situation. The Combi was the place where you had to lay it all on the line. The Pipeline Combi met its demise in 1988 as demolition bulldozers cut into it. The Badlands skaters rode their pool, even while the backhoe scraped its face. Concrete and coping rained in on their parade. End.
It took another ten years for the Combi to resurface and it did so in a most unlikely place. A mall in Orange County. Vans decided to build a skatepark and retail store at a local mall. The skaters in charge of designing it, decided on creating a replica of sorts... the Combi was brought back to life. Since then, its held a fascination for skateboarders all over the world. It is on everyone's 'Must Skate' list. Vans has kept to its roots. The Combi contest. The event is the pinnacle pool riding event of the year. Legends. Pros and Masters. It showcases only the very best. Past meets present. The Vans Skate Park has held the Combi pool contest annually for a decade now. It is a throwback to a different time. A younger era. Raw and untamed. Skateboarding and pool skating were so new. There was a freshness and innovation to it. Every day was one of discovery. Skaters pushed themselves and the terrain around them. The Combi pool brought out the best in everyone. It did so then and it does so now. - Ozzie Ausband

item.title: Sofia
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The light was bright. It contrasted starkly with the rest of the room. Day had long ago slipped to the other side of the world and still she toiled. The bracelet in her rough fingers dully gave back the white light. She spun the silver lazily in her hand. She brushed a stray hair from her eyes and peered around for her hammer. "Where is it?" She saw the cluttered work bench and mumbled under her breath. "This won't do!" Meticulous in nature, she had always kept her work place in order. Once she slipped into creative mode, all bets were off. She lost track of time, meals, phone calls and obligations. The world went away and all that mattered was what she was creating.

The silver bracelet was turning into something all on its own. The lines and detail were her decision. Yet the ultimate results were up to the silver itself. She liked making things organically. It was a cooperative effort between herself and the metal. When things worked, she was often delighted with the results. Limiting her self-criticism, she had been allowing her artistic temperament to develop. Raw. Undefined. A mixture of cold metal, coarse lines that fit well, yet carried weight. There was a dense, primitive feel to her jewelry. It was like someone punched a hole in time and a blacksmith turned their iron making skills to refined uses.

Sofia thought about the years she had put into what had become a passion. She started using fabrics and sewing as a young girl in San Diego. Over the years, she adopted the uses of leather goods, silver and brass in order to develop different looks and varied lines. There is a distinct genderless quality to Sofia's work. Utilitarian. It allows a man or a woman to express the self in a wordless way.

To view current collections and past works: http://sofialorena.be/

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The design philosophy is initiated in the minimization of machine tool use. Things are kept simplified. The expression of unisex appeal lies at the very foundation of all that is done. Uninhibited, Sofia's creations are from a dystopian future where past and present collide and conventional fashion is eroded.

item.title: Fairweather
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The fairweather friend. The user. We all have or know of at least one in life. The person who phones when they know you're having a party. Selfish sponge. The person that needs something... They want what you have and although they rarely feel anything for anyone, they certainly feel you out for a space between your ribs so they can stick the knife in. Tony Alva called them "parasitic people". Perfect. I had a recent weekend start with such a thing. It's okay. I know what they are now all about and have banished these people from my life. Their inferiority complex is fully justified. I try and keep only quality friends. These are the friends that know me well and love me anyway. My past is not so laudable. I've been a fecal pile in two shoes and I try everyday to do well. It is good to have a few real friends. I phoned up some of these people recently and set up a pool day. Low key. The weather was perfect. We met up at the appointed hour and Brandon Wong and I looked into a few early morning possibles. The house sat at a twisting bend in a gritty neighborhood. Huge trees sagged over the run down home. Dawn was only a few short hours behind us. Quiet. Sunday. Sleep. I pulled myself over a wall and looked the pool over. The pool had a lid on it. The plastic had long ago gave way and hung in tatters. I peered down underneath. The transitions were strange. Sloping walls led down to a radius at the pools bottom and I ran an experienced eye over the whole thing. I checked for water, power and squatters. Soon I was in the truck again. The entire recon had taken just under three minutes. I pulled the truck around the corner, punched in the satellite and scanned the rest of the neighborhood. We drove to meet up with the rest of our pals. We were skating with Kevin Burke, Shawn, Gopa and Scott Ward. It would be a fun day. Enroute, Brandon told me about a possible pool nearby in a really seedy area. We agreed to look into it. We consolidated cars and drove to the first pool. A neighbor came out in his yard and spoke briefly with us. He was young. Tattoos covered his arms and neck. He had hard dark eyes. I approached him and asked about the house. He was surprised when I told him we were planning on skating in the pool behind the house. I asked if that were okay with him. "Yeah, that was once our house. I used to swim in it." He said they lost the house and he looked away. I asked if we were cool to check it out. "This neighborhood is run by my uncle so you guys are good." I nodded and we slipped behind the house in short order. [caption id="attachment_20036" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me, Gopa, Shawn, Kevin and Brandon[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20039" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kevin[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20037" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Gopa[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20038" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shawn[/caption] The pool was a funnel. A pit. The walls were flat, sloping and steep. It was a pool nonetheless and we were happy to be in a struggle with her... Decaying. Old and broken. She wouldn't always win. We abandoned her after a short time. Visiting an old favorite, we then checked a few more, knocked on doors and every time I looked around, I saw happy friends. The fairweather friends had been abandoned and discarded until only the good ones remained. Thank you to Scott Ward for the images and thank you to my good friends. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Tony Alva View Book Project
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Introduction Tony Alva is without a doubt, the most influential figure in skateboarding. He was the first skater to dominate pools, parks and pipes. He was brash. He had style. When you saw him skate, you wanted to do what he did. Tony was spawned out of the gritty Venice streets where surfing was the most important thing to do. If you didn't surf, you didn't matter. His roots are steeped in ocean water. Style and presence, on and off of a surfboard were of paramount importance. Every morning, Tony would find himself at the Pacific Ocean Park pier. He'd eye up the sets as they crawled darkly toward him. He'd wax his board and slip into the deep green sea. To the east, dawn would be spilling over the nearby buildings of east Los Angeles. He didn't care. Dawn was only good for one thing. Greeting the ocean. Majestic. Tony loved how the ocean seemed like a giant that licked the cold sand and would pummel him to within an inch of his life. Gasping and spitting water, the sea would take its wet arms off his shoulders and buoy him up for a breath. Reprieve. He thanked the ocean for it. Learning curve. As the years turned him from a tanned teenager, sun-kissed and wiry, he had picked up a skateboard. Natural aptitude. He oozed surf style, speed and complete unconcern for his own bodily harm. Progression. Tony Alva took all that he learned from the sea and applied it to the banked, black top school yards of his teenage years. Drought and desiccation reared its ugly face. Los Angeles baked under an unforgiving sun. The earth thirsted. Skating back from the beach one day, Tony and his friends cut through an alleyway. Peering through a sun-seared fence, he saw a pool. Empty. Forlorn. It spoke a silent language only he could understand. He and his friends slipped through the slats... the kidney pool was round. The school yards had proven to be fun. Surfing on land. Cut backs, carving and closing in on catastrophe. It was just the thing that Tony found irresistible. He sat his board down in the shallow end. The steep round walls called to him. They seemed almost insurmountable. Tony pushed in. Cutting a sharp arc across the surface, Tony carved the deep end. The light passed beneath him. Tiles clicked away beneath his wheels.  He rolled up into the shallow end and his face could not hide his excitement. This was amazing. His friends quickly began skating the pool and continued pushing themselves and each other. Pool skating... it was like a strange new form of heroin. Blood thrumming, pulse-quickened fun. Nothing could compare and so it began. Tony Alva took the wheel of progress and drove us all straight into a perfect future.

item.title: who you are
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
It matters who you are. I'm not referring to nepotism. I'm certainly not writing about drinking the cool-guy Kool Aid and all the nonsense that goes with that. I'm thinking that it matters the sort of person you are on the inside. I certainly am not the man my father is. Stoic. Sober. Self-sacrificing. I've become a bit of those things but it took awhile. Fifteen years ago, I took a skateboard tour on the road and completely let everyone down. My drug and alcohol use sent me to the emergency room. An agonizing flight back to California was accompanied by shame, guilt and self-loathing. There was money missing... I asked myself, "How did you spend five thousand dollars in less than two hours?" Blackout. The answer is somewhere out there. Theft? Drunk decisions? Unknown. The point is this: It matters who you are. Especially in the greater scheme of things. Once I became sober, I had to go back and try to make amends. I made a shameful, grave mistake. It may not matter to others, but it does to me. That story is still bandied about with plenty of laughter directed my way. It's cool. I certainly deserve it. Like I said, I'm not the man my father is. This entire thread of thinking was brought on by a pool that Kent Senatore found last summer. Kent is one of the original pool destroyers from the Los Angeles area back when it all started. He was there as it was invented because he was one of the pioneers. He'd constantly look for pools. He found them everywhere. Kent was one of the first skaters to go over love seats and grind over death boxes. There are no versions of the truth. The truth is simply the truth. He was there. Kent was always given carte blanche by the Dog Town skaters. Tony Alva said it himself, "Kent was one of the only outsiders allowed at the Dogbowl because he surfed. That got him a pass with us..." Kent Senatore has lived on the North Shore in Hawaii for many years. Whenever he comes to Los Angeles, he quickly finds himself looping through the hillsides and the San Fernando Valley looking for pools. Old habits die hard. The blood quickens as blue tiles are spotted through a privacy fence. He knows. He's been doing this longer than most.

Last summer, Kent was driving the twisted streets of the Hollywood Hills and parked his car. He checked out a pool he had seen on satellite. It wasn't worth the effort. Walking back down the hill towards his car, he looked over the side of the road to peer down into the yards below. Vantage point. Always take the high ground. He saw a flash of blue. Continuing on, he soon found himself in front of a well-maintained house set against the hill. The gate was open. He couldn't believe it. He could see an empty shallow end! He called out. No answer. Gardeners were working. He stepped in. Empty kidney pool. "Sometimes, you just get lucky."

No one was around, so Kent took a photograph and told me about the pool later that evening. I went and spoke with the owners. She told me that she was an attorney. My heart dropped. Litigation. Injury. Blah, blah...  Surprisingly, she made coffee and told me that John F. Kennedy Jr. was once an intern at her law firm. She would have parties and John and the rest of the revelers, would jump off the house roof into the pool. It sounded pretty fantastic. After a bit, she agreed to let us skate the pool. There were black ceramic fish on the right side wall of the pool that were in the line. They were definitely a problem. She asked, "Can you take them off?" I called Lance Mountain and we all decided to work on the pool the next morning.

[caption id="attachment_20059" align="aligncenter" width="468"] President Kennedy and John John[/caption]

I thought about John F. Kennedy Jr. that evening. I was driving cross country in 1999 when I heard that he had flown his plane into the Atlantic Ocean. Instant loss. Not only did he lose his life, but his wife and sister-in-law's as well. Here was a man that embodied the concepts that I'd written about at the start of this tale. Who you are. His father was President of our country. Nepotism could certainly apply. I would think that it must have been very difficult to live in such a shadow as his father cast. Yet, John John -- as the press called him -- was his own man. He became an attorney, started and ran George Magazine and the man that he became was unique and inspiring. A man with class and intelligence. A man with his own opinions... he wasn't simply a parrot repeating his father's words. I read interviews with him. He was thoughtful and kept an eye on the common man.

[caption id="attachment_20060" align="aligncenter" width="584"] John John at George Magazine[/caption]

The pool was aptly named 'John John' and Kent, Lance and I met up for some pool improvements. The homeowner made us coffee and her children came out to talk with us. They were college students and knew all about skateboarding. They weren't surprised that she was letting us ride. "Mom is the coolest!" We couldn't argue with that. We chiseled the black porcelain fish off the pool and smoothly patched over the spots. In no time, we were cruising about the old Blue Haven kidney. The owner and the kids were stoked as Lance pulled frontside airs and Kent and I pulled grinds. The shallow was small and difficult but we wanted to do John John some justice. It matters who you are. We skated the pool periodically over the fall and winter. Kent shared the love, I did what I do and Lance lent his expertise. We gave the family shoes and gifts. Gratitude.

[caption id="attachment_20061" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kent and Lance handle business[/caption]

I took friends. Tony Alva, Andy Neal, John Zask, Bulldog, Lorrie Palmos, MRZ, Brandon Wong, Cam Dowse, Robbie, Chuck Hults, Arto Saari and Kevin Burke. We've all sat on the shallow stairs and marveled at the scene and the session. Although the pool was pinched in the shallow, everyone quickly got into it. Happiness. Stoke.

[caption id="attachment_20062" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20066" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chuck Hults[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20064" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20068" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cam Dowse[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_20067" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kevin Burke[/caption] Human beings are a unique blend of good and sometimes bad. Conflict exists inside of us. We find things that help us escape. They often bring us to our knees. Becoming an individual, remaining unique and confronting our weaknesses and errors is of paramount importance. I think that it matters who we are. [caption id="attachment_20063" align="aligncenter" width="584"] me[/caption] Thank you to the owners and huge thanks to Kent Senatore for the pool. Thank you to Lorrie Palmos, MRZ and the Associated Press for images. Thank you to the readers of Blue Tile Obsession. I do what I do... for you. - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on Punx In Solidarity Blog and commented: Who You Are From Blue Tile Obsession!
I like that you pulled out some original board set ups to get that ole spirit flowin'.
Such a rad post Miss you, Andy Sent from my iPhone >
Nice story, rad skating too!
A very good read. Thank you!

item.title: Felix
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: She murmured to him. He smiled over the edge of the book he was reading. Pulling a strand of dark hair away from her eyes, she smiled back. IT had been many years since they met. It seemed as though they had been together forever. All the ones before him were nothing. All of the ones in the past mattered little. They were twin souls. Mirrors. Once they met, the world seemed warmer, grass greener, tastes were sweeter...  life moved in a strange dream. They were sitting on their porch. Her cat Felix sat beside her. She loved her cat. It had wandered onto their porch in Beverly Hills many years ago. He frowned at her back then. "You feed it, you'll never get rid of it." She squatted there on the porch, scratching it behind the ears. The cat purred... He went to the car and drove off. He had said that he'd be back shortly. She sat in the sun on their porch. They had lived in the rambling estate home for over twenty years. It was perfect. He wrote. She ran her business. Together, they traveled and loved like never before. She heard the birds nearby. The cat purred. He pulled up in the car again. Approaching, he set a grocery bag on the porch at her feet. She looked at him questioningly. Reaching inside, she removed two cans of cat food. She smiled. "My Ozzie." She reached back in the bag...  pulling her hand out, she held a box of allergy tablets. He grinned and kissed her on the head. "Purrrrfect." he mumbled.

item.title: Garret Shigenaka / Guest Post
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_20092" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Max Jenson[/caption]
Thank you skateboarding. I have much to be thankful for, because of this wooden toy. My skateboard has brought me great joy, as well as pain. It has also taken me to places I never imagined I would go. I started bringing my camera to the places I skated, so I could take photos of other skaters. I took photos of some pros, but mostly just guys or girls who were skating at the time. I got to meet skaters who were local, and skaters who lived thousands of miles away. I've met great people, who are doing amazing things for those in need because of this wooden toy, and I've been able to skate with all my childhood heroes. Thank you skateboarding. I am extremely honored, humbled and grateful to Ozzie for letting me share. Of course, thanks be to God, my wife, for putting up with me, and all of the people who have stoked the fire in me, and helped me continue to do what I love. As the saying goes, "Skateboarding doesn't owe me, I owe skateboarding," so thank you skateboarding. Here are five friends who happen to be great skateboarders.
[caption id="attachment_20093" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lincoln Ueda[/caption]
Lincoln Ueda. 
Lincoln has been my favorite vert skater to watch ever since I met him in 2004 at the old Vans skatepark vert ramp. He is one of the nicest, most humble dudes you'll meet. For this shot, I drove down to Mancha's ramp in Vista. We didn't know what we were going to shoot, so I just shot a few of him warming up. He told me he didn't have a shot of a lien frigid, so we decided to shoot that. He got this one about fifth try.
[caption id="attachment_20094" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mimi Knoop[/caption]
Mimi Knoop
After shooting a star-studded session at Hawk's warehouse with Mimi, we decided to shoot more over at Alex Road skatepark in Oceanside. We were blessed with an awesome sky that night. Mimi wanted to get a backside ollie over the hip. I shot a few with a 50mm lens, but she wanted to try one from below. We set up and it became the favorite of the night.
[caption id="attachment_20095" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian Hosoi[/caption]
Christian Hosoi
This was one of those days that was like a dream. Saturday afternoon at Bellmar's with Christian Hosoi, Lonny Hiramoto and Jay "Alabamy" Haizlip. This was one of those days where I sat back and thought, "I'm skating Bellmar's with Christian Hosoi." If you had told me way back when, I would never have believed. It wasn't a hype session. No one was pushing themselves. We just rolled. I shot for about forty five minutes and this was one that stood out to me. One that will go down in my archives as one of my best days in skateboarding. Getting to roll with three other brothers in Christ made it all that much more special.
[caption id="attachment_20097" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Neal Hendrix[/caption]
Neal Hendrix
Back when the Vans skatepark in Orange had the vert ramp, I used to see Neal Hendrix there regularly. That's where I got to know him and was able to document some great sessions on that ramp. These days it's a rarity to see him at the Combi. One weekday afternoon, I was surprised to see Neal rolling around with Lincoln. I skated with them for a bit and then took out my gear. For the most part, I don't ask people to do tricks I want to shoot, I will ask them what they want to shoot. Neal suggested this slob fast plant. I really dig the way this one came out. Rad trick by a rad dude.
[caption id="attachment_20098" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Allysha Bergado[/caption]
Allysha Bergado
This year will mark the tenth year since my first photo of Allysha. In 2005, I shot her at her first contest in Upland, and this year, Hoopla released her pro model. It's been awesome to see how far she's come and where skateboarding has taken her. This session at the Combi was toward the end of the night during some Combi Pool Classic practice with Lizzie Armanto and Julz Lynn. In and of itself, I thought it was a cool photo, but the way that the light caught her hair was a happy surprise and got me that much more stoked on it.
Thank you to Naka for taking the time to share his thoughts and amazing photographs with us. For more of his work: Naka Photo   Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That photo of Lincoln is sick! That dude can blast!

Great guest post Ozzie! Great photos and insight Garret!
Brian Shelford Art Director Nordec Inc.

item.title: Alva Book / Business
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
A- Editor
Ozzie Ausband - Primary collector of images/Photographer contact/Chronicler of Alva anecdotes/Editor. I am receiving 150.00 per eight hour day to perform above functions. I would like to discuss a fee per unit on publication. As I trust Tony and Michael implicitly, I feel this is something we can agree on between ourselves.
1- 1/29/2015 - 150.00
2- 2/16/2015 - 150.00
3- 3/14/2015 - 300.00
B- Photographer Publication Standards. In researching industry standards for photograph use and payment, I have come to the conclusion that the lowest we can offer is around two hundred dollars per image. Since this book is the first of its kind for Tony and he has a massive fan base, I'm sure these photographers would rather be included than excluded. I think we should go in and offer this fee per image. Having these photographers in the book will make the project take on an even broader scope. Not only will we be reaching the Tony Alva fan base, but with each photographer including a Bio and a portrait, we'll gather their individual fan bases as well. This will reach a broader range and scope of reader.
1- Lance Mountain : Three images.
2- Warren Bolster : Three images.
3- Boyd Harnell : Three images.
4- Grant Brittain : Five images.
5- Craig Fineman : Two images.
6- Bryce Kanights: Five images.
7- Lucia Griggi: Three images.
8- MRZ: Five images.
9- Raul Vega: Two images.
10- Steve Wilkings: Two images.
11- Arto Saari: Three images.
12- Stan Sharp: Six images.
13- William Sharp: Two images?
14- Jim Goodrich: One image.
15- Art Brewer: Two images.
We are at a total of forty seven images thus far. Tony has to make a decision on Rhino and Wynn Miller. We are pending selections from Mofo and Kevin Thatcher, though I am no longer betting on these images appearing in time for any sort of inclusion. Both photographers have scattered archives and appear in no hurry to locate requested images. Glen E. Friedman and Craig Stecyk are conspicuously absent. Craig told me directly too use anything I want or can find. I could locate little. Tony looked at Glen's images and stated that all of his work has been seen before and he is uninterested in using Glen's previously published photographs.
Forty seven images at approximately two hundred dollars per image equals ninety four hundred dollars thus far.

item.title: burn
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
nemesis
She watched her husband sleep. He was old now,  yet she still saw him as the young man she first met back in the summer of 1946. The years had been hard on them both. He had silver at  his temples and 'distinguished' was a term often applied to him. He had spent his years in the steel mills and his hands were cracked, scarred and calloused. She smiled thinly to herself and brushed back a tangle of hair from her forehead. She once teased him saying, "Your hands are the softest part of you." He'd smirk at her and try harder to be gentle. Loving. It was their way. They had put their children through school and pinched pennies the entire time they were together. He had been promoted to foreman at the plant when the kids were smaller and their lifestyle gradually improved. They bought a house out in San Bernardino. It was on a quiet side street with a view of the nearby Angeles National Forest. The hills that backed up against their neighborhood were mostly grasses and small scrub brush, but they didn't mind. They had a swimming pool and the hot summers were tolerable for them. Neighborhood children gathered almost daily to splash and swim in the refreshing water. She shifted in her seat as her husband stirred then softly begin snoring again. Peering through the gloom, she saw soft fingers of sunlight spill through the blinds and light up the brass- framed family photographs on her side table. Her sons. Her life.  'Mother' is the name for 'God' on the lips of all children. Their house was quiet now. The din and racket of radios, laughter and telephones had long ago diminished. Dust motes spun lazily in the afternoon sun and she felt sleepy. She reached over and thumbed the TV remote. There had been fire scares lately. The headline news spoke of horror. Fires were now spreading, burning the Angeles National Forest and she felt her pulse quicken. The newscaster reported that the fires were moving fast. Fire had always been a constant threat for them. It was their nemesis. She smelt the smoke earlier today as she had driven home from church. She had seen the TV coverage days before. "It will be contained." She hoped. Two days later, she watched as her husband watered the roof down with a green garden hose. The fires were descending on the area. Winds billowed fire and embers skyward. Soot rained down and she saw the sun-- pale and yellow-- through the burning smoke. She saw ashes--like snow--on the hood of her car and it was like watching some strange film on the 'Holocaust'. Everything was gray, dying and wrong. This was really the end of all the good in her world. She called out to her husband. He turned to her and she saw fear. Firemen approached from the big red trucks. They were being evacuated. "Where?!" She screamed out, wringing her hands in frustration. Her husband reached for her with his big calloused hands. He held her briefly and quickly they climbed into their car. He drove her away as the revolving lights of the fire engines lit up the demise of her life and dreams. She never returned and there was no reason. The fires had consumed all that she was.
consumed
Epilogue Skateboarders discovered this property afterward. Blackened appliances, bicycles and smoldered furniture still sat amid the remains of the buckled house. Some members of the family came one day. The sons. The skateboarders had drained the pool and stacked the families scattered belongings to one side, covering them with a piece of rubber tarp. The sons said that their mother was heart- broken. She would never come back. It was done for her. She and their father had started anew elsewhere. The skaters mumbled their apologies,  gathered their things and left.  They would return and ride. They would try to find some sanity in overwhelming chaos.  Skate- Ozzie
Josh Borden
[caption id="attachment_14223" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Alex Perelson[/caption]
Chuck Hults
Duane Peters
Thank you to MRZ and Brian Fick for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Bobby's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Kent Senatore and Tony Alva looked across the pool at each other. Tony was telling Kent about seeing a bird earlier that morning when he was hiking down by the beach. He was walking down to check the waves and stopped as a bird flitted from limb to limb. It pipped and chirped at his intrusion. So he thought. Jay Adams had recently passed away and Tony had been thinking about Jay, their lives, and the times they spent together. The sun splashed through the palm trees. Tony watched the small colorful bird as it preened its feathers and spoke to him. "It is just like Jay..." he thought. Waves licked the sand and Tony heard people nearby. The bird took one more look at Tony and rose up out of sight. He felt a weight lift off of him.  "Jay..." he murmured. When Kent heard Tony's story, he smiled. The three of them had spent a great deal of time together in their youth. They surfed, skated and partied. Jay was truly missed. [caption id="attachment_20131" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20132" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kent Senatore[/caption] Here they were at Angelo's Clover pool. It was thirty five years since they first skated pools together. They were both older. Jay was gone and yet the fire still remained. Good pools. Good friends. Stoke. Tony flowed through the pool like water. Kent kept his style clean and pure as only he can. Brothers. The Malibu afternoon waned. The sun sank and they went their separate ways. Days later, Kent crept through the San Fernando Valley in a rental car. The sun glimmered off the windshield and he squinted into the glare. Graffiti splattered alley wall. Pool ladder. Kent stopped the car. He pulled himself up on a cinder block and looked. Empty pool. This was his second of the day. He was accustomed to it. Decades of pool hunting had given him a pedigree few could argue with. He was doing this long before he knew that what he was doing was special. Kent and Tony and all their friends had thrown a pebble in a pond. The ripples have never diminished... [caption id="attachment_20134" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cat Lady[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20135" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Fat Lip[/caption] Kent took a few photographs and continued on. He searched the grid. The afternoon wore on him. Heat. Traffic. It never ended in the valley. He stopped for a drink and then pulled to the side of a neighborhood street. He checked his surroundings. Satellite showed several possible pools in this area. Family homes. 1950's vintage. Larger yards and properties. "It has potential..." Kent drove through the neighborhood. Bent square. Steep Anthony kidney. Box of rocks. Three pools. Little use. He kept to the task at hand. Kent knew--as did anyone who searches for pools--that just when you want to quit and go home, you'll find a gem. [caption id="attachment_20136" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bent Square[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20137" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Box of Rocks[/caption] Kent had seen a really good pool on his last trip to Los Angeles over a year ago. Weaving through side streets, he made his way back to that neighborhood. He saw the familiar pale blue green tiles through a decorative cinder block wall just as he turned a corner. "Whoa! Hold on here..." He almost hit the curb with his tire as he stopped quickly. Bright white plaster met his eyes as he walked up to the wall. "Damn. It's empty?" He looked over. A capsuled deep end and arrowhead shaped shallow greeted his eyes. He took it in at a glance. The side walls pillowed out. Transitions looked stellar. He had made contact, but the owners son wasn't sure his mom would allow it. He was certain the answer would be no. Kent made a note of the address. Contentment filled him. A few days later, he flew back to Hawaii . [caption id="attachment_20140" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kent and Bobby[/caption] Kent filed it away with all the other pools he had found. It was a big file. Months passed and he was soon back in California. He was with me and we were skating pools. He took me by the house. We knocked and Bobby, the owners son, came out. The pool looked amazing once we were inside. Bobby still denied us and we took his number. That started another ripple in the pond. I'm relentless. Over the next few months, I called from time to time. I actually began to think it was not going to happen. December came. Winter colored our every word. Clouds and rain. I phoned Bobby. Lance and Rune wanted to film something. We reached an agreement. On the appointed day, it rained. We tried to no avail. The sky wept... [caption id="attachment_20142" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance, Robby, Rune[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20143" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Not working...[/caption] The next day, we returned. It was still wet. We used leaf blowers and propane heaters to speed the process. Once dry, we skated hard. We took the long awaited runs we had been dreaming of. I phoned Kent Senatore in Hawaii. I could hear an odd mixture of stoke for us and sadness for himself. He had found a gem and couldn't be here for the first session. We tried to do him justice. We wanted to make him proud. He was the definition of altruistic. [caption id="attachment_20146" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20148" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arto Saari[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20154" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rune Glifberg[/caption] Thank you to Kent Senatore. You rule it brother. Thank you to Bobby for allowing us to roll. Thank you to Arto Saari for the images. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I love this story and double love

item.title: Tony Alva View / Introduction / Promo
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Tony Alva is without a doubt, the most influential figure in skateboarding. He was the first and most stylish originator of pools, parks and pipes. Tony was spawned out of the gritty Venice streets where surfing was the most important thing to do. If you didn't surf, you didn't matter. His roots are steeped in the ocean. Style and presence on and off of a skateboard were of paramount importance. Every morning, Tony would find himself at the Pacific Ocean Park pier. He'd eye up the sets as the crawled darkly toward him. He'd wax his board and slip into the deep green sea. To the east, dawn would be spilling over the nearby buildings of east Los Angeles. He didn't care. Dawn was only good for one thing. Greeting the ocean. Majestic. Tony loved how the ocean seemed like a giant that licked the cold sand and would pummel him to within an inch of his life. Gasping and spitting water, the sea would take its wet arms off his shoulders and buoy him up for a breath. Reprieve. He thanked the ocean for it. Learning curve. As the years turned him from a tanned teenager, sun-kissed and wiry, he had picked up a skateboard. Natural aptitude. He oozed surf style, speed and complete unconcern for his own bodily harm. Progression. Tony Alva took all that he learned from the sea and applied it to the banked black top school yards of his teenage years. Drought and desiccation reared its ugly face. Los Angeles baked under an unforgiving sun. The earth thirsted.
Skating back from the beach one day, Tony cut through an alleyway. Peering through sun-seared fences, he saw a pool. Empty. Forlorn. It spoke a silent language only he could understand. He and his friends slipped through the slats... the kidney pool was round. The school yards had proven to be fun. Surfing on land. Cut backs, carving and closing in on catastrophe. It was just the thing that Tony found irresistible. He sat his board down in the shallow end and pushed in. Cutting a sharp arc across the surface, Tony carved the deep end and rolled up into the shallow end. His face could not hide his excitement. THIS was amazing... They continued pushing themselves. Pool skating... it was like a strange new form of heroin. Blood thrumming, pulse quickened fun. Nothing could compare and so it began. Tony Alva took the wheel of progress and drove us all straight into a perfect future. Ozzie Ausband / Los Angeles

item.title: Alva View / Lucia Griggi
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_20166" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lucia Griggi[/caption] My love of photography was inspired by my passion for travel and finding waves around the world. I learned to surf in England and the search for perfect waves took me to corners of the earth I would have never found if I wasn't surf crazed. I lived to have two feet in the sand and my toes in the water, and I was always on a beach or swimming in the ocean somewhere. I spent many seasons on the North Shore of Oahu documenting surfing by land and sea - either shooting from the beach with a big telephoto lens, or swimming out at Pipeline to tell the stories of athletes like Kelly Slater, Lisa Anderson and all the other great North Shore specialists. Book assignments took me to California, where I took portraits of skate legends Tony Alva, Jay Adams, Tony Hawk and dozens of others. These book projects took me as far north as Seattle and as far south as the tip of Baja, and I am now based part of the year in California - surrounded by the surfing and skateboarding lifestyle. Being on the road shooting surfing led me to a fork, where I began doing work for the mainstream media. Magazines such as National Geographic and companies like Jeep look to me for images and moments which have the look and feel of the adventure lifestyle. I work on commercial advertising assignments with a team of people all dedicated to providing clients with the highest quality images. For the past decade I have been traveling from England to California to Hawaii and around the world to document the adventure lifestyle - and inspire others to find their own path. - Lucia Griggi

He rose to fame through his work at Skateboard World Magazine from 1977-1979. Rest In Peace. item.title: Alva View / Grant Brittain / Promo
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20180" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Grant Brittain[/caption] Grant Brittain picked up a camera at the ripe old age of 25 and started shooting his friends skateboarding at the Del Mar Skate Ranch. The "Ranch" was a skatepark in a small beach town north of San Diego, California that he managed in the early 1980s, and it was there that he honed his photographic skills. After blowing massive amounts of film, he took every photo class Palomar Junior College had to offer. And with that, he felt he finally learned how to manipulate his 35mm camera. While at college, an influential instructor introduced Brittain to the vast world of photography, and set him on his creative path. In 1983, Grant was asked to contribute skate photos to the premiere issue of TransWorld SKATEboarding magazine and became its founding Photo Editor and Senior Photographer. Over the past twenty years, Brittain has helped TransWorld grow into the most popular skate mag in the world, and has captured the best skateboarders of the last two decades in photos that have become classics. He has also taught some of the best skate photographers, past and present, and helped them develop their own work. He hopes that they have gotten as much inspiration from him as he gets from them. Over the years Brittain's personal work-abstracts, portraits, landscapes and travel images-seems to draw from the opposite energy of his action images. His "off hours" are consumed by a search for calmer and more serene subjects. Still lakes at night and solitary desert forms are among the subjects of his diverse personal work. Some of his portraits of well-known athletes even manage to divulge a more reflective side of their personalities. Few photographers have pursued so wide a range of subjects and styles. But few individuals find themselves so central to such an active community, where one's perspective is just a notch askew of the rest, and where movement and progression is the norm. Grant Brittain's body of work reflects his deep involvement in an emerging youth culture, as well as his escape from it. Grant and a group of the skateboarding elite talent have left TWS and started The Skateboard Mag, check it at: theskateboardmag.com and at shops and newsstands — Miki Vuckovich [caption id="attachment_20182" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony on the set of Thrashin' in 1986[/caption]     [caption id="attachment_20183" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony in Tempe, Arizona[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20184" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony on the set of Lords of Dogtown film. Pasadena 2004[/caption]
