item.title: Back In The Day / Mondo's Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20188" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Smith at Mondo's Pool[/caption] In 2012, William Sharp and I began working on a book project together. It was difficult from the beginning. Thousands of slides were assembled, all out of order, randomly stored in sleeves... it took awhile just to separate and categorize everything. We both have full time work, so it was a labor of love. Passion. I decided to interview everyone I could and include anecdotes with the images. We did three major photograph selections. Only the best of the best. Then, we spread the love around. For example, I found only one photograph of Lee Gahimer and one photograph of Charlie Ransom... they went in. We both felt that it was important to give as many skaters as we could, the recognition and respect they deserve. We did exactly that. [caption id="attachment_20190" align="aligncenter" width="584"] William Sharp[/caption] About a year into the process, I was doing the section on Mondo's pool. I never could pinpoint where Mondo's pool actually was. Some of the best images from Skateboard World magazine were shot there. The iconic Jay Smith lapover photograph comes immediately to mind. It was Scotch taped to my bedroom door in Pennsylvania.   The Sharp archive was filled with great photographs from Mondo's. Eventually, I found the pool. I drove out in the summer of 2013. The house was in pretty good shape. A high wall surrounded the property. I had to go in via the front door. I knocked on the security gate. A woman's voice answered, "Yes?" My reply... "I know that this is going to sound crazy..." With laptop in hand, I began telling her about the pool's history. Silence. A metal clank. The gate opened. The owner introduced herself and looked at the photographs. Fascination. "Whoa...  it actually is this house." She was intrigued by the whole thing. I asked if there was any way I could see the pool. "It doesn't look like that anymore." She replied, pointing at my computer screen. My heart sank. I followed her into the yard. [caption id="attachment_20191" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Mondo's now[/caption] A slate top deck had replaced the famous Blue Haven bullnose coping and there was a huge jacuzzi in the shallow end cup. It didn't matter. I walked around in awe anyway. I was standing at Mondo's. I ran my hands along the top of the pool just below the tiles of the hip. Jay Smith's spot. The owner just looked at me in amusement. The transitions could still be seen under the water. Amazing. Mellow. It was a very wide bowl. No wonder so much was done here. I thanked them and went on my way. I'm grateful to have been there. The William Sharp book  'Back In The Day' is completed. We are getting ready to shop it around and put it out. Mondo's is just one of many pools that are included. I'll keep you updated as to its release. Thank you to William Sharp for the Jay Smith image. Skate- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Coolness!!!
That is a gorgeous looking bowl section. Congrats on completing your book. Looking forward to pouring through each image and detail.
Jay Smith's spot!
Beautiful ! looks great Bill is a true Artist , Legend Photographer to the sport and super nice guy ! Looking forward to a Wonderful Project !
I need this book. Everyone needs this book!

item.title: Jerry Valdez Introduction
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: “Skateboarding is the best education into oneself. It’s not about having others make it for you; it’s about you making it happen”. Jerry Valdez Who would have thought that the late 1960’s and early 1970’s would have set the stage for what we call skateboarding today.  America’s kids were looking for a physical outlet outside the existing sports.  Born out of the concrete and asphalt jungles of the inner city, curing boredom and dissatisfaction, the skateboard delivered a solid solution to this need. Drainage ditches, catch basins and empty swimming pools, became the playgrounds for a sport not yet accepted. Those few that had imagination, ambition and the mental “go for it” attitude, looked for more than the typical sidewalk ride and skateboarding became a way of life for them. Challenge, a high level of confidence and visual art form, these were some of the virtues that created the icons of the 1970’s and set the standard moves that remain the staple of today’s skating. For without the highest focus and commitment, pain and injury will follow. Only a handful of photographers were around to capture the history-making trendsetters who blazed a new trail for skateboarding.  This book is a tribute to the pioneering skaters and Bill Sharp, whose photographic skills captured the state of the art at its beginning stages. Bill Sharp’s photography is a window into that time. For without his lens, most would not have pushed it to the max. I am proud to call myself a skater and thus be associated with the group of individuals that make up the brotherhood of skateboarders now and in this book. Enjoy the blood sweat and mega-pain it took to produce these images.

item.title: what we got
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: What you give, is what you get. I drive the grid. My mind a cauldron. I search. Asphalt ribbons. The endless road. I fantasize. I'm hoping that the next Dog Bowl, Gonzales pool, Buddha pool or Date Bowl is right around the next bend. The morning consisted of endless traffic, filth, poverty, heat, and frustration on virtually every face I saw. People looked ready for a return to the Dark Ages. I could see it in my mind's eye.  If someone say's some disrespectful crap, they get a knife across the throat. No words bandied about. No warnings. Knife point. Immediate. Draining on the ground. Bloody froth. Questions... "What? How?  I would look down at them in their urine-drenched pants and murmur... "If you knew then, what you know now. You probably would've done otherwise..." It seems to me that the problem these days is that there is no accountability. People can run their mouth without fear of reprisal. Our society has become cowardly. A revolution of the meek. I turn my thoughts off. Kill switch. I don't want to think like that any longer. I downshifted the truck. I had been all over the San Fernando Valley since six thirty in the morning. The dirty sun hung overhead now. Trash and old tires littered the underpasses. In an alley, there was a square pool. It looked like it had round carveable corners and I wanted a closer look. As I slowly crawled along, I spotted green water through a broken fence on my right side. I stopped. Trash bins overflowed. Reeking. A dog barked at my intrusion. I peered between the wooden fence slats. Firecracker coping. Kidney pool. Disuse. I swung around the block. Knock knock. The owner basically said that he wasn't interested but I gave him my phone number anyway. "Just in case you need it drained sometime." He smiled and closed the door. I went on my way. Life moves. Ebb and flow. The pool quickly blended with a thousand others I've seen... A week later the phone rang. It was the homeowner. It took a minute to pinpoint what pool he was referring to. He asked if I could drain his. "You can skate but I'm going to clean and repair it. After that, it will be full as my daughter wants to swim." I told him that I would be there the following Sunday morning. Arto, Shawn, MRZ and Lance joined me for a few turns. It was pretty stellar. The wall dropped pretty sharply after the loveseat on the right side and the shallow end was steeper than we wished, but the pool was fun to ride. The loveseats were clicked off in short order, Arto banged out a side wall slasher and I threw myself across the love seat and deathbox combination. Failure. The firecracker coping really dug into my trucks and my testicular girth was insufficient for said maneuver. When you've been riding forty plus years, you learn to be happy that you're still rolling. I didn't take it too hard. Life. [caption id="attachment_20214" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shawn Ahringhoff[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20215" align="aligncenter" width="572"] me[/caption] I tried setting up another session but the homeowner was pretty elusive. I understood. Having a group of strangers in your backyard skateboarding in the pool -- as normal as it is for us -- is probably a bit disconcerting for regular folks. I didn't push the issue. Some of the San Fernando Valley pool skaters heard about it and informed me that the pool I just drained was one they called "White Horse". They had ridden it about ten years previously. This sort of thing happens sometimes. You find something new that actually isn't. I would try to set them up with a session... Proper respect. [youtube https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kFPxHqLJ52s&w=420&h=315] This past Sunday, the owner phoned me. I figured that the pool had been filled. He told me that I could come and patch it for him. As I drained it the previous weekend, I saw some cancer spots and told him I could fix them. He now asked for these repairs. I drove up the next morning and spoke with him. It was early and it was hot. San Fernando Valley. I took the supplies into the backyard and quietly repaired the cancer holes. He told me that we could ride it one last time that day. I was stoked. I phoned the Valley skaters that had originally rode the "White Horse" but they had to work and couldn't get away. Pat Rat, Mitchell and Jake were in from Hawaii and they stopped over for a few turns. In the end, fun was found. It rained from the sky. What you give, is what you get. I believe it. If you put out harsh words, lies and treachery, you're bound to receive some bad Juju. Dark Ages. But, what if you put out some good... [caption id="attachment_20219" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Robbie[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20220" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Hawaii Jake[/caption] Thank you to the homeowner. Thank you to the San Fernando Valley crew. Thank you to MRZ and Arto for the photographs. What you give, is what you get. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Heimana Reynolds
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20247" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Heimana Reynolds[/caption] As a kid growing up in Pennsylvania during the 1970's, I saw the skateboard magazine photographs of all the original pool skaters. Most of them came from a surfing background. They had style. It oozed from their pores. I can see the photographs even now. Shogo Kubo, Roy Jamison, Kent Senatore, Jayboy, TA... all of them had that thing that separated them from most others. Great style. Over the years, there have been a few super stylish skateboarders. In my opinion, a skater can do every trick in the world, but if he looks bad doing it... well, there we are. There are skaters that look good doing even the simplest things... effortless. Quiet upper body. Flow. Some skaters just have that thing. I was watching the Am Tec a few years ago and saw it again. Heimana Reynolds. Pure style. He is from Hawaii. He surfs, skates and is about as cool as one can be. It isn't hard to see the reason once you meet his father. Epic human. Heimana was on an absolute tear this year at the Combi contest but a slam took him out...  literally. He left on a stretcher but made it back to watch the finals. I personally think he has the potential to light that building on fire next time around. It will be a great thing to see. I asked Heimana a few questions and here is what he had to say. Enjoy- Ozzie Heimana Reynolds BTO-  How much do you skate and what do you ride the most? Vert, street or bowls? Heimana-  I try to skate as much as I can, probably about three to five times a week. I skate everything from flat ground to curbs to street to vert and bowl. I usually get warmed up skating street then work my way to skating bowl. I'll go up to the vert ramp and then usually I end skating street again. I vary things. BTO- How much influence does surfing have on your skateboarding? Heimana-  It has a lot of influence on my skateboarding because I am lucky enough to do it almost everyday with good waves and warm water. Surfing and skating definitely work hand in hand. My skating helps my surfing and my surfing helps my skating. BTO- How do you learn new tricks and what inspires you to do so? Heimana-  I learn new tricks by thinking of them in a skate session and trying them out. If they work and I like it then I keep trying and trying until I hopefully land it. I get my inspiration from seeing really good skating from other skaters or skating with my friends and feeding off of each other. BTO- Is there anything you really want to learn that you haven't yet? Heimana-  Of course there are a lot of tricks out there that I want to learn, but ultimately I just want to get better at everything and keep learning. BTO- Favorite trick that you do? Heimana-  My favorite trick has definitely got to be a Madonna. I like to see how far I can kick my foot out and I like to see how loud I can slap my tail. BTO- Influences (pros past or present)? Heimana-  Some of my biggest influences were of course my dad and my family but as a grom my biggest pro influences were the boys from “The Search for Animal Chin.” I watched it so many times I could repeat all the lines and call out the tricks. I especially liked it when they came to Hawaii and skated the famous Wallos ditch located in my neighborhood. BTO- Favorite places to skate? Heimana-  I enjoy skating my home parks here in Hawaii with my boys. But I also really enjoy traveling to California to skate with all my friends there. I spend a lot of time at Combi, DC Ramp, and Woodward. BTO- Future plans? Heimana- My future plans are to finish school, and keep trying to get better at skateboarding and surfing. I enjoy competing and traveling to new places. There are so many surf and skate spots all over the world to be ridden. I plan to stay involved with skateboarding as much as I can. My family owns a successful skate shop and skate park here on the islands so skateboarding will always be a part of my future. Thank you to Heimana for the words and MRZ, Landon Hayashi, N. Bustamante and Dan Sparagna for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Christian Hosoi on Shogo Kubo
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20230" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shogo Kubo[/caption] Shogo Kubo. He was a huge part of the early era of skateboarding. The generation of Tony Alva, Jay Adams, the Z-Boys and Dog Town. Shogo was an integral part of that time. When he first came here, he barely spoke English, but soon after, he was a master at using the English language to heckle and joke. He would make us laugh hysterically. Back then, there was a declaration... a creed. If you skated, you had to step up and rip. If you didn't, you had to go. You had to be trying. Shogo and Jay were my mentors. They raised me with that attitude. That attitude was expressed: "If you're going to layback, do it! You need to blast. No half-stepping." It was the Golden Age. Skateboarding was its own little culture at the time. Attitude. Aggression. Style. Individuality.  The next generation (ours), translated all of this into travel and sponsorship. I took what Shogo taught me and applied it to my life. It is so ironic that Shogo and Jay were taken from us at the same time. What they gave us is incredible. We'll continue to harness and draw from them. Both were such radical skateboarders. They were passionate and uncompromising people. Shogo was not about the limelight. He was all about style. This really resonated with me. The personal time I spent with him is important. He stayed with me and my pops at our house and we would shoot pool all night and skate all day. My father was great friends with all of my mentors and that made it easy for me to have access to their wisdom, which has led me down the road I have traveled ever since.  Shota Kubo is Shogo's son. He has his own thing going as well. He honors his father and I know that Shogo is proud that he has a son that loves skateboarding. The bottom line is that skateboarding is not just a sport. It's about keeping it authentic and respected. Honor it. Never exploit it. This is what I learned from Shogo. Rest In Peace Shogo.  - Christian Hosoi Thank you to William Sharp for the previously unpublished photographs of Shogo and thank you to Christian Hosoi for the words. Honor Shogo Kubo and skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jeff Littlefield HR crew Pacifica CA
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Two so True and never forgotten. Nice job Christian
Thanks Christian.

Amazing! I 'm from Rio de Janeiro , Brazil . I need to teel , thank you Ozzy ! You're a skateboard lover , not just for ride . But for the history , the memory! The real spirit of skate. Again. Thank you for share this pictures, historys and moments with family skateboard arround the world ! God bless you .

item.title: Jerry Valdez / Barham Ditch
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Concrete ditches and spillways seem bleak to the average person but to a motivated skater who sees all the possibilities and lines, they become a treasure. Once given an imaginary mystique title, it conjures up all the inspiration and determination to rip. Barham Ditch aka “Little Rincon” was a small ditch nestled in the hills of the Universal Studio back lot. It provided continual backside hits and frontside slashes with its twenty degree slope for flow. As we faced being busted and jailed for trespassing at every skate spot, this site was worth the stress of a possible arrest, which made every ride the best.

item.title: William Sharp / Some Thoughts
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
As I look back on the journey to publishing this book, I find myself intrigued at the thought that I sat on all of this material for nearly thirty-six years. I had no interest in doing anything with this material. After all, I was a really young twenty year old when this journey began and I didn't think anyone would still be interested in thirty year old skateboarding photographs. I had a new life photographing surfing since the early 1980's and never even thought about doing anything with these photographs. The slides and black and white proof sheets sat lonely in boxes for all of these years.
But in 2010, I received a phone call from Brad Bowman, a skater I had met in 1976 and had photographed many times for Skateboard World magazine. He wanted to know if I wanted to ride along with him to a made-to-skate pool, overlooking Paradise Cove in Malibu. I told him that I wasn't really in the skate scene any more and had no interest in going. A few days later, he called me up again and asked me to reconsider. I decided to go and I brought my camera.
On that day, I met the pool owner Angelo Gullotti. His father had owned the Skate City Whittier skateboard park in the 1970's. Little did I know at the time, that this meeting would lead to a great, heartfelt friendship. Angelo had built a replica of the Skate City Clover pool next to his regular swimming pool overlooking the ocean. His friends could come by to skate and swim. Right away, I was back in the skate scene. It was as if I had gone back in a time machine. Along with Brad, I was reunited with Steve Lippman, who was a grom back in the 1970's but would rip up the parks and pools of the San Fernando Valley. He went on to become a great photographer as well. I met Lance Mountain, a shredder, who became famous after I left skateboarding, but who is one of the best skateboarders I have ever seen. I took pictures and it was an awesome and memorable day for me. It was the first step on the road to putting this book together. I was stoked, recharged and it brought back so many memories of the good old days with my brother Stan, and all the fun we had shooting the great skaters of the day. I left feeling really happy and I was glad that I went.
A month or so later, I was back at Angelo's, enjoying some cold beers and skateboarding. I met Ozzie Ausband of the Blue Tile Obsession. He put forth the idea of putting together a book of my old material. I recall saying something like, "Are you kidding? I have thousands of color slides and boxes of B&W proof sheets. No way. It's too much work." Ozzie told me to think about it. He said that maybe we should go over some of the material. Some time went by and I ended up pulling out some of the slides. The memories came rushing back. At that moment, I realized that it was time to do a book and bring these images back to life.
It has taken over three years since that time. I scanned over three thousand slides and reviewed hundreds of B&W proof sheets. We edited and edited and edited until we settled on approximately five hundred images. It took a long time to track down the skaters and interview them. Some still skated, others got out of skateboarding altogether and some are -- unfortunately --no longer with us. We persevered, and things finally came together.
After nearly thirty-six years of sitting in boxes in my garage, and a few years in the making, we finally have a book. We hope you enjoy it as much as we did putting it together. We hope it brings back the memory of your youth, like it did for us.

item.title: Banks / Schoolyards
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The mid 1970's. Los Angeles. The hillsides ran up and away from the ocean. Roads meandered and homes, public parks and schools were nestled up among the slopes and canyons in between. Catch basins constructed with rough concrete were situated randomly along Mulholland Drive and throughout the Hollywood hills. These were designed to aid in water runoff during storms in the winter months. The catch basins had long sloping walls and a mellow downhill angle. They were to collect rain runoff. The contractors that built them couldn't know that what they were building would soon be utilized for a different purpose altogether. Skateboarding. The local schoolyards were tucked away into the hills as well. Playgrounds were smooth asphalt and these also had sloping sides in some places. The banked school yards literally wrapped around these playgrounds. The builders had unwittingly created the first skateboard parks. Young surfers and skateboarders in Los Angeles would ride these banked schoolyards and the catch basins in the hills. They'd pretend they were surfing. They would mimic the moves of their surf heroes. It all happened in Los Angeles.

item.title: Acknowledgements
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
There are a lot of people who I wish to acknowledge for helping make this book a reality. First, I would like to tank my parents for buying me my first camera when I was thirteen years old and encouraging me to "document my life". Pretty standard stuff, I know. But if they hadn't given me my first camera, I don't know that I would've went out and bought one on my own.
My brother Stan Sharp, who constantly put down my early attempts at photography, like any good older brother would, to help me become a better photographer and think outside the box. He made me think more abstractly about what I was doing. Stan came up with the concept of having two photographers shoot the same session. He and I would cover it from different angles. One color, one black and white. While most shooters hated the idea of another photographer at the session, Stan utilized the concept to its maximum potential and ended up with great results. This is just one of the reasons why many people thought Skateboard World was a damn good publication. Stan was the driving force behind us getting in with the Dog Town skaters as well, for reasons I won't go into, but if you remember what those days were about, I don't need to explain.
Tony and Johnny Altieri, my earliest skateboarding influences. They kept nagging at me to go out and shoot with them on their homemade skateboards in the very beginning.
Jerry Valdez, who always took me to the edge of reality in terms of life and skateboarding. He was a great influence in the way I approached shooting skateboarding. He is a lifelong friend and someone who truly showed me an alternative way of looking at how I envisioned my photographic ideas.
Tony Alva. The first real pro skater I ever took photographs of. He showed me how skateboarding was supposed to be done. From banks, parks, pipes and backyard pools, he was the consummate ripper of the times. A real innovator in the truest form. I can't say enough about his influences on the way skateboarding evolved.
Brad Bowman, for making those phone calls to come to Angelo's and watch the session. I believe that if he hadn't invited me to come watch him skate, all of these images might, and probably would, still be in boxes in my garage. For that, I am very grateful.
Angelo Gullotti, who quickly became a good friend after initially meeting in 2010. For helping me to not take life too seriously, to enjoy the moment and not get caught up in things out of my control. His advice on the publishing end of this project was invaluable as we went forward with each step of the process. I still enjoy taking his council whenever I get the opportunity.
Ozzie Ausband, for motivating me to do this project. He helped me realize the historical aspect of the entire thing. He was the real force behind my decision to move forward with this book. He was also the guy who kept after me to continue working at the scanner, on those days when I had eyeball headaches from staring at my computer screen. I can't imagine doing this book without his help or input. He definitely knows his skateboard history and I without him, I wouldn't have had this project off the ground.
Lance Mountain, Steve Olson, Ray Zimmerman and Arto Saari for their counsel and advice in all aspects of making this book a reality. All of them provided us with invaluable advice in every stage of the process. I can't express my thanks nearly enough for all they provided.
Paul Wisniewski for doing such an awesome job laying out the book. We owe him a ton of thanks for making the book look the way it does. I am grateful for all of his hard work in making this into the book it has become.
Finally, to all of the photographers who were in the trenches back in the day and who had an immense influence on my photography at the time. Thank you so much for your contributions to the way we looked at skateboarding.
Warren Bolster, Craig Fineman, C. R. Stecyk III, Wynn Miller, James Cassimus, and Glen E. Friedman.

item.title: Freedom
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz

item.title: Sharp Bio
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I started taking pictures at the early age of thirteen, after my parents gave me a camera for Christmas. My first real influence was a photographer from the Los Angeles Times who was dating my sister. He was a big influence, as he got me into the darkroom to learn how to make prints and learn what the grayscale was all about. I later gravitated toward surf photography because my brother Stan and a number of our cousins were into it. I soon started shooting my friends at the schools around the area as they had banked playgrounds, which were perfect for the skaters to imitate their surfing moves.
In 1975, I heard that a new skateboard publication was going to come out. It would be based in Encino, California and would be published by High Torque Publications, which primarily published off-road magazines like Dirt Bike, Off Road and the like. This would be the first time they ventured away from this type of action sports and do a skateboarding magazine. They were under a lot of pressure to do it right.
I went in to interview to be their primary photographer, with my binder full of skateboarding photographs of my friends. They ended up hiring me on the spot. They asked if I could write and --stupidly-- I said no. I told them that my brother Stan could write really well. They asked me to get him in for an interview. The magazine basically ended up hiring him as the Associate Editor, basically my boss. The high I was feeling after being hired as the magazine's photographer was soon replaced by the thought that my older brother would now be telling me what to do and where to shoot.
In the end, it worked out great as we knew each other's strong points and Stan started using the double angle approach by having the two of us cover each session from different angles. We never missed a shot or manuever. We had it covered. This quickly contributed to Skateboard World becoming the major competitor to Skateboarder Magazine within a few months of its initial release in 1976. For nearly four years we were tied or a close second in sales and readership with Skateboarder Magazine. This was a huge feat as Skateboarder Magazine had already been established and had a higher advertising base than we did. Our sales were high and this made us very competitive. We were very proud of this fact.
In 1980, I took my very first trip to Hawaii and it was on that trip that I got hooked into shooting surfing and the ocean lifestyle in a major way. With the demise of Skateboard World in 1980, the transition to surfing photography was a simple one. I had shot surfing in the past and I knew that I wanted to do it for a living. I didn't succeed right away and I had to work my way up the proverbial ladder at Surfing Magazine. It didn't happen overnight.
During that time, the early to the mid 1980's, I worked at a friends photo lab near Universal Studios, doing color processing and printing work for independent film companies up at Universal. It taught me a great deal about the business side of the processing and printing world. I met my future wife at that time and soon we got married. At some point in the late 1980's, my friend moved his photo lab into Los Angeles and I chose not to do the daily commute.
I decided to follow my dream of shooting surfing full-time from that point on. I was soon picked up by Surfing Magazine. Over the last twenty-five years, I have worked for Surfing, Surfer, Trans World Surf and have traveled to over a dozen countries around the world on assignments for these publications. I've also done work for some of the largest advertisers in the surfing industry. At present, I contribute to Surfing Magazine.

item.title: Kent Senatore / Turningpoint Ramp
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
The Turningpoint ramp. It is possibly the one thing I’m most often associated with as a skateboarder. In some cases, I’m told Jerry Valdez and I did the first loops in it. In others, I’m told that what Jerry and I did weren’t loops at all but rather, inverted carves. I never really cared and certainly never made any claims… both Jerry and I let the images do the talking. At some point I just wanted to distance myself from the ramp and that conversation, for no other reason than that I wanted to be remembered as a pool skater. In retrospect, I am proud to have had the opportunity to work with family while riding and touring with the Turningpoint ramp. We hauled that beast from Ft. Lauderdale to New Jersey setting it up and breaking it down ourselves. We did demos at surf contests, a trade show, and the New Jersey state fair, then dragged it across the country where it ended up at Marina del Rey skate park.

By the time the ramp arrived on the west coast, I’d been riding it almost exclusively for several months. I had the thing wired, which -- if you ask anyone who’s ridden it -- was no easy feat. It was kind of scary dropping in from that little crow’s nest thing up there, and the ramp rocked back and forth while you rode it. The faster you went, the more it moved. Those four foot by four foot Lexan panels were stronger than Plexiglas, but they still flexed. Again, the faster you went, the more they flexed. It made for a bumpy ride and slowed you down. Eventually, we learned to stay off the Lexan and ride the ribs as much as possible. It could be surreal at times, especially in the low light situations we got during the night shows at the state fair.

The loop line was a figure eight starting with a carve in the dome and then two kick turns at the far end of the pipe, and the trick to getting an upside-down carve was that last kick turn. You had to get as high as you could and pump really hard off that one. It was heavy because you were over vert and looking down into the abyss. The pipe was at a 30 degree downhill angle and you were about 35’ off the ground. In the last weeks I rode it at Marina del Rey,  I was finally able to do a double loop. I knew the line was there. I’d been working up to it for a while…It really wasn’t even that hard, just scary. There was more than enough speed, I just had to come out of the first one and keep turning. Thanks to the designer, my little brother Scott Senatore for having the vision and wherewithal to make it all possible. The continued influence of his creation is reflected today by the many cradles and capsules seen in skateparks around the world.

item.title: Ozzie Ausband / Thoughts
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Full circle. As a young skateboarder living in Pennsylvania during the 1970's, I read Skateboard World magazine. I imagined that my wooden half-pipe was a backyard pool and that I was riding with Tony Alva, Kent Senatore, Jerry Valdez and all of the other great skaters I saw in the magazines. I would pretend that I was riding the Buddha pool and the Fruit Bowl along side them. It helped me through the long, frozen winters and isolation. There weren't very many skateboarders in my town. Pennsylvania consisted of god, guns and guts. I didn't really have any of those things... I rode my ramps and studied photographs. William Sharp photographs.
Fast forward. I've always skated and always will. To quote my friend Jim Howell - "...until they shovel the dirt over my face." One other thing that I've always been involved with, is writing. I've written short stories, poems and the like for as long as I can remember. I started writing for skateboard magazines in the 1990's. But the skateboarding I saw in them wasn't the skating I knew and loved. Pools had been usurped by ledges and handrails. Skateboarding had changed. I started a blog about pool skating and history. It struck a chord. People responded to the words and photographs. I found an audience.
At one point, David Hackett helped facilitate a meeting at Angelo's clover pool in Malibu with William Sharp. While skating, we talked about doing a book with his archives. That meeting started the entire project moving. It just so happens that on that day at Malibu, William took a photograph of me skateboarding. When I saw the image, I was completely stoked. William Sharp, photographer of all of my heroes, was sending me a photograph that he took of me skating. It all happened on the same day. Full circle. I am grateful for the opportunity to put this book together and give my respect to the people who helped make me who I am today. Thank you to William Sharp, Tony Alva, MRZ, Lance Mountain, Arto Saari, Shawn Ahringhoff, David Hackett, all of my pool pals and everyone I spoke to regarding this project. Gratitude. - Ozzie Ausband

item.title: Alva View / Publishing Stats
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I sat down and wrote out the proposed costs and an estimate on the Alva View project. We've decided to pay each photographer the same rate per photograph. This will minimize any potential problems among the book participants. On approach, all have been in agreement thus far. We are paying two hundred dollars per photograph for the first run of the Alva View book and one hundred dollars per photograph for ever run thereafter. It is an industry standard pricing, although it is lower than usual. All of these photographers are very keen to be involved in such a breakthrough project like this one. Tony Alva is an icon. Any project associated with him is a big deal. They know this. Tony wants to use at least five images per photographer and up to seven for some others. We have the following breakdown and image choices listed below. 1- MRZ- seven images - 1400 2- Rhino- five images- 1000 3- Grant Brittain- five images- 1000 4- Warren Bolster- three images- 600 5- Craig Fineman- three images- 600 6- Arto Saari- seven images- 1400 7- Lucia Griggi- five images- 1000 8- Boyd Harnell- three images- 600 9- William Sharp- five images- 1000 10- Stan Sharp- five images- 1000 11- Steve Wilkings- three images- 600 12- Mofo- seven images- 1400 13- Wynn Miller- seven images- 1400 14- Art Brewer- one image- 200 15- Bryce Kanights - five images- 1000 16- Raul Vega- five images - 1000 17- Lance Mountain- three images- 600 18- Goodrich- one image- 200 19- Friedman - ? 20- Stecyk - ? The total for the above chosen images minus Stecyk & Friedman is sixteen thousand dollars. The cost per book for printing is estimated at six dollars to ten dollars per book. We will complete a first run of ten thousand books.

item.title: Wally Inouye / Del Mar / Skateparks
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I had just moved to Cardiff and my good friend Curtis Hesselgrave, who I had met at Skatepark Montebello, asked Chris Strople and I if we wanted to be a part of the construction of the Del Mar Skate Ranch. I was super stoked to work on the park. Most of the design was already done, but we had a chance to change up a few things during construction. We were able to add the kidney pool which was done because of my Inouye Pool Service sticker logo. This is what they gave me as compensation for my input and work. We spent countless hours there, digging and extracting wheelbarrows of dirt and we worked with the guys who poured cement. I'm proud to have been involved with the early era of skatepark design and construction. When I see how the parks are done now, it makes me happy to know that they learned from our mistakes.

item.title: Neil Blender / Big O Pro/Am / Contests
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Steve Cathey put me on Yo-Yo wheels right before a contest back then. Double conicals. I was like, "Oh yeah man..." I did pretty well in that contest and afterwards they asked me to ride for the G&S team. I mean, they had some really amazing guys. They had Doug Saladino, Micke Alba and Billy Ruff, just to name a few. I was stoked. I had seen Steve Caballero do an Andrecht invert at the previous Big O contest. Fully table-topped. I was shocked by it. I was thinking, "Oh, I have to go and learn it like that..." I was skating hard and getting ready for the Big O Pro Am contest. G&S sent my very first package directly to the park. Gerry Hurtado --who worked there-- cut it open with a box cutter. In the process, he gouged the board. I didn't care because that package was huge. Color coordinated G&S goodies. Molly shorts, yellow and gold socks, Vans... I was stoked. I stayed with G&S until 1989 or so.

item.title: Jay Smith
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_8566" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Smith - Marina[/caption] Powell- Peralta. The Bones Brigade. I recall that team & its formation much like everyone else. 'Skateboarder' magazine  was soon to be a cherished memory. D.David Morin changed it to 'Action Now' magazine but the bicycling, sandboarding, rollerskating & the rest of it sort-of nauseated most die-hard skateboarders. Its life was short lived. Like all things  in skateboarding at that time,  everything exploded hot & heavy. It was  quickly undone. Vertical skateboarding was changing just as rapidly. Surf styles, lines & powerful flow became usurped by technical maneuvering. It became a sport of trickery. Jay Smith filled me in on the details of this time. His time. 1979.
Jay Smith hails from Canoga Park out in the San Fernando Valley. He started skating in 1975.  Jay stated- "I was really just a street skater. This was before parks and magazines in a way. All my friends rode motorcycles and skated. That was what we were into back then.  Eric Grisham and I rode pools together in the valley." Jay then told me an interesting anecdote regarding his early pool skating barges.  " The Sunset Pool company had an office with concrete demonstration pools on site. This was right next door to where 'Skatercross' was being built. They had two pools there. One was empty. We would sneak in and ride  even while the park was being built next door. It was the first time I hit tiles & I recall looking over at 'Skatercross' and wanting to ride the bowls there when it was completed." Jay became addicted to the speed and vertical like so many of us. [caption id="attachment_8567" align="aligncenter" width="527"] Jay - lapover - San Fernando Valley[/caption] He recalled riding pools all over the area when he was young. Jay told me how they would constantly look for things to skate. - "My friends and I would ride all over the San Fernando Valley. From Encino and Woodland Hills all the way over to Glendale... everywhere. There were so many pools to ride. We hopped the fence at --singer--Barry White's & were riding his pool one morning. He walked out but was really cool about it. He had his maid come outside and they watched us for awhile... he was pretty nice to us considering the situation. Lucille Ball had a house out in the Valley and it sat empty. The pool was a 'go' for quite some time. We also rode at this place in the Valley. It was a zoo or animal park. It had these bowls and stuff that were empty. The place was closed down. We rode the reservoirs  that the animals had used as a natural habitat type of thing. It was pretty unreal." Jay talked about the early skate park scene. He was a local at Skatercross. Jay told me that he rode with Eric Grisham, Arthur Viecco, Shane Reed & Jerry Valdez. He told me that those guys were a bit older though. "My early skate influence was probably Shreddi Repas. I loved to skate with him. He was stylish, fast & powerful. Eventually, I rode for Lonnie Toft & Sims. I skated with the whole Santa Barbara crew. Doug de Montmorency, Jack Waterman and other Oxnard and Skatercross riders." Jay told me that he was really into flow and speed. -"I really love to go fast!" It would be at Oxnard where Jay had his first photograph taken which ended up in the magazine. " Bill Sharp took a photograph of me doing a tailtap on the corner. I was stoked. I couldn't believe it!" Things started falling into place for Jay. He was skating some of the hottest parks & pools. His speeding, low-slung, rubberman  approach to skateboarding was rapidly winning him respect & admiration. Jay then told me how he was put on the Powell Peralta team that Stacy had just formed. Jay is a wealth of historical skateboard information. After all, he was on Powell Peralta before he was 18 years old. These were formative years for Jay. He continued- "I was riding for Sims but they already had Bert Lamar & Brad Bowman. Those guys were both super riders & Sims wasn't really doing anything for me. Powell Peralta & Sims were both out of Santa Barbara as well. It was odd. When Stacy approached me at Marina del Rey and asked me to ride for him, I was like- "Oh hell yeah!" It was immediate."Jay told me that the Bones Brigade started as- Stacy Peralta, Ray Bones Rodriguez, Mike McGill, Alan Gelfand and then he was added.  I asked him about the 'Powell Peralta Class of 79' advertisement.  Jay stated that Stacy  chose the best he could find to represent all areas of the country.  " Stacy added Mike Jesiolowski & Jami Godfrey from Cherry Hill right after I was put on the Bones Brigade. He also added Rodney Mullin & Tim Scroggins from Florida, Steve Caballero & Scott Foss from Northern California, Teddy Bennett from Big -O and David Zakrzewski from Oasis. That was the original Powell Peralta team." Jay remembered early contests with Powell Peralta and stated tersely- " Contests just weren't my thing man! They're just too organised. That goes against everything I am. I just loved partying and riding pools with my friends. Stacy was super nice though. He bumped up our confidence. If I remember correctly, I actually turned Pro at the Bakersfield contest before I was on Powell Peralta. Once I was on the Bones Brigade, I waited for awhile before I received a model. I think we all did." Steve Caballero & others told me that some of the riders kept their AM status & continued to build contest standings & placings. They developed new tricks and worked on their overall skating. This way, they created a demand for a model rather than just having one put out for them. [caption id="attachment_8568" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay- FS Air - Pipeline Combi[/caption] Jay Smith himself was soon ready for his own model. He originally rode Powell Peralta Double Beamers. - "I wanted the Double Beamer to be my model but they were having lamination problems." Jay asked me if I remembered the rivets in the Double Beamers.-  "Of course." He laughed & continued-  "Back then we would do long boardslides and the top- most layer of black fiberglass would become ground down. The rigidity of the deck was affected and it would snap. Rib Bones were then made larger to compensate for this.  Caster made my boards for awhile. The first Jay Smith 'Splash' deck was made by them. I think that the Caster boards were more expensive though. They were really good & had concave. Powell Peralta finally ended up making my boards from Brite Lites but they were definitely flatter than the Casters were. " [caption id="attachment_8569" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay- Andrecht at Marina[/caption] Jay went on & discussed the early punk scene and its influence in his life. He loved the fast music, motorcycles and anarchy.  " It went along with what we were doing. The music and clothing added to it. It was crazy, fast & fun. I really didn't care. I just wanted to rip and have fun....  no worries." Jay told me that Stacy liked him on the team with his long hair & all. "I was just rebellious. I was actually a long-haired surfer kid. Then, I made an anti-christ kind-of change. I cut all my hair off. I was back east with Glen Friedman. We were going to Cherry Hill, Staten Island, Apple & other parks. We would go in & cut the skaters hair. It was just to be obnoxious...  the kids were so cool."  Jay said that he was really into heavy rock-n-roll like Zeppelin & early Van Halen but the punk music was too hard to resist. "Bands like The Buzzcocks, Discharge, 999 and others soon fueled all of our sessions."  Jay told me that he will always have a fondness for Marina del Rey & Cherry Hill skateparks. "They were the best things I ever rode." I had heard various stories regarding Jay Smith over the years.  One quote - "He was the epitome of punk."   Another - "Jay would take a contest run and he'd just carve in circles throughout the entire time... smiling." Whatever the case may be, Jay Smith was hard to miss. He was a standout. Glen E. Friedman & Jay became pretty good friends and would hang out quite a bit back then. Some of the great Jay Smith images that we have were from Glen and this period in time. Style. Timeless perfection.  Glen told me about Jay Smith- " The bad uncle (to Stacy's good father) of the Bones Brigade, his awesome girlfriends, his insane risk taking driving, The most stylish layback and frontside carve in existence, and a heartbreak of an injury that sent him for a loop. I took him to see the Bad Brains play a club in NYC (when they first moved here), with less than 30 people attending the show. We drove across the country together to do a skate tour and he tweaked his ankle on the first stop, so it was 'Jay's Barber Shop Tour' instead. That's just off the top of my head-- 30 years later." [caption id="attachment_8570" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Classic Skateboarder Magazine centerfold by: G.E. Friedman[/caption] Jay Smith and his life have been shrouded in myth & legend for decades. I was at the 'Old School Skate Jam' in 2000 and I remember seeing Jay Smith attending the event. There were just as many people crowding around Jay as  there were with Tony Alva. He has immense popularity & appeal. Jay is one of a kind. I asked him about his  disinterest in skateboarding & subsequent walk from it.  He readily replied- "I didn't dump skating! I became kind-of bored with it. Tricks were becoming wall-to-wall and mechanical. It took away from the speed,  flow and beauty. If you take away the beauty of it, it'll lose everything. That is what drove me from skateboarding. The 'power & finesse' is what made it rad for me. That is what Powell Peralta embodied. Stacy encompassed all of this. Jay lists Duane Peters, Eddie Elguera, Shreddi, Steve Caballero &  Scott Foss as being a huge influence to him & his skating. [caption id="attachment_8571" align="aligncenter" width="480"] King James Cassimus sequential of Jay Smith layback[/caption] Jay told me that he continued riding into the mid 1980s but motorcycles & racing took up more of his time. Eventually he stopped.  He saw Richie Carrasco at a show & Richie kept after Jay to go skating. Eventually he caved in. Jay- "Richie took me out and we went slalom riding. It was so rad. Pretty soon, I was riding vert, doing airs and laybacks, I slammed though and was hurt pretty badly. It hurts more... and for a longer time these days."  I asked Jay if he skated recently. He went on to tell me of a dark day a few years back. A day he will never forget. He was riding his motorcycle in the rain. Almost night. The black greasy ribbon of wet freeway reflected all of the lights. " I was in a motorcycle accident on the 101. I slammed into a car. I had a few drinks & it was raining. I got on the freeway and found myself behind this woman going 55 mph. I got pissed and went around her. I really gunned it. Then I saw why she had been going only 55 mph. There was a car directly in front of her going slow. I saw it at the same moment that I ran up into the back end. I hit her so hard that I broke both my legs. I got tore up! I was in the hospital for a few weeks. I haven't really skated because I have plates and screws in my legs. My movement just isn't there. No flexibility." I was quiet for a moment, digesting all the tragedy that Jay had just laid bare. The thought of Jay Smith skating without flexibility was intolerable. It was like Picasso without a paintbrush. I groaned inwardly.  Jay quietly went on - "Ozzie, you know what ? It was all worth it. Skateboarding. I am stoked on my skating time and how it all went down."  So are we Jay.... so are we. Thank you to Glen E. Friedman for the --previously--unpublished Jay Smith images. Thank you to Jay Smith, Steve Caballero, Glen E. Friedman & Jami Godfrey for their memories. Thank you to King James Cassimus and Bill Sharp for images. We'll just thank them all. Jay wants to thank Dave at Skaterbuilt for all the support. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Fishbowl / Pink Motel / Camtest
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_20313" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad Bowman[/caption] History. They say it is written by the victors. Funny. I suppose that another saying may also be true...  "Half the world believes what the other half invents." Whatever the case may be, the origins of Fishbowl AKA The Pink Motel are solid and sure. Factual history. Think what you want, I'm here to relate it as I heard it. A group of young skaters from the San Fernando Valley were skating to school one day and they spotted the pool behind the fence. Terry Bixler and Wagner Rodrigues crept inside and were summarily kicked out. They had the moxie to return and be persistent. [caption id="attachment_20339" align="aligncenter" width="409"] Monty - Fishbowl/Pink Motel Owner[/caption] Eventually, they made an arrangement with the owner- Monty -and the pool became a permission pool for them and anyone they cared to bring along. They kept it tight and secretive. It was 1976. Eventually, word leaked and skaters began riding it. Magazine images appeared. Fishbowl would become a Mecca. Pilgrimage. Skaters around the world marveled at its huge transitions and giant palm trees. It screamed "California". [caption id="attachment_20315" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Fishbowl[/caption] Fast forward. 1987. Powell Peralta video - Animal Chin. The Bones Brigade were famously told, "You guys can do anything you want to do, if you want..." Then they did. The footage from that session is amazing. I believe that it was at this time that the Fishbowl became known in skateboarder's minds as the Pink Motel. In the late 1980's, Skate TV used the Pink Motel as a base camp. Heavy sessions were held and all of it was pumped out through the wires and into televisions all over the place. Fishbowl. Pink Motel. Its history is heavy. Its place in skateboarding is cemented fast. [caption id="attachment_20331" align="aligncenter" width="1017"] Bones Brigade / Animal Chin Session. Mountain, McGill, Guerrero, Caballero, Hawk[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20341" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance with Lance Jr. / Skate TV[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20342" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Steve Caballero / Skate TV[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20343" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain / Skate TV[/caption] Over the years, random skating events have been held at the Pink Motel. It can be rented out hourly, though it can be costly. In 2010, Lance Mountain helped California Skateparks with a pool refurbishing that smoothed out the transitions and skim-coated a new surface onto the entire pool. It had deteriorated from years of sun, skating and sitting empty. [caption id="attachment_20336" align="aligncenter" width="584"] California Skateparks refurbishing[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20337" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Fishbowl Facelift[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20338" align="aligncenter" width="436"] Lance Mountain ties the old into the new.[/caption] In the past few years Cam Dowse has been holding his Camtest event at the Pink Motel and --once more-- the Pink Motel finds itself host to a good thing. Cam started holding the Camtest in Colorado in the early 2000's. It was a way to get all of the Colorado skaters together and session. They held it off-and-on over the years at different locations in Colorado. Eventually, Cam would end up in California. One year, Cam was going to hold his birthday party at the Pink Motel when he found out that his close friend Dave Tuck was diagnosed with Cancer. The subsequent birthday party became the Camtest and a fundraiser to help his ailing friend. [caption id="attachment_20321" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Camtest 2012 / Pink Motel[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20325" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Robbie[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20333" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20327" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Cam Dowse[/caption] The next year, it was held in Arvada, Colorado with Dave Tuck in attendance. Ultimately Dave was taken from the skateboarding world and his friends miss him terribly. His legacy and good nature live on in everyone he knew. Friends never die as long as we continue to celebrate their lives... [caption id="attachment_20332" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Dave Tuck R.I.P.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20322" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Glen Charnoski Camtest/Dave Tuck Invitational/ Arvada[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20329" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Parts, Tuck and James / Arvada Tuck Invitational[/caption] Camtest is being held this year at the Pink Motel. It is a ten dollar donation at the gate and ALL money goes to cancer charities. Three bands will play and DJ Don Cesar will spin tunes. The contest will have weight-classes ranging from 100-125 pounds all the way up to 200 pounds plus. Everyone will get to lay into the historical coping of the Fishbowl/Pink Motel. The Camtest runs from 1:00 pm until 9:00 pm. If you've never been to the Pink Motel or witnessed unbridled skateboarding mayhem, then you should drop the ten dollars for a good cause and come have fun. After all, most of us spend that much at Starbucks in a week... they're not nearly as historical or important in the grand scheme of things compared to the Fishbowl/Pink Motel. History. Truth. See you there... A special thank you to William Sharp, MRZ, Team Pain, Brandon Wong, Skatemaster Tate, Thrasher Magazine and Powell Peralta for the images. Thank you to Cam Dowse for putting it all together for a great cause. R.I.P. Dave Tuck. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_20349" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Dave Tuck R.I.P.
Image: Thrasher[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Right on Great read Ozzie. Cam rules,Tuck Lives!

item.title: Alva Rhino Vans
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The Bakersfield Vans park had a huge bowl built in it. It was a freak of nature. It wasn't even meant to be built that big and gnarly. Vans sent a crew of guys out there with Rick Carje, who had built the Vans Combi pool in Orange. Jeff Grosso and some other guys went out there and they were determined to make something that was just fucking scary. They did exactly that. It was a huge capsule, like a version of the Big O skatepark capsule pool, but even bigger. It was gnarly. The channel would throw you out. If you tried to air over it, you had to release early and stretch for the other wall. The sides didn't match up. None of the kids in Bakersfield really skated it. It didn't get ridden unless a crew of gnarly pirates came through there. It took an invasion crew to get a session in there. It didn't last very long either. I think that park lasted maybe two or three years. Vans started closing down parks for financial reasons and it was one of the first to get dozed. Believe it or not, I liked that pool. It had great carving lines. It was deep and gnarly. No joke.

item.title: Grant / Arizona Jump Ramps
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The jump ramp days. Arizona. We were doing demonstrations. You can see all of the kids. In the jump ramp era, we probably broke more boards than ever. The tails would snap right off. We would pull back and do Method airs. It's crazy that we'd do jumps like that. We had wide boards and soft wheels. It all worked together. For awhile we were riding Converse as well. I guess we were into the Ramones, Clash, post-punk rock look and Converse were what we related to at that time. They sucked for skating though. It was like wrapping some canvas around your foot. No support. The other shot is from the same trip in Arizona. I'm riding a Cooksie board and doing a tail tap. It is almost like a backside layback... I can't believe how fit and thin I look. I was probably living a bit better then. Lean and mean... and leaning mean.
