item.title: MRZ / Nude Bowl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I brought 215 Indys and a new board to the Nude Bowl. It had recently been unearthed and I figured since I was going back out to revisit such a gnarly spot, I'd make it more gnarly by bringing such a setup. It is all new. I get really comfortable with clothing and shoes so you can see I'm wearing some trashed pants and stuff I just can't get rid of. I have my Wood on Wheels t-shirt on. It goes back to 2008. I visited Prescott, Arizona. I asked some kids that were skating at Prescott, "How do I get on the team?" The kids ran up to the team manager, scrambled back to me with a t-shirt, threw it to me and said, "You're on the team." That was that. It was really funny. I don't recall when it was that I first rode the Nude Bowl. I remember going out there and skating when bands were playing. I saw Kyuss and JFA at the Nude Bowl. We would go out to keg parties. Party zone. Great pool, no rules, no limits. This photograph makes me think of the Nude Bowl as the pool that would not die. MRZ really caught the moment. He is really close to me as well. He's six inches from the nose of my board. That's faith.

item.title: MRZ Borrego
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was the way we started our new years in 2013. This pool was immense. Seventy feet long and forty feet wide. It had a spit gutter at the top. It had nine to ten foot face wall transitions too. I'll tell you this: besides the Champion Bowl, next to the Hollywood Race Track, this is the biggest egg-shaped pool I've ever skated. It is big! The volume of this pool is huge. You can carve the entire pool all the way around and never really carve across the flat bottom until you get by the shallow stairs. In the photograph, where I'm doing the edger, there is another fifty feet of wall still towards the shallow end. It is unheard of. You could fit three Gonzales pools inside of it. That pool was super big. So much room. You told me that it has been bulldozed since the time of this photograph. That's what makes these images what they are. Rare moments. Many of the places in these photographs don't exist anymore. It is like looking at a surf spot where they built a harbor now. If you look at Stanley's Diner next to Rincon, they built a freeway exit over the surf spot. It was a good wave. They built a seawall with rocks over the sandbar. Done. That is where surfing and skating relate in other ways as well. Many skaters don't get that because they don't surf. You can have a great spot one day and the next... it is gone! This is especially true if it's a reservoir, pipe, ditch or a pool. In my opinion, these are the four best things in the world to find and skate. A reservoir like Skyline, a ditch like Indian School, a pipe like Baldy or Amarillo, and backyard pools. We've built some pretty good pools in skate parks but no matter how hard we try, they aren't as good as the real thing. That's because real pools are like waves. They are never the same. Waves break differently. Real pools are just like that. Two pools can be the same shape, but they will not ride that way. Imperfections. The subtleties of the transitions, the surface, the coping...nothing is the same.

item.title: MRZ PIPE
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Rusty, dusty, gnarly, in the middle of a stinky-ass San Pedro industrial area. The pipe had a chemical smell to it. The sound was so hollow and strange when I was skating the pipe. Indescribable sound. Echoing. It was up on a trailer. You can see that it was chained onto it. I'm wearing a mask and you can barely see that only my eyes were showing because of the chemicals and dust. Who knows what was inside this thing when it was in use. I have a full face mask on. It was winter. Cold. I'm heavily clothed. I like that he caught the skate action between the metal spokes of the pipe. Overall, it was a pretty big pipe. It was about eighteen feet wide and forty feet long. It was the best metal pipe, in the last few years, that we've had the opportunity to ride. Although we were trespassing, I don't recall it being a big bust or anything. We got in, skated and got out. I think that when I pulled up, MRZ and his crew were done and packing it up. They stuck around for a bit and I took a few runs. This is a photograph of one of them and this is how I met MRZ. Trespassing.

item.title: Jay Adams / Last Words
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20399" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jayboy[/caption] It has been almost a year since Jay Adams left us. He passed August 15, 2014. He carved away from the sun. He didn't look back. We don't know why... The finality of someone leaving us is difficult to grasp. The void. Jay Adams was a remarkable light in the world. I was searching through my computer files this past winter. I was looking for something that Jay had sent to me for use in the William Sharp book - Back in the Day. I found an email from Jay and it was dated September 3, 2012. It was a story that he had written to me about his early skateboard experiences in pools. I was shocked, as I couldn't remember reading it before. I am unsure why I didn't recall the email or if I was saving it... Maybe I was supposed to save it for now. Is Jay smiling down on us? Maybe it was meant to be. Whatever the reasons, I decided that today would be a good day to send it out into the world. I rewrote it exactly the way Jay sent it to me. It is Jay Adams. All of him. R.I.P. Jayboy.  - Ozzie "The boundaries which divide life and death are at best shadowy and vague. Who shall say where the one ends, and where the other begins." - Poe [caption id="attachment_20396" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay Adams / Rabbit Hole[/caption] Jay Adams/Last Words I really cannot remember the first time I ever skated in a pool, but I do remember that I wasn't too stoked on it. I'd come back from living in Hawaii for a few months and while I was gone, Alva and the boys had found one. They had made the change from riding schoolyard banks to riding empty pools.The first one was called the Rabbit Hole. It was a little kidney which was ridable, but not really a perfect one, like the pools we found later. I hated wearing shoes when I skated and basically Alva and everyone told me that I had to learn to skate with shoes. Pool riding was a bit rougher than riding the banks and schoolyards. The boys had a little head start on me and it showed. Alva was just learning how to carve over the light. Frontside kickturns were just being invented. After the Rabbit Hole pool experience, all of us were addicted to pool skating. It was all that we wanted to do. We soon had another one called the Canyon Pool, which was actually a very good pool. The Canyon Pool was the first pool that I can remember being bothered by the cops. The cops would come and kick us out, so we used to have guys on lookout patrol, waiting for the cops to drive down the street coming for us. It was funny to me back then. We didn't think that we were doing anything wrong. We were just playing in someone's empty pool. They weren't using it, right? We never thought we were trespassing. Those charges came later. [caption id="attachment_20408" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay - Log Cabins[/caption] The Canyon Pool was the real beginning for all of us Dogtowners. We were really hooked on pool skating. Alva was the king and I'll say it again: Alva skated better than everyone at that time. He was faster and more stylish than anyone that had ever been seen. This was still very early and knee pads weren't even being used yet. We all got banged up a bit, but when you're a young teenager, nothing can stop you. Especially a few little road rashes. Alva was the king in our area, but then a guy named Johnny Palfreyman put down his BMX bike and started riding pools with us. He rode BMX and he skated. If you've never heard of Palfreyman, you're missing out on some important history about skateboarding. J.P. lived in the little studio that me and my mom rented on 7th and Sunset in Ghosttown. Venice was dangerous back then. It was not like it is today. We were some of the only little, white surfer types living down there then. Palfreyman was out of his mind. He came from a tough family of crazy motorcycle riding men. They were not bikers though. His dad was the best sidehacker in America and J.P. followed in his footsteps. He was the first guy I ever saw ride his bike in a pool.  J.P. would do wheelers in pools. If you were from Santa Monica back in the 1970's, you would have known about him and his brothers. They were crazy guys. [caption id="attachment_20409" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay - Dogbowl[/caption] So, Alva was the king, but J.P. was the raddest. He did the very first two coping block edgers on a skateboard that I've ever seen. Edgers became the new rad move and J.P. had them down. After the Canyon Pool, we would go to the Fruit Bowl in Orange County. J.P. was living at my house, so we were skating every day. We were either driving down to O.C. or going up to Beverly Hills or even the San Fernando Valley. Before I forget, I have to give credit to the Valley boys. We had Dogtown, but they had their own scene going on at the same time. Jerry Valdez was their king and the Jer was rad. Kent Senatore was another guy who really ripped it up with style. The Valley guys had so many pools... It isn't hard to see how they became good pool skaters. In the 1970's, there was a water drought, so people were ordered to keep their pools empty, unless they were already filled. No one could fill a pool anywhere in LA. We were constantly looking for pools. We would ride down alleys in Beverly Hills, sitting on the roof of Stacy Peralta's car, or rent a little plane at the Santa Monica airport. We searched. There was nothing we wouldn't do, if it meant we could ride a new pool. We had one called the Fireman, because the owner was a fireman and we basically knew when he'd be at work for three days on, four days off. We were able to skate his pool when he was gone. We also had one in Beverly Hills called the Keyhole. It was perfect. They were doing construction on the house. On Friday afternoon, we'd come and drain all the water out, skate it all weekend, then fill it back up Sunday afternoon, just like we found it. This all occurred mostly before skateparks put in good pools. [caption id="attachment_20410" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Jay - Image: Surfer Today[/caption] I guess I could continue on and tell you about the Gonzales pool or the Dogbowl, but I'll wait until next time to tell you about those... These days, everyone still loves backyard pools. There's something really special about finding one, draining it out, then riding it. Its a bit more soulful than pulling up to a skatepark, putting on the pads and skating through all the kids. But I do have to say that I love skateparks and bowls that were made for skating. There is nothing more perfect for me. The whole backyard pool thing... well that's what made us skateboard criminals when we were young and crazy. That was fun.  Aloha - JAY BOY 100 percent skateboarder 4 life Addendum- The William Sharp book - Back in the Day is due out this fall. It contains anecdotes from all of the pioneers of skateboarding. Chapters include, banks, ditches, schoolyards, pools, pipes, contests and parks. We will keep everyone informed when it is ready- Ozzie Thank you Jay Adams for the words and memories. Rest In Peace. Thank you to Kent Sherwood, Surfer Today and William Sharp for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Red Lip
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I first saw this pool in 2009. Cloudy November. The cold would soon call to us. Winds ripped at the trees, as I stood beside the truck looking at the property. I had already pulled myself up and peered over the block wall. Rossmore kidney pool. Red coping. The blue tiles were barely visible due to the pea-green colored water that filled the old pool. I looked the house over and noted the trash piled up, tattered sheets over the windows and the grip of neglect that wrapped the house in dirty arms. I could see no signs of life. I wedged open the back gate and took my pump inside. I moved slowly, like I was in a dream. An hour went past. Tick tock. No one bothered me and nothing existed except the gurgle of the hoses and the low rumble of the pump. I brushed the walls of the pool with a sidewalk broom to remove algae as it drained. The pump had dropped the water level about halfway and the shallow end was looking pretty good. I was pushing the broom in the shallow end, removing green muck, when I heard a voice. It startled me. "What do you think you are doing?" I was looking into the face of an elderly woman. She had the back door partially open and her eyes darted from my face, to the pool, and back again. She seemed as shocked by my presence as I was of hers. The pump suddenly sounded much louder than it had been before. My blood thrummed. Conflict. I switched off the pump. "I didn't know anyone lived here." I started. I smiled at her. I told her my name was Hugh Jorgan, as I usually did in such situations. It kept the smile on my face. She looked confused. "I work with Vector Control. We pump out filthy pools that harbor mosquitoes." I could tell that she wasn't really buying my story. I moved over to the pump and started collecting my things together. This was not going well. Over my shoulder I quickly stated, "I'll have my employer call you and explain the need to have the pool emptied." She moved back inside and locked the door. I felt that she might be phoning someone. Someone in law enforcement. My pace quickened. I gathered the hoses and threw everything into my truck in a pile. I saw her eyes watching me from inside the house. I was the insect and she was the spider. Web of my own making. I grabbed the pump and made my retreat. Later that night, I thought about the pool. The transitions were really starting to show as I drained it. I guess it would have to wait for another day... if ever. Fast forward. April 2015. KB, Shawn, Gopa, Scott and I were out rolling around. We rode several pools that day. It was getting late and KB said that he knew of one we might hit for a thirty minute session. A house remodel. The owner was no longer living there. A day laborer stayed there and for a little quick cash, we might get some grinds. A new pool is always fun and we headed over. [caption id="attachment_20389" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kevin Burke[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20390" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Gopa Ahringhoff[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20391" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shawn Ahringhoff[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20392" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me[/caption] When we pulled up, I laughed to myself. I thought of the old lady all those years ago... I periodically wondered if I'd ever get to ride that old red-lipped pool. I guess the time was now. Thanks to the IE guys for draining it, thanks to KB for the heads up and thank you to Scott Ward for the images. Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Sharp / Dog Hug
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: What I really love about this photograph is that Bob Biniak is in the photograph as well. He passed away in 2010. We are all just kicking it in the shallow end. Everyone thinks that the Dogbowl received its name because of Dog Town, but that is not true. We called it the Dogbowl because there were all these dogs living on the property. It was a mansion in Santa Monica. Dino lived there with his parents and they were very wealthy. Affluence. You can see the size of the home in the background. Most photographs of the Dogbowl are limited to the pool area itself, but in this photograph, you can see the rest of the story. I've always been an animal lover and it just shows interaction with the dogs that lived there. The dogs loved to hang out with us by the pool. It was their pool, not ours. We were borrowing it.

item.title: Sharp AZ Pipes
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I think that we flew out to Arizona on this trip. I recall that they were really far out there in the middle of nothing. We flew out and landed on this little dirt airport. We got out and went straight to the pipes. We didn't go into a nearby town or anything. We went directly out and started skating. I've been out there a few times during the short period of time that they were being made. It was always strange. Nothing and everything. We would drive across vast expanses of dirt, cactus and heat, only to arrive at the greatest skateboarding obstacles ever made by man. Yet, they weren't meant for skateboarding. They diverted the Colorado river into Phoenix. That aqueduct was put in during the mid 1970's and it sent water into the Phoenix area. No one wanted to live in that area, unless you were a lizard... It was hot and dry. The size of the pipes can give you a good idea just how much water can be put through them. Massive amounts. They were twenty-two or twenty-three foot pipes and I'm riding some pretty primitive equipment. This was definitely early on in the desert pipes period. That's fairly high up there for a seven-inch, solid oak board.

item.title: Sharp Dogbowl headphones
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I would listen to the radio headphones.Rock stations. I think it was KMET or KLOS. It would fade in and out because of the frequency, I suppose. It wasn't like it is now with satellites and all. I always tried to tune it to a station that would play Jimi Hendrix or Led Zeppelin. I had the headphones tied on with a bandana. I wove it through the headpiece and the aluminum frame of it. Then I tied it super tight around my head so it wouldn't move around as I skated. It was ahead of its time. I should have thought to come out with some Alva headphones... but I was a young kid just skating. I just wanted to hear music and skate. I wanted that sonic sound... I also should have developed a helmet with small speakers inside. That would've been unreal. Another thing, I'm riding Powerflex wheels. When I later came out with my own Alva wheels, we emulated the multi-colored look of the Powerflex wheels. I think ours ended up being better because of the different shape we developed and the advanced urethane materials. Powerflex wheels were like gum balls. Spongy. They were good for wheelers and for skating rough spots like Skyline and ditches.

item.title: Sharp / Dogbowl Weed
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I'm unsure who that is sitting between Kent Senatore and I. It looks like Lee Gahimer. Lee was a Badlands skater though, so I'm pretty sure it cannot be him. There were no outsiders ever allowed at the Dogbowl. I can't tell who it is but he has a Heineken and we are getting ready to smoke a big fatty. I have that look like, "Fuck you!" We would smoke constantly at the Dogbowl. It enhanced our skating. At one time, smoking weed was an integral part of our deal. It helped us tune into the pool and elevated the sessions. Everyone would get into the zone and push each other. Years later, it stopped working for me. It became a detriment.

item.title: Sharp / Pipeline pipe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: You can see that this is right after the pipe was built at Pipeline Skatepark in Upland. The concrete was still curing... It looks like it is still wet. It is so new. Look at it. The really great thing about the Pipeline full pipe was that it was really long. We had ridden the Mt. Baldy pipe and the Arizona desert pipes before this. The Arizona pipes were bigger, but narrow. At Pipeline, we could carve really far and draw lines down the pipe. We already had our pipe-riding technique down. As far as I'm concerned, the rest of the Pipeline park was alright. It was big, but it only consisted of bowls with no coping. You have to understand that we were already riding pools regularly. Pools with coping. We were accustomed to having that lip, so when we went to Pipeline, we just went straight to the pipe and rode it. It is all we wanted to do there. It was all about the pipe. I rode with Bob Biniak at Pipeline. He did the highest frontside turns of anyone. Just straight up and straight down. Free-falling down. He was an insane pipe skater. His two great strengths were pipe riding and downhill. They called him "The Bullet" for a reason. He skated very fast. He was powerful in pools.

item.title: Stan Sharp / Concrete Wave
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was one of the early concrete skateparks. It was over in Anaheim. Concrete Wave. It looks like an opening day type of event too. There are a great deal of spectators around. I'm throwing down a full speed bert. I'm riding Road Riders and Bennett trucks at the time, so this was pretty long ago. It is a rare shot in some ways. I mean, there really weren't all that many skateboard photographers around back then. This is one of the first parks. There weren't that many pro riders either. It was all so new. So, it goes to show that Stan and Bill Sharp were definitely some of the first skateboarding photographers. The brothers. That is why -- with how prolific the brothers were and the shots they were taking --they gave Skateboarder Magazine good competition. Skateboard World magazine was their thing and the two Sharp brothers had amazing photographs. Not only were they at the grass-roots underground spots, but they were at the park openings as well. They made that magazine the success it was.

item.title: Stan Sharp / Lakewood Halfpipe
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Lakewood. A classic-looking photograph. It was one of the only half pipes around at the time. It was a nice transition, it was made out of concrete and that was cool and all, but it didn't have any coping. Again, we were used to riding pools that had coping and it was strange to ride somewhere without it. The more stuff we could find with coping, the better. I think that all the primitive spots that we were skating, slowly evolved and became better over time, but it had to start from something like this. Lakewood was a good start for back then.

item.title: Stan Sharp / Gonzales Group
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is funny. Such a cool photograph. We are all just mugging it up in the shallow end of the Gonzales pool in Mar VIsta. That's my sister on the steps, then Thais, my girlfriend at the time, Ray Flores and Billy Yeron. Billy Yeron dated my sister back then. Ray Flores' mom knew Mr. Gonzales back in the day and Ray was almost connected like family to the Gonzales household. We had that connection and Ray received permission and drained the pool. He brought us in. We were just laughing and having fun. It is odd to see Thais looking at the camera, as she was usually so camera shy. She was a Marymount girl. Catholic. We were together for about five years, I think. The board I have is a poplar or birch laminate deck. It had a sticker on the nose that said, "If you value your life as much as I value this skateboard, don't fuck with it."

item.title: Stan Sharp / Hester
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: We only went to the Newark Hester Series contest because of the bowl. We knew that the Newark bowl was good and we wanted to ride it, so Jay and a few of us went up and entered. I don't even know how I placed and it doesn't really matter that much. I think that this may have been one of the last contests I entered. I didn't skate very many of the contests. It was a big, fat new bowl in the shittiest part of northern California and we wanted to ride it. It wasn't a pretty place to visit. The bowl. That's why we went. The Nor Cal guys like Tim Marting, Rick Blackhart, Peter Gifford and a few others were really ripping that bowl. Roll-ins, rock-n-rolls and other tricks were done at that Hester contest. I think Tim Marting won. I did doubles with Jay in that contest and I recall doing doubles with Duane Peters at Winchester as well. I knocked Duane's ass out. He did a handplant and I hit him with my hip. He blacked out and slammed straight to the bottom. Knocked out. Master of disaster. You know Duane though... stuff like that is just a part of his story.

item.title: Stan Sharp / Olpin's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This photograph was taken at Steve Olpin's concrete half-pipe. It was only about eight feet wide. It was in Santa Monica canyon. The Palisades. Sunset boulevard is directly above the half-pipe. It was down a hill below the busy street. I think his parents had it built for him as they were wealthy and wanted to keep him close to home. It really wasn't there that long. Back then, spots like that came and went. We didn't skate there very often either. I only recall riding it a few times. It reminds me of the driveway ramp near Glen Friedman's place, because it had that broomstick type of coping. It was like they took a wooden dowel and cemented it in place. I'm riding the Bulldog board. It was probably the best board he ever did for me. Plus, I'm wearing Levi flair corduroys... It's a style shot. It looks like a photograph that should be in Details or something. Actually, they wish they could get something like this now.

item.title: Stan Sharp / San Gabriel Valley Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This pool was in San Marino and we were taken to the pool by Chris Strople. It was one that he had going. It was killer. The pool was amazing. It was fast and smooth. A perfect deep end. Pool skating has evolved. Back then, we were riding the deep end and maybe a bit of the shallow, but these days, we would ride the mid pocket, the shallow, the whole pool. I love the board I'm riding in this photograph. It is the Wes Humpston handmade board. He made everything. Routed it, hand-painted it, the entire thing. The wheels I'm riding were the prototypes for Alva Naturals. Alva Naturals were the best wheels we ever made. This entire setup was perfect. I loved that board. It is a cool image. I'm fully gunslinging it... look at my fingers. You can see Bill Sharp in the background shooting opposite Stan. Like I said, the brothers covered both angles. They always did.

item.title: Spooner Vows
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Until you, there was little else. Life was a barren field.
Not much ever made sense. It was all a puzzle with more than a few pieces gone.
Then there was you.
I promise here and now,
That I will love and protect you.
I will keep you close through every light and dark day,
when your spirits are at their lowest, I will be there.
In the best and worst of times, my heart will remain yours.
You are my best friend, my lover, my wife.
I love you, not only for what you are,
but for what I am when I'm with you.

item.title: Tony Alva Unseen
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: In January of this year, Tony Alva and his business partner Michael Early, sat down with me and we decided to move forward with a Tony Alva book project. The idea had been discussed off and on for a year or so, but with Tony's Vans commitments, travel, band schedule and generally busy life, it was shelved for the time. I was also knee-deep in the William Sharp 'Back in the Day' book project, so we sat on the idea. In January, all of that changed. Tony had a vision of what he wanted and I was asked to bring it all together. The process is a long one. I've discovered that books are a very time-consuming process. I've learned the hard way. With a full time job and hectic life, I had to work on the William Sharp book in my spare time. With Tony's book, I knew what I had to do from the start. As one of the most photographed skateboarders on the planet, I had to start from the earliest days of skateboard photography. I contacted photographers and initiated the process of having them locate decades-old slides. Tony was looking for the rarities. He wanted to only use photographs that have never been published. Unseen. We are now about a third of the way through the process and it is beginning to take shape. A life of its own. Alva Unseen is a photographic journey, complete with Tony's memories and candid observations about a life unfolding. Tony Alva: an icon, a rogue, skateboarder, surfer, musician and so much more. We will be bringing you updates as the book reveals itself. Skate- Ozzie Thank you to Jonathan Coudriet / Jon Sea for the image. For more of Jon Sea Photography: www.jonseaphotography.com

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: So rad
Brilliant ! TA = ☆☆☆☆☆
Awesome!! Looking forward to it...
The man, The legend!

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jeff Littlefield HR crew Pacifica CA
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Epic

item.title: Wynn Raggirl
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is a photograph of Rag Girl. Her real name is Karen. She was the manager of our band, the Skoundrlz. She wore rags in her hair all of the time and was a hair stylist and makeup artist. She was this crazy artist that ended up being our manager for a few years through the mid 1980's. Super supportive. Rag Girl provided us with assistance when the band really needed it. Rag Girl really contributed to our look of the time as well. We had that New Wave Gothic thing going on... I've lost track of her since then. It's funny isn't it? The people that we hang out and associate with through the crazy years of our lives, aren't around forever. I don't think that those type of relationships are meant to last.

item.title: Wynn Gonzo / TA / Mondo
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was for an advertising thing that we were doing at Wynn's studio. Mondo airbrushed and came up with the entire concept. It is a Mondo creation. Dave Beck was Mondo's real name and he was a skater from Cherry Hill, NJ. In this particular photo shoot, I was a part of the art direction. The Freddie Mercury pants I'm wearing, were made from an old wetsuit that I had been using. We dressed Mark Gonzales up in the Eddie Munster look that he has going on. He was like thirteen at the time and was already super talented. We developed that type of advertising idea and were wanting to include Mark Gonzales in it... but the ultimate result just screams "Mondo". Even though Mark Gonzales and myself are in it, it really is a Mondo advertisement and creation. His baby. This has never been used or seen. In advertising, you're only ever looking for that one shot. That is how it works. This was just a gem that was left sitting for a few decades.

item.title: Wynn Arms Crossed
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was later in the 1980's. Serious. Semi-angry. "Let's get this photograph and let me be on my way..." I wasn't irritated to have my photograph taken, but I always had other things on my agenda. I had things to do. I wanted to be out skating and stuff. It was more about being outside in an environment that was conducive to action. Being in studios and having photographs and advertisements to shoot was painful sometimes. Some were fun, most were not. Usually, I just wanted to get it over with.

item.title: Wynn Nukeland
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The pipes were built by the Ameron Pipe Company when they were building the San Onofre Nuclear Plant in the late 1970's. We would sneak onto the USMC base on which the pipes sat under the pretext of visiting a brother or cousin in the military. They'd let us on the base and we'd park between the pipes to hide the truck we were driving. We'd drive straight up to the pipe sections and skate. I think we got kicked out once or twice. The military police were pretty cool about it, if I recall. I think that they were intrigued by the whole idea of us riding the huge pipes. They were really big. The sections were gapped. Side by side. We could fly out and launch ourselves pipe to pipe. This is the first place where we could do this. Skaters were flying out of Baldy pipe, but I never saw anyone transfer pipe to pipe until Nukeland. When we flew out of one pipe and into another, we were leaving the ceiling of one and landing high up in the next pipe. Such a thing hadn't existed before. It was really something. Pretty gnarly. Upside down and floating. We defied gravity. The pipes didn't last too long. They caught onto us fast and put them into the ground. When you're trespassing and breaking the law to skate, you have to get it while you can. It never lasts.

item.title: Wynn / Herbst / Bronson Canyon
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was taken by a friend of Wynn's. The photographers name is Bronson Canyon is one of my favorite places to skate in Los Angeles. It is rough and gnarly. The sky, the surface, the G-Turn... it looks cool. You never really see photographs of people skating there. People just don't get it. Bronson Canyon ditch is right below the Hollywood sign. It has been rideable for something like forty years. It is one of the most old school skate spots in Los Angeles.

item.title: Alva Unseen Short
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
ALVA UNSEEN
Tony Alva proudly announces his new book project. Alva Unseen. The book is a photographic journey, complete with Tony's memories and candid observations about a life unfolding. It is a complete look into his private world. His life. His memories. Tony Alva: an icon, a rogue, skateboarder, surfer, musician and so much more. We will be bringing you updates as the book reveals itself.

item.title: SR-91 Corridor Improvement_Carousel
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: "Ride the snake... he's old and his skin is cold..."

item.title: Intersections
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: "We have all been placed on this earth to discover our own path, and we will never be happy if we live someone else's idea of life." - Van Praagh Shawn walked slowly down the alleyway. He had his skateboard, some gear, a bottle of water and the day was just getting started. I was standing beside the truck waiting and when I saw him, I laughed. " You look like shit." What did you do last night... pole dance?" Shawn smiled and said something about my parentage. Peering into the truck, he asked, "What, you didn't bring it?"  I looked at the brooms, buckets and pool draining equipment and couldn't figure out what I'd forgotten. I looked at him questioningly. "You left your 'Style' at home again?"  He quipped. So it began. We loaded up and were on the road. We'd be meeting up with KB and Brandon in awhile, but we had to check a few pools first and bucket another that Shawn had located. [caption id="attachment_20503" align="aligncenter" width="700"] Intersections[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20505" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Squatter's shoebox[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20507" align="aligncenter" width="560"] Choices[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20506" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Elbow[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20509" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Yard Sale[/caption] Shawn is moving to the east coast in a week or so and this was probably going to be one of our last pool missions together for awhile. We had been hunting, draining and skating pools together for about six years. Kindred spirits. I was bummed that he was leaving. He told me, "Life takes everyone in different directions. Sometimes our lives intersect with like-minded people. It is how the story goes..." We pulled onto a side street and looked at a pool. It was a shoebox. There were people squatting inside. I was a ghost. Back in the truck, Shawn told me about a capsule pool that he knew of. "I saw it about five years ago, but it sets in a cluster of houses back a long driveway. I think several families live at the property. There were always cars there. The front house is empty and yesterday, I walked back. It looks pretty good." We were soon walking back the driveway. The house was empty and the morning was still. A dog barked nearby at our intrusion, but quickly lost interest in us and lay back down. It was already growing too hot to care. [caption id="attachment_20511" align="aligncenter" width="584"] We have an appointment[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20513" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Blue Lip[/caption] The pool looked a bit steep but Shawn and I grinned. We liked them that way. There were sheds and garages on the property. There was trash and evidence of homelessness. The place was a bit of a mess. It was fairly easy to clean up the pool though, and we soon were at it... sweeping, bucketing and getting it ready. I phoned Brandon and KB. They were at an intersection just down the street. It was already close to ninety degrees and we sat in the shaded shallow end, taking it all in. Waiting. [caption id="attachment_20515" align="aligncenter" width="494"] Wow! Four whole hours...[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20516" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Dear Santa...[/caption] KB and Brandon showed up and we got into it. A lady soon came up to the rear fence and asked what was going on. She seemed cool with us being there. She lived in one of the houses on the property... "The police have been watching this place because someone broke in. They come by sometimes... I'm just saying." We would take our chances. Nothing new. We started skating and found the juice. The pool was fun. Lines were tapped into. [caption id="attachment_20520" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me / KB[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20521" align="aligncenter" width="584"] KB[/caption] Shortly after, a pretty big dude stuck his head over the back fence. He was standing on the hood of a car parked out there. "You niggers are just having the time of your life, huh?" I -- for one -- am rarely called such a thing and the tone of his voice was far less than friendly, so I answered, "Yes...we are actually." Shawn said something like, "Fun in the sun." He climbed down off of the car and I saw that there were actually two guys outside the fence. His tone and hostility were unmistakable. We were unwelcome. We took a run or two each and I peered through fence, looking to see where they were. Shawn said quietly, "It doesn't matter where they went..."  I looked over at him. He pointed. "The man." A police officer was walking up to the pool. He actually looked relieved to see us... I presumed that in such a neighborhood, he was accustomed to something a bit more violent and nefarious than a couple of old guys skating a pool. He escorted us out. [caption id="attachment_20522" align="aligncenter" width="494"] Escort[/caption] We pulled away and into the morning. Stopping by another pool, I knocked and received no answer. KB suggested a quick barge that he knew of. "In and out. Fifteen minutes and that's all we get." We nodded. Shortly after, we were looking into one of the weirdest pools I'd ever seen. It looked old. 1940's era. The transitions looked like they were hand poured... sloping and strange. The waterfall was super steep. It had a wall running flush on one side, a metal ladder, sharp hip, no tiles... it was a mess and it was perfect. We took about three runs each, KB hit the deathbox and we were soon driving away. [caption id="attachment_20524" align="aligncenter" width="494"] Waterfall[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20525" align="aligncenter" width="584"] KB[/caption] Stopping for drinks and snacks, we talked and decided to hit an old favorite or two. It was super hot and we knew that the rest of the morning was only going to get worse. We wanted to skate as hard as we could before the afternoon heat sapped all of our energies. At the next pool, KB slammed and took one to the elbow. Brandon got some, Shawn bruised the side wall and I pulled a mute. Things were good. The sun was hot. [caption id="attachment_20527" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brandon[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20528" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Shawn[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20529" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me[/caption] The afternoon was upon us. We talked in the shade by the pool. There were boards resting on top of the wall and it provided us with shelter. Grateful. We spoke of our years together riding pools. KB said that this was one of the first pools he ever skated. It was right after the fires in 2003. "I rode this pool and knew that pool skating was something I'd always do." Brandon talked about going out pool skating and riding a half-dozen in a day. Collectively, we have spent many weekends together having fun. I think that is why our lives intersected. We love pool skating. We ended the day at an old reliable. Big, steep, slippery and fun. Blue Haven egg. Soda was purchased and sprayed onto the pool. We soon took everything we had left and put it all out there... and we always would. [caption id="attachment_20532" align="aligncenter" width="584"] KB[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20533" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me[/caption] Thanks to Brandon Wong for the images. Thanks to the core four...  big fun. I'm going to miss you Shawn. I'll see you when you visit and we will keep a few pools ready- Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: With all the crap that arrives in my inbox, the Blue Tile Obsession notifications are always a welcome reprieve; always relished. Thanks for barging and sharing these tales of a life well lived. Om.

item.title: Gary
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20540" align="aligncenter" width="466"] Gary[/caption] My father text me Monday. "Sorry to tell you this, but Gary R. passed away over the weekend." I stood and looked at my phone. I hadn't seen him since after high school. Gary had gone on and done his thing and I had done mine. We had spent a great deal of time together in middle and high school. His family had a farm nearby and Gary had a few older brothers. They had cool cars, motorcycles, snowmobiles, everything. I would hang out with Gary and get to ride around with him and his brothers. His brother Donnie, turned me onto Judas Priest, Motorhead and the Scorpions. He also gave me my first beer. The brothers looked after me and kept me safe. [caption id="attachment_20538" align="aligncenter" width="584"] My ramp / Pennsylvania 1979[/caption] One day, I was trying to build my first half-pipe and Gary gave me one hundred dollars to get plywood. Gary didn't even skate. Seeing that he passed away, made me think about my own mortality. He was my age. Life on life's terms. I think of him now... but I probably  should have reached out a long time ago. I just didn't. Bumming... Don't hesitate to tell people what they mean to you. Someday, it may be too late. Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Amen to that brother. I need to do almost the same thing as you did. I have not seen my My next door Skate bro neighbors from Hacienda Heights, CA since High School. Their dad and them built a killer half pipe in their backyard in 1977. I even have super 8 silent movies of us ripping the broomstick coping on my woodshop single kick, Bennet's and stokers. For those who don't remember, the first kick boards were just flat boards and we nailed on a wood wedge to the back end. Someone can correct me if I am wrong, but I believe they called it a kick because it was such a kick in the butt to ride with it. That silent video is the only proof I have that I was a demon skater back in the day. I later converted it to DVD and take it out and show my teenage son and his friends once in a while. RIP Gary and Rip the wedge kick.

wp:comment.wp:comment_author: Jeff Littlefield HR crew Pacifica CA
wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Words to live by Ozzie words to live by

item.title: Brad Bowman
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_11455" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad Bowman- Image: Sharp[/caption]
Brad Bowman. Style. Legend. He rode for Sims back in the 1970's and he oozed style every time he stood on a skateboard. I asked Lance and Cab to tell us about Brad Bowman. Here is what they had to say. Thanks to Bill Sharp for the images. Skate- Ozzie
Steve Caballero
Brad Bowman... He's my Minki (said in an english accent) what's a Minki? Ask Bert Lamar, Steve Olson, Keith Meek or Scott Foss that same question... it's an inside joke/story. Two words come into my mind when I see Bowman on a skateboard... style and grace! Back in the day, looking through the pages of Skateboarder magazine in the late 70's, he stood out like a sore thumb. Not because it hurt to see him in the magazine, but because he looked so awesome in every skate photo I would see. I don't think the guy has ever taken a bad photo in the magazine! What he wore and how he kept his composure while on his deck was simply amazing and beautiful. I would always look forward to seeing more and more of him in the magazine. You could say he was known as a pretty boy with deep blue eyes, but his skating was just a beautiful and stylish to match.  I remember that I wore a red/white and blue Flyaway helmet, Molley Shorts and even a half shirt because of Brad Bowman. He definitely inspired me in many ways and I also tried to emulate his signature "early release" frontside airs at one time.  The dude was rad then and is just as rad today! I had the privilege to skate with Brad once again in Malibu and I must say, it sure was a pretty sight to see!
thanks,
Cab
[caption id="attachment_11456" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Brad at Malibu - Image: Sharp[/caption] Lance Mountain Brad Bowman. Back then, skateboarding was changing fast.  Skateboarders were coming out of other places besides Santa Monica.  They were ripping and they looked great. That was the first thing I thought. These guys looked good when they skated. Skateparks were opening and new faces were being exposed. Brad had an earlier photo at Reseda in  Skateboard World. It was the Christmas issue of 1977.  That photograph  was the first one of him that I remember. Backyard square pool, frontside wheeler on the split gutter. We watched as Brad went on to be one of the mot stylish skaters of all time. He also had one of the most memorable interviews in Skateboarder magazine ever. I remember thinking he was always right at the top  of contest placings throughout Gold Cup. Lets not forget his love of New Wave and his early release frontside airs. - Lance Mountain I posted this in 2012 but thought it needed reposted. I have skated with Brad a few times and spoken to him at length. He is one of the most mellow and stylish legends I've ever met. - Ozzie

item.title: pine
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: At Oasis with two of my pals, Dave Andrecht and Bobby Garcia. Sunny day. It was good for shooting some photographs. Alot of times, unless I wanted something specific to be shot, Jim Goodrich just took out his camera and started shooting the session to see what became of it. Lots of memories though, just looking at the picture... Hobie wrist guard, O.G. Protec, leather Rector pads ... IPS sticker.  At that time, I was riding for ACS Trucks and Kryptonic Wheels. It was me, Salba, Malba and Dunlop on the team. D. David Morin was our team manager for Kryptonics. We had some good times back then.
