item.title: Tony Alva / Rhino Photo/ Gonzos
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Senor Gonzales. He was an actor on television. He was in shows like Bonanza and Perry Mason. His entire family lived in that house. Three generations lived there. Ray Flores introduced me to the pool as he knew the family. At first we were sneaking into the backyard but he caught us once and chased us out with a butcher knife. It's funny that you see us here and he's standing on my board. I'm all chummy with him. This is much later in the Gonzales pool history. I think the image is from 1999. Mr. Gonzales died soon after this photograph was taken. The surface of the pool was one of the best that we ever had from back then. There was not one kink in the entire pool. It's a flawless right-hand kidney pool. It was perfect for skateboarding. Besides the Dog Bowl, it was my favorite pool. I don't think there will ever be another like it. Every square inch of Gonzales pool was rideable. We replaced coping and maintained it. Ultimately, I became a full-fledged member of the Gonzales family. Once he passed away, I went back one more time and it was when we filmed the Lords of Dogtown, After we filmed, I had the pool refurbished and repaired so that the family could have it going as a swimming pool again. I did that for the family. I heard Gonzales pool was empty again a few summers ago but I never returned. I never felt the need to. Respect.

item.title: Grant / Hastings
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Vancouver. Hastings. We were partying hard back then. I was riding some funky shoes. I was designing them for a company overseas at the time. I still have a pair of them somewhere at home. I didn't follow through with any of it and I'm happy that I stuck with Vans. It's funny how the shoes match my helmet. Hastings was cool though. You can see that there is such a mixture of skaters hanging out and riding. There is a very cool scene in Canada. There is a huge mixture of ethnicities and different people. Older skaters, young, street guys... They have a great deal of concrete to ride up there, but the best time to go is in the summer. The rest of the year is cold and very wet. If you go there in the summertime, it is amazing. I remember one day, Paulo Diaz, Matt Fields, Joey Tershay and I were up there. We had these chocolate eggs that had pulverized magic mushrooms inside and we each had one. We called them , "El chocolate". We'd take a bite, smoke some weed and go, "Okay. Where are we going?" We then tried to ride ten concrete parks in one day. Higher than you could ever believe... skating. We'd ride past each other high-fiving and yelling, "El chocolate". I don't even see how we got park to park. It was crazy. The experiences of Canada.

item.title: Grant Thrashin
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is how Dave Duncan and all of those guys started the Daggers thing. I made the boards. The Daggers started as a fictitious team for the film Thrashin'. It was like a West Side Story type of thing for the movie. The Daggers are the bad guys. The Daggers were, Dave Duncan, myself, Eddie Reategui, Jesse Martinez, Christian Hosoi, Masao, Robert Russler and Mark Munski. The Daggers were brought about by the film Thrashin' but those guys didn't want to let it die. We were the bad guys. The Jets and the Sharks. We borrowed alot of the look from a team that did extra work on the film, especially the downhill section of the film. The team was from San Francisco and they were called Jaks team. They influenced our look on the film. That is why I'm dressed the way I am. I am an honorary Jaks team member, as is Mondo. I wore pads because we were doing some super fast downhill scenes. We were filming these crazy races at almost forty miles per hour. I think I'd need pads if I was going to take a fall at those speeds.

item.title: Grant Dogbowl Pasadena
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Two hundred thousand dollars. When I see this pool, I think about how much it cost them to build the pool for the film, Lords of Dogtown. It was the best pool ever. Are you kidding me? It was built better than any skatepark pool. It was perfect. Every inch of that pool was rideable. We did make the shallow end a bit mellower so the actors could get from point A to point B. It wasn't exactly like the Dog Bowl in any way, shape or form, but it worked for what we needed. You can see by the way I'm coming over the hip that it was the best hip ever. Floaty. You could fly over that thing. You can see that I'm not done there... My line keeps going. This isn't an exit. You can also see that the pool was deep. Ten feet. It broke Griffin Collins leg in two. Catherine Hardwicke fell into it during filming and ended up in the hospital for awhile. Lance Mountain, Tim Trudell and I put our heads together and came up with this for the final scene in the film. When you see the pool in the film, it is like the Taj Mahal of skateboarding. Lance ruled that pool. I have to give him props. He had a great deal to do with the building of it and he ripped. Out of everyone, he was the best. They ended filming and dozed it. There wasn't even a drain built into it. The owners wanted a lap pool put in after filming was over. Basically, that was the deal. Build it, film, destroy the pool and replace it with a lap pool. Crazy. It basically cost them a quarter million dollars to build the pool for that movie. I don't know of any other story like that in skateboarding. It was private, invite only. There were security guys at the gate. No trespassing. We got to ride and that was that. It is gone and done. This is why I love the photograph. It reminds me of everything from that film.

item.title: MRZ Jon Jon
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is a really cool looking photograph because of the shadow. The image makes the pool look a bit bigger than it really is. It is pretty small and tight. The pool looks like a teardrop... a musical fretboard. With the lighting, it is really pretty. John F. Kennedy Jr. once swam in this pool when he was a law intern. That is an interesting fact. It was funny. The owner was sitting there chain-smoking and watching us. She was so cool. She had bought us donuts and coffee. She kept trying to get me to eat a donut. I was like, "No thanks." I can't really eat donuts. When you are my age and trying to stay active and healthy, eating donuts is not conducive to keeping your energy up. I stick with stuff that works for me. That's probably why I no longer smoke weed. It once worked for me, but no longer. This photograph is also a great reminder of another thing. It was just Ozzie, me, Lance and MRZ. Early morning session. We are all having fun. It was sober morning and it was a few good friends and we were all on point. We were skating and having fun because we love it. No other reason. This pool was not really all that good. The photograph is good, but the pool is small and tight. We didn't care. We were having a good time anyway. The one-wheeler photograph is so far into the shallow end. It was really vert right there. It was such a bomb drop. After I made this, we went to lunch. I don't think I could've done anything better. A perfect end to a perfect session.

item.title: MRZ Malibu Oceanview
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I think that this is one of the most beautiful shots ever taken of me. It looks like I'm surfing on concrete. That's what it looks like. Especially if you are privy to a place like Angelo's. It was built just for skateboarding. You have this perfect pool, the ocean, palm trees... This is Californication at its finest. This is from another private session as well. These photographs are our private moments. There was no one around. It was just us on a sunny day in Malibu, riding a perfect clover pool. It simply doesn't get any better than this. Heaven on earth.

item.title: MRZ ARTWORK
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is a painting I did for the gallery at Alva in Little Ethiopia. We were having a Love & Guts art show and I wanted to do a painting for it. It is Navajo-inspired artwork. I painted here in the backyard in Beverly Hills. It is very simple. I think that the lines and the colors are great. It is the largest painting I've ever done. It has a traditional American Indian influence. We sold it that night. It is hanging in a Vans store out in Las Vegas, I think.

item.title: Wynn Alva Clothing
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: We were shooting advertisements like this with Raul Vega back then. This reminds me of what we were doing at the time. One of Wynn's strengths is shooting products. He's known for his commercial photography. This was an Alva advertisement for the Alva Action clothing line in the 1980's. That's a great deal of neon! That shit would be super popular right now. That stuff was forty years ahead... Wayne Woods designed the clothing. I rarely wore it unless they needed me to put something on for an advertisement or something. It sold in Bloomingdale's and places like that. It started turning into a big deal. Then it just fizzled. It wasn't meant to be. That was definitely the wrong direction to take Alva into that New Wave fashion thing... it was a poor decision. Sometimes, money sends you in directions you shouldn't go. My business partner thought it would be the next big thing. Which, it wasn't. We caused a stir but that was it. In skating, our products must have form and function. The clothing really lacked this. Function wasn't happening back then at all. That's why I think it would do better now. People wear neon while running, riding bikes and motorcycles... So they are visible on busy streets. It would prove more useful now.

item.title: Wynn Saint Moritz
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The Palace Hotel. I don't even recall doing this but I guess the grass must've been pretty even and steep for me to try bombing it... I had softer wheels at the time. That town, Saint Moritz, is stunning. It is in the Swiss Alps and it really is an amazing place. It's also very expensive to do anything there. You have to have mega-dollars to stay there. Amazing experience. No one skateboarded there. No one. I don't think that there was another skateboard in that entire town. We were driving through on our way to Italy. We had lunch, took a few photographs. If you ever have the chance to go to Saint Moritz, you should go. Wynn Miller, Pete Zender, myself and a local guide were on the tour. The local guide was a toy vendor that started selling Alva skateboards. He sold so many, he invited us over. I was nineteen years old and life was pretty amazing.

item.title: Bolster / Del Mar Contest
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This photograph is old school. Look at the holes in my shoes and the ass of my jeans. I've got a sticker covering the hole so my ass isn't showing. I'm riding Cadillac wheels with open ball bearings and a Zephyr board. This is 1975 and my last year in high school. This is at Del Mar and it was our first contest as a team on Z- Flex. Such a 1970's photograph. Look at all the little surfer chicks. I see Ty Page in the background... He's probably watching us and thinking, "Oh man... I'm fucked." When it was our turn to skate, we rode like we did at home. It didn't matter to us if it resonated with the other skaters or judges, it resonated with us. We were shredding. We just showed up and schralped. We didn't even really do freestyle stuff. We were like, "Okay... It's our turn?" Then we'd do crazy slides and turns. We just ripped. No plan. I think Jay Adams did some handstands, but I didn't. I didn't do any red-faced tricks until I got on Logan earth Ski. I started doing them because I knew I'd get more points from the judges in Freestyle. Pretty classic photograph. It doesn't get any more classic than this.

item.title: Lucia / Ozzie Photo
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I really love this photograph. I am riding an original Alva Surfcraft board and I was out at third point with Glen Horn. Glen is a great surfer and it was only the two of us in the water. You were up on the cliffs and had borrowed Lucia's camera and long lens. You captured everything perfectly as I was driving towards the second point. I'm carving and so is the pelican. Overcast. It was just started to clear up that morning. I can see that the swell was starting to pick up. Once the swell came in, the waves were really fun.

item.title: Return to Buddha
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20927" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kent Senatore[/caption] Bill Sharp and I met up with a publisher today. On the way back, I pointed up into the hills and said, "You know, the Buddha pool is right up that street." Bill nodded and smiled. He knew where it was... generally. After all, he'd been there in the summer of 1976 and 1977 when it was first skated. He had shot photographs of Kent Senatore, Jerry Valdez, Ralph Valencia and Marc Smith. I phoned the owners granddaughter and asked if I could bring Bill by the house to look at the pool and say "Hello". She agreed and we were soon standing beside the pool. Bill hadn't been in this backyard in over thirty five years. I made the introductions with the granddaughter and then she showed us a copy of Skateboard World magazine with the Buddha Pool article from 1977. She still had it in the house. She said her uncle had brought it by. "I guess he thought that it was pretty cool." [caption id="attachment_20928" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ralph Valencia[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20929" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Buddha Pool[/caption] The granddaughter went on to tell us that the skateboarders trespassing in the pool all those years ago, had been a real issue for the family back then. Things had been stolen and there was vandalism. She quickly pointed out that this may have been done by people other than the skaters... but who knew? [caption id="attachment_20930" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bill and Dina[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20934" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Marc Smith[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20935" align="aligncenter" width="320"] Bill Sharp looking at the changes...[/caption] We looked through the magazine and it was remarkable to see all the changes in the landscape and the trees over the ensuing thirty five years. She then asked Bill to sign the magazine for her. Bill was humble and did so. I was stoked. It was cool to look on such a scene and know that at one time, this family may have felt ill will towards skateboarders, but things have come full circle and all ended well. Thank you to Bill Sharp for the photographs, the family at the Buddha for taking the time and thank you for reading. Skate - Ozzie [caption id="attachment_20931" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bill Sharp[/caption] [embed]https://ozzieausband.wordpress.com/2014/06/05/the-buddha-pool/[/embed]

item.title: 5f855281-3a98-45ca-af09-e2cf6624f22c
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.excerpt:encoded: Bill Sharp looking at the changes...

item.title: Return to Magoo's
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: He sat on the side of the bed and shivered. Bones aching. His nose was running and his stomach spasmed, a convulsing knot. Drug life. He pondered. The oncoming dark? The element had become everything. Angelic. Insidious and sensual... Magoo slipped the rubber tourniquet around his right forearm arm and squeezed. What veins remained in that arm, began to bulge and thrum. They cried out like tiny mouths...  There is no hell that compares to opiate withdrawal. Magoo knew...  his legs trembled. A puncture, a pullback, blood spilled oily and vivid into the syringe. He pushed with one finger and felt the drugs piss down his spinal cord. Killed. A bit at a time. There would be no other view. After his last arrest, he had finished eighteen months and was cut loose from the Penitentiary early. Overcrowding. The weapons violations were what really fucked him. The judge didn't like him. Magoo didn't care. He didn't really like himself very much either... What was to like? He had returned to the house in the San Fernando Valley two weeks ago. His parents had given it to him in the 1970's. A sister in Phoenix had kept it locked up and in the family name while he rotted away behind bars. "Nice of her..." he thought. During his heyday, he had floated her loans of a few thousand dollars from time to time. It was okay with him. He had money piled in shoeboxes. He actually didn't even know what to do with it sometimes... That had been back then. The good old days. There certainly were no shoeboxes of money laying around now. The heroin lulled him. He lit a cigarette and idly sat in a chair. The sun glimmered through his window. A ceiling fan spun in a lazy arc above him. Tireless. His eyes felt heavy and his palms itched. Drifting. Awhile later, Magoo heard a noise in the backyard. He reached the sliding glass door in three quick strides. Someone was in the swimming pool... ' What the fuck are you doing? You're trespassing!" A head slowly appeared as the person walked up out of the deep end of the empty pool. He grinned sheepishly at Magoo. "Hey man" he mumbled. Magoo laughed in spite of himself. "Picciolo. "I should've known it would be you..." Thanks to William Sharp for the image. Skate - Ozzie [embed]https://ozzieausband.wordpress.com/2014/07/20/magoos/[/embed] [embed]https://ozzieausband.wordpress.com/2014/11/04/the-fall-of-magoo/[/embed]

item.title: Stan Sharp / Freeformer Number 1
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The guy standing there is Donnie Branker. He promoted the event and represented the Free Former guys. I guess he thought that Ty Page and the Free Former skaters were going to come in and sweep the 1977 Long Beach contest. I set a World Record for barrel jumping and did well overall. I was just giving them a lesson: "You guys are smalls and I'm big.". I had my fedora, Alva shirt, Rector shorts, argyle socks, trophies and paycheck... That is a total attitude shot right there. It's a "Fuck you" photograph.

item.title: Stan Sharp / Coliseum
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles Coliseum. It looks like a college football game. It could be a professional game but I can't recall. I think it was a half time Pepsi Team demonstration. That is the 360 Sportswear ramp. I think I see Tony Jetton and Lonnie Toft beside the ramp. They rode in the Pepsi Team demonstrations. You can see them standing there beside the ramp looking up at me and I'm showing them how to do it... You go straight up the support beam on the centerline and pivot. It is the fastest part of that ramp. That is like math. Straight up the middle. It was sketchy. The ramp might look good for photographs, but that thing was a hunk of junk. Dangerous. Plexiglass. It was narrow and flexed... If you fell, you went down and got hurt. The surface tore off your pads. It is pretty crazy that there are forty or fifty thousand people there. That's a hell of a crowd to be watching someone skate. Things were really starting to happen back then.

item.title: Fineman Oxnard
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: When Oxnard opened up, our entire crew would go up the coast and skate there together. We would invade that place. Jimmy Plumer, Billy Yeron, Jay Adams, Shogo Kubo, Bob Biniak... all of us. We'd all go as a group. It was a pretty good bowl but it didn't have real pool coping and tiles. The coping that was on the bowl worked though. It was hand poured lip. This was during the time when skateboard evolution was occurring. I'm riding a wider deck but I think the Power Pivot device on the tail is funky. We were the first guys to go to Oxnard and do airs like this. Oxnard had some pretty good guys though. Jerry Valdez, Jack Waterman, Lonnie Toft. We would drive up there, skate the place and get the fuck out of there. It was a long drive for us. An entire day. Oxnard was full on agriculture back then. There was really nothing going on. It always had a heavy Latino culture and still does. I think Craig Fineman lived in Oxnard back then. He was an amazing surf photographer and a really nice guy.

item.title: Bryce Fuel TV
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: There was a Circle Jerks gig on Fuel TV. You can see that the bass player Zander Schloss has his bass cabinet in the back. I brought my dog Earl. He looks like a baby. He'll be ten years old next week. He trusts me... balancing on my arm. It's funny. He has a good life. I'm wearing my Skatanic Rednecks hat. They're the worst band in the world. Dave Reul gave it to me. They are noisy and awful. I just like the hat. Interestingly, the Circle Jerks played a great show and a few years after this photograph was taken, I was playing in a band with Greg Hetson who is the guitarist for the Circle Jerks.

item.title: Bryce Burnside
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I'm at Burnside. It is 1993. Looking at the board I'm riding, you can see the changes that were happening in skateboarding. I'm doing a mute grab over the hip and the Burnside park looks pretty primitive at this stage. It would later have multiple additions added. It is currently much different. I'd never ride a board like that now. It looks like I was nose sliding it and everything. The deck is all scraped up. Total period photograph. It was a progressive time for me. I suppose that I wanted to keep up with the pack. Twenty five years ago... It seems like yesterday.

item.title: Bryce Oregon
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I look like I'm from Oregon in this photograph. That's about as big as my beard gets. You could start a rumor with this photograph. "Tony Alva moved to Kelso, Oregon and is living in a Silverstream RV". This image would prove it. Living in the woods, eating bear meat and going full 'Revenant'. I love this photograph. The place is like a tea garden. It is so peaceful. The feeling of it. Zen. Northwest meets Dog Town style.

item.title: Bryce Dreads
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Nilton Neves, Joey Tershay and I. We are in Oceanside at my old skate shop on Wisconsin Avenue. Behind the shop was a basketball hoop and we'd sit out there and smoke out. These two guys are fantastic. They have golden hearts. They are both amazing skateboarders as well. I can see that I'm about twenty pounds heavier from all of the beer drinking I was doing back then. Like they say, we have to go through all of the past in order to get where we are.

item.title: Lance Willis Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This is such a gloomy winter day. Lance really lit it up well. It looks cold. That's something you don't always see in pool skating photographs from California. That's a pretty good backside air. I loved doing backside airs in square pools. They aren't too easy because you have to pop and pull away from the coping. If you don't, you'll hang up and get your bell rung. That's probably why I'm wearing a helmet. I'm actually wearing full gear. I was going for it. Geared up and ready to fly.

item.title: Lance Corral Pool
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: This was a famous pool in the San Fernando Valley called the Corral Pool. We rode it in the 1970's. It disappeared off of the radar for awhile and then someone got it going again in the early 1990's. They called it the Crack Pool. I guess the house was abandoned and some crack heads lived there. It was an ugly place but the pool was good. Someone painted it blue. I recall it being slippery. You can see the paint on my wheels. You had to be careful. I look pretty relaxed in the photograph. I'm pretty sure I had that grind... "I got this." That looks like it was a pretty good session going on, though I can't tell who else is there. Just another heavy pool session in the San Fernando Valley. I always love those.

item.title: Lance Indy Grind
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: I remember that this was right when I started learning these. Indy Pivot. I was like, "Hey Lance, you gotta get this man..." If this was frontside, it would be a total stinkbug. I can see that my thumb is controlling it. I like reaching across the rail. I saw Eric Dressen reach across his nose and go to tail... I wanted to try a version of that. It feels cool when you're grinding Indy like that. Locked in. It almost feels like I'm upside down. I love that feeling. I like this photograph but those pants need to go. Total Guatemalan jungle pants... Everything changes. That is one of the cool things about looking through these images. You can see where we were, where we were headed and what we are about. Life.

item.title: Old Bones Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_20989" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Alison & Christian[/caption] Christian Potter visited with his wife Alison this past week. They flew in from the UK. We immediately had a super pool day out and everyone had a stellar time. Christian came to visit me about two years ago. On that visit, we rode Ridiculous pool, Gorilla pool, Malibu, Arto's and Baldy among other things. When Christian returned to the UK, he built a bowl in a barn with some like-minded friends. They created their own scene. After riding several times a week in their bowl, Christian was more than ready to get into some pools and parks on this recent trip. Immediately, I saw a difference in his skating. He jumped into the shallow end and promptly handled business. He was grinding over the light and nabbed his first side ladder grinds as well. [caption id="attachment_20990" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bronson Canyon[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20991" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Etnies[/caption] There were a few days when I had to work and MRZ came up and took Christian and Alison around. They ended up in Bronson Canyon ditch, Etnies and Arto's. I met them at Arto's after work one day. BLKPRJKT came along and Jason Jesse showed up. We all rolled around trying new things. The day was bright and perfect. Happiness. [caption id="attachment_20992" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Arto's[/caption] [caption id="attachment_20993" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian, Jason Jesse and Arto[/caption] It was good to show our friends around Los Angeles. It is a place I love and call home. I'm always happy to share pools and stoke out my friends. Thanks for the visit Christian. Good to meet Alison as well. Until next time... Thank you to MRZ for the images. Skate and love your friends before it's too late- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_20994" align="aligncenter" width="584"] That's right...[/caption]

item.title: Two Thousand Words.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5687" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Chris Miller[/caption] "Two Thousand Words."--  Chris Miller 1990

item.title: Thinking
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_5954" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Aaron Scott[/caption] The silence of the foothills & the woods lay like a brooding cloak about my soul. I was walking around in the hills of the Angeles National Forest  I skulked & kicked at pine needles. The black shadows seemed immovable as the weight of neglect that overhung the nearby city of San Bernardino. Vague ancestral dreads stirred at the back of my mind; for I had been born in the pine woods & thirty years of roaming the wastelands of the world had not erased their shadows. I shuddered at the old tales of witches & goblins. I think Goethe wrote in 'Faust' that "Such was I once, before dark ways I sought and with fell words a curse on living wrought." This particular passage reminded me of a poem by W.H. Auden. He wrote- "A psychopathic god: I and the public know What all schoolchildren learn, Those to whom evil is done Do evil in return." As I walked through the darkened treeline & noticed the small, shy creatures scurrying away at my intrusion into their world, I thought on the insanity of humankind. Why are some consumed with such a lust for control? Why is there such a drive for power over others? Is is because these individuals feel a  lack of control over themselves that they compensate outwardly? I think  history has proven that it ends up as nothing in the end. I peer through the pines & see a Hawk winging its way across a granite outcropping. It soared above the pettiness of man. I feel childish as I envy the Hawk & its freedom. Thinking... Thanks to Brian Fick for the image- Skate- Ozzie

item.title: Style is forever.
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Night. Pennsylvania. 1979. The sleet hisses off of the windows of my bedroom. It is December & it has been storming for three days. Periodically,  huge green snow plow trucks would rumble slowly past-- tire chains clanking--to scrape the country roads. The trucks yellow revolving roof lights  bounce off my bedroom walls as it moves off into the darkness. I hear the distant whining of a snowmobile, as someone slides through the fields. I am glad to be inside and turn my attention back to my magazine. Skateboarder. I am noticing something. Some of the riders have such a great presence. In the images, style was clearly captured. Not to denigrate anyone... but, when I see a photograph of Tony Alva doing a frontside air & then an image of George Orton, I instinctively know which looks better. Style. Flow. Expression. I flip the pages & come upon an image of Brad Bowman. He is skating a backyard pool in the San Fernando valley. Brad Bowman is balanced precariously on two wheels, edging across a death box. His arms are quiet, hands  perfect, eyes cast downward toward the drain, watching his line. Descent. The image is a moment of style & flow, perfectly captured in time. It is everything I want to be. I close the magazine & look outside. I am acutely aware that style is so important.  The glass is cold against my fingers. Christmas lights sparkle & reflect. Snow is piling up on the roof outside my window. The  lights shimmer & the rest of the world seems far away. I feel like I am on a distant planet. Cold. Wind. Ice. Loneliness. Casting a sideways glance, I see my Sims Taperkick and reach for it. The storm will end. Soon... [caption id="attachment_6867" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Pat Ngoho & Brad Bowman -proving that 'Style' is forever.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_6868" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Pat Ngoho- Marina Del Rey-1979[/caption] [caption id="attachment_6869" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Pat Ngoho- Shakeys- circa: 2004[/caption] [caption id="attachment_6870" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Brad Bowman - Spring Valley -1979[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_6871" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Brad Bowman - Malibu- 2010[/caption]

item.title: Jerry Valdez & Friends
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_21000" align="aligncenter" width="584"] The Jer[/caption] Jerry Valdez. If there was ever a more perfect example of a skateboarding legend, I haven't heard of it. Jerry Valdez ripped pools, pipes and parks into easily digested pieces. What he didn't like, he spat out for the weaker to suckle on. Frontside insanity at eleven o'clock in the shadowy realms of the twenty-two foot Arizona pipes, San Fernando Valley pool play mostly above coping while most struggled above the scumline, frontside inverts, frontside rock-n-rolls and incomprehensibly high lines on Baldy's flat wall were all his and his alone. He was called a "Val" because of his affiliation with Val Surf, yet Jerry was Hollywood -- as he puts it -- in Yearbooks. He grew up in Hollywood and went to school there. He rode everything and was a ruler from the starting gun. [caption id="attachment_21001" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Angelo[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21002" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain 'Tail Tap' under the watchful eye of its originator[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21004" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian Cooper[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21003" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad Bowman[/caption] Now, some forty years later, a few of us gravitated to Angelo's Malibu clover to put down some lines with the birthday legend. Brad Bowman, Jim Gray, Wesley, Angelo, Christian Cooper, Chris and Tommy, Lance Mountain, MRZ, Tony Alva and I were in attendance. [caption id="attachment_21006" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Happy Birthday Jer[/caption] We pulled grinds, laughed and the hard line crap-talk was a mile a minute. When Jerry is around, he pushes you to skate harder, pushes buttons and shoves the insanity level past the edge. It's where he's most comfortable. I love you dude. Happy Birthday Jer. Thanks to everyone and thank you to MRZ for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_21007" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21005" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me / Brad Bowman[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Reblogged this on Gøne ツ Ska†îηg and commented: The Jer's B-Day!

RAD! Thanks for another great article, Oz.
Sumdumsurfer

item.title: Stripped Away
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_21039" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ray Zimmerman taking one for the team.[/caption] Why? Why do we seek out filthy, neglected backyard swimming pools? What compulsion drives us in a relentless search for others? We clean out rotting fruit, garbage, landscape debris, moldering grass clippings, endless beer bottles and cans, dog feces, urine and virtually any other putrefying thing you care to imagine. The stench is horrifying. [caption id="attachment_21040" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle and I[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21041" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle, Rick Stine, me and Brad Bowman.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21042" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Final Countdown[/caption] Dead animals, paint, oil drums, car transmissions, dead dogs, household appliances and -- the myth that still lingers -- a dumped homicide victim, have all been seen at one time or another. Pool skaters regularly unearth completely filled in pools. Jeremiah Risk and Rodney Rodrigues put it all on the line. Nude Bowl, Buena Vista, Pala... Action. Not words. They dug out the Nude Bowl and Rodney was responsible -- I believe -- for the others being rideable again. Devout. Pool skating is a minor religion. [caption id="attachment_21051" align="aligncenter" width="429"] Brad Bowman[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21044" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21045" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey Phillips[/caption] Pool skating is difficult. I think it may be the most difficult discipline in skateboarding. You have to locate a pool. Drain and clean it. Figure it out. Every pool is a puzzle. Every single wall is different. Pools are humbling. I've seen some of the best pool skaters in the world, like - Tony Farmer, Ben Raybourn, Kevin Kowalski, Matt Dyke, Cody Lockwood, Mason Merlino, Brad McClain, Skreech, Mark Partain, Steve Alba, Robbie Russo, Shaggy Palmer, Chris Livingston, Sean Mazza, Al Brunelle, Grant Taylor... and every single one of these skaters have been humbled by pools. [caption id="attachment_21047" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me[/caption] Stripped away. Pride and ego. Pools are the great equalizer. So, why do we do this thing that we do? I think that it is a combination of things. It is the challenge of riding something that was never intended for skating, it is the lawlessness and excitement, it is the purity and it is the fun. The satisfaction that comes with going over obstacles in pools cannot easily be put into words. It is not a perfect wall, pristine surface, skatepark stunt. You have to figure out how to get the speed and the angle to pick a line that puts you over... a puzzle to work out. Then, you have to stay on. The simplest thing, becomes everything. [caption id="attachment_21043" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick Stine[/caption] Stripped away. We strip away the filth to reveal the surface. Then we strip away our fear and ego... and that is where the fun is found. Thank you to Brad Bowman, Rick Stine, Al Brunelle and Corey Phillips for the hard work in the heat and a huge thank you to MRZ for suffering through the afternoon to capture what is hard to put into words. Skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: BB!! Big Al!! Corey Philips!! Awesome........
Uh huh ...
"Pools are the great equalizer." I've thought that many times. Nice one Oz!
Great read.
You guys really should use rubber gloves when doing that! :-)

item.title: Blue
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: A dirty sun had perched over the city as he reached the thickest part of its guts. The news was blue. A grey sky overhead colored his every word. Brain boiling black. Fingernails bit into his palm. The freeway was a blur of metal and motion. His dark eyes drifted left and right. Exhaust fumes were a balm to his troubled mind. At seventeen, he knew his end was close. No Medicare for him. The thought of growing old, church functions, ice cream socials and Viagra filled him with a raw red panic. His blood thrummed. He was the kind of kid that others called, "Strange". Snorting in laughter, he changed lanes almost hitting the car beside him. Middle finger sign language passed between them. "Fuck. What's so strange about Sigur Ros and poetry?" As far as he was concerned, they were the ones that were fucking strange... slaves to parents, schools, jobs and expectations. He had read a book by Talbot Mundy who said, "The only safe thing I know is to follow opportunity and leave others behind to do the worrying. More people die lingering, ghastly deaths in arm-chairs and in bed than anywhere.” He fully agreed. He went down an off ramp, slowed as he passed an accident and pulled into a line of glass-fronted buildings just off the freeway. Sitting in his car, he calmed himself. "Jesus..." He liked accidents. Hurt and happiness are one. Always. His reflection looked back at him. Empty eyed. He was a book with no pictures. Only mirrors. He reflected nothing and everything. He was whatever anyone wanted him to be. No identity. Cipher. Whatever caused him to end up like this, he didn't know. He always felt dead inside. His one emotion was wrath... Going into a bookstore, he purchased a journal and paid for it with a stolen credit card. The clerk must've been stoned. He kept up some happy talk to distract him, commenting on the Phish t-shirt that the clerk was wearing. "Oh yeah, Phish bro...  great band." Had the clerk looked closely, he would have noticed that the customer certainly didn't resemble a female named Cynthia Dottingham. He walked out of the store smiling. Underneath his sweatshirt were two books of poetry by Baudelaire and Bukowski. "He had it coming. If you're too dumb to do your job right, you deserve to be ripped off." Driving across town, he spotted a young schoolgirl on a corner with her mother. "Not bad." he thought. He stopped by his friend's apartment and bought a shard and took the speed home to smoke it. Empty house. Empty street. Empty pool. His yard was full of trash and junk that his mom's boyfriends left laying around. She'd come home from the bar with some shithead and he'd soon move in. A few months later, another. Then another. He didn't even talk to her anymore. He'd be eighteen soon and he'd never allow "It" to tell him what to do ever again. He exhaled and looked out the back window. The dirty glass was cracked. His brain squirmed and his thoughts moved like ants on a hot summer sidewalk. The old pool squatted there in the weeds and grass. When he was a boy, they would swim in it. He shook his shaggy head. He couldn't recall the last time. It was a shame... at least the neighborhood kids would come talk and hang out. It was the only cool thing about being a kid that he could remember. He mattered. He fit in. No more... Thumbing a stray strand of black hair from his eyes, he picked up the pipe again. Thank you to MRZ and Rick Stine. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_21069" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Al Brunelle[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21070" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Brad Bowman[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21071" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey Phillips[/caption]

item.title: Raining
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Jon Bolduc
Andy and I had just flown into LAX the night before, the weather for the weekend looked bleak...a rarity in Southern California. So we knew despite our jet lag from our cross-country travel that we needed to get on it right away. We had already hit two pools that morning before the skies opened and rain ended our session.
We had taken cover and a much-needed food break at a nearby taco stand and planned our strategy for the following day. Ozzie, Rick, Andy, and I knew our only chance to avoid the rain on Saturday would be to head east into the desert. There was a chance it may storm out there as well as it seemed rain was inevitable for many parts of the Los Angeles area.   Although, we didn't really have any other real options since riding an indoor skatepark never seems like a good idea. In fact, it would be a bummer to fly to California to ride in a cage with a bunch of jocks working on their stunts, we could most certainly do that on the east coast. But that's not skateboarding...or at least the kind of skateboarding I'm interested in doing. So with that, it was decided pool mission in the desert and we were going to go for it! Saturday morning at first light our crew assembled to head east. Marlon had to bail on the pool mission since his wife had made plans to attend an all day rock concert (or something like that) leaving him on dad duty for the day. Corey and Ray rounded out our solid six man crew.
[caption id="attachment_21086" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bulldog[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21089" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey[/caption] The skate gods smiled upon us that day as we didn't see any threat of rain until dusk. We moved quickly and swiftly from pool to pool.  We looked at some and passed, we drained and cleaned others, and of course we skated as many as we could. Who did what, who ruled the pool, which pool was better, etc. These details are unimportant...what matters is that we all had a blast, skating, laughing, and sharing the stoke. It was beyond a rad day!  It was perfect!
[caption id="attachment_21088" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick[/caption] Pool riding is all about finding perfection in the imperfection. Backyard pool skating was and will continue to be 100% pure skateboarding.  All day, everyone was stoked.  We were with friends riding backyard swimming pools that had never been intended to be ridden. How rad is that? The feeling of riding a backyard pool is hard to describe (or at least for me it is difficult to put into words) but what I can say is that it is a feeling that I have never experienced riding in a skatepark and for that reason alone I will always be a pool skater. - Bulldog Andy Neal Skateboarding is fun.  The first time I stepped on the wooden toy was in 1984 and I was ten years old.  The feeling that I got from skating was pure joy and happiness.  Not much gives me this feeling other than my family, my daughter, and some of my friendships. In 1984, my terrain was the streets of Poolesville, MD and my grandmother's long asphalt driveway. Eventually, the terrain progressed to ramps built by me and my skateboard family of that time.  I would look at my idols in Thrasher and Transworld and read every word in every issue.  I was always drawn to the images of skaters riding in backyard pools and all I wanted to do was ride them.  A few years later I rode my first pool in Poolesville.  Fast forward to 2016. Skateboarding is still fun.  I can't stop.  At 41, I still feel like that ten year old smiling from ear to ear from that pure joy and happiness that riding provides.  I go to California once or twice a year now to search for the plaster and to hang with the owner of this blog who has become one of my dearest friends and my personal SoCal meteorologist.  Pretty easy job, it hasn't rained in LA since 1935 and it's always 78 degrees, right?  Wrong!  "And then the rains came." But, we outsmarted old man Nino by heading into the desert to ride some sun parched plaster.  At first entry, not a word was spoken; every part was perfectly played out by those in the crew, who just, knew what to do.  A well-oiled machine. [caption id="attachment_21095" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Andy[/caption] We handled the situation in ten minutes. Pure Fun... Repeat.  Wheels rolled, stories were told, and the tacos were bold.  I am grateful for skateboarding and my pool pals, both old and new.  The day, put simply, was perfection.  If there is one thing that skateboarding has taught me, it is not to take things too seriously and just have fun.     - Andy Neal Rick Stine
Saturday morning. 5:30 am wake up with a 7:00 am meet up. Palm Springs was on or radar this morning. Pulling into town sometime about 9:00 am, the attack began with almost military-like precision. Two pools were cleaned out and on the drying list by 9:30 am. This had to be one of the best executed double barge missions that I could remember, and this was only the beginning of a very successful barge springs mission.
I salute my brothers Ozzie, Bulldog, Andy, Corey and MRZ.  - Rick Stine
[caption id="attachment_21097" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick[/caption] Corey Philips Bucket brigade the first pool like a tribe! The chief, Ozzie, synchronized a great crew to beat the rain in the valley and head to Palm Springs. I never met two of the guys (Bulldog and Andy) before, but after the first pool it felt like I've known them forever. 10:00 am double trucker slash grinds from hell, almost blew the quest by the main man Bulldog. Rick decides to back him up with a slasher and Andy gets super close on the second run on a frontal slasher in the shallow end, but we had to dip out as quickly as possible because of the gnar. We went to skate another pool close by and Ozzie does a one wheeler on some heavy tranny. The coping stuck the fuck out and Mrz got the epic shot! [caption id="attachment_21100" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey[/caption] By this time it's only 11:00 am. We had two pools skated and had scouted several so we celebrated with -- what turned out to be-- the most expensive tacos in Palm Springs. We then drove further east and end up running into a very heavy crew. Me and Rick cracked open a couple of cold ones and watched. The crew was crushing things. We dipped out and got to this last barge that was super sick.  Rick got the grind so we headed out as soon as possible.  It was a wonderful day and I left with new friends and great memories. - Corey Philips MRZ [caption id="attachment_21102" align="aligncenter" width="409"] MRZ[/caption] This particular day was nostalgic in some ways. After Ozzie was arrested in 2011, he began trying to get more permission pools going. We'd still go out and barge from time to time, but it sure was easier on the nerves when we had permission to be there. It also made it better for shooting the skateboarding. I could set up lights, set up shots and the skaters could basically dial in the pool. On this day, the heavy rains had forced us east into the desert. Ozzie hooked up with some local friends and did his homework. He had several barges on the menu for that day. It was in and out. The fifteen minute rule was in full effect. We drove in, cleaned out several pools, then headed back to the first one after it had dried and checked them off one by one. It was exciting and fresh... it felt like the old days. - MRZ [caption id="attachment_21106" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21103" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Andy[/caption]
[caption id="attachment_21104" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ozzie[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21105" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Corey[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21107" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bulldog[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ace as usual : )
Great stories from everyone! Sorry I missed it!
Ozzie, what wheels are you riding here, mini cubics?

item.title: Friendship
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_21112" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Gopa, Rick, Ripperside Shawn, me[/caption] Ripperside Shawn moved to West Virginia a few months ago to work a farm there. We have scouted, drained and cleaned many pools over the past few years. I missed him when he moved away. He drove across country this past week and arrived in Escondido Saturday night. [caption id="attachment_21113" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Ripperside Shawn[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21114" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Gopa[/caption] His son -- Gopa -- celebrated his birthday and Shawn drove into town. He asked me to set up a pool mission for them. Easy. One of the pools I had set up was a new little Blue Haven kidney. I was pretty stoked to be taking them this weekend. The owner text me yesterday and said they'd be gone all day, so it was off the list. I thought of the Pink Motel. I knew that Shawn and Gopa had never ridden there. [caption id="attachment_21116" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Rick Stine[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21115" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Me[/caption] Rick and MRZ drove over and we met up and had the place to ourselves for awhile. Good friends. Fun. No other reason to be doing this...Happiness. Happy Birthday Gopa. Thank you Rick, Shawn, Gopa and MRZ. Excellent. I value your friendship. Skate - Ozzie [caption id="attachment_21117" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Friendship[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: What it's all about ... period

item.title: Combi Contests
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="attachment_21125" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tom Wally Inouye
Pipeline Combi[/caption] In doing the William Sharp book, I looked through his archive of contest photographs. He had images from the Spring Valley and Upland contests of Hester I. He also had some amazing images from Hester II at Del Mar and Upland. The Combi contest is tomorrow at Vans in Orange, California. I've been to most of them over the last ten years. I've written about them and had others do guest posts on Blue Tile Obsession. From Eric Nash, Chris Miller, the Alba brothers, to Jeff Grosso, Lance Mountain and almost everyone in between, the contests have been compared, pondered and dissected with surgical precision. [caption id="attachment_21128" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pipeline Skatepark Upland, Ca.[/caption] Over the last few days, I've been posting some classic images from the Pipeline Combi pool in Upland. The park and its radical terrain, helped to create a wave of powerful skateboarders that seriously pushed the known limits of skateboarding at that time. The park lasted from May 1977 to November 1988.  After it closed, local riders rode the pool even as the heavy steel blades fell in swinging, frenetic motion. They almost couldn't believe its end had come. In 1998, Vans opened the Vans Skateboard Park inside of a mall in Orange, California. In planning it, Vans had brought in Dave Duncan and Rick Carje -- among others -- to bring about a return of the Combi pool. Rick Carje had built Kelly Belmars and Chicken's pools and had worked with Dave Duncan building ramps and things. They met with Vans and Don Hoffman of the original Pipeline Combi.  Duncan, Belmar, Carje and Chuck Hults all put their heads together to decide how to rebuild the Combi pool. Rick Carje said that with a crew of about twenty workers, they finished the Vans Combi in about a month. [caption id="attachment_21131" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Vans Combi pool / 1999[/caption] Eventually, Vans decided on having a pool party contest in the Combi pool. A few guys that rode the pool regularly, had a bit of an advantage. The Vans Combi was plaster. It was lumpy and the coping stuck out. According to Omar Hassan, "You had to put the time in to ride the Combi well. The regular sessions were made up of only people who really wanted to ride it. It was bumpy and slippery... we loved it." Brian Patch, Bob Burnquist, Omar Hassan, Rune Glifberg, Jeff Grosso, Steve Alba, Lance Mountain, Chris Miller and a few others knew where to draw the lines and how to maintain speed. They rode it often and they rode it well. Vans didn't realize the impact these early contests would have. No one did. According to some of the early contest riders, it was a return of the big bowl riding contests that they recalled from their youth. [caption id="attachment_21140" align="aligncenter" width="455"] Alex Perelson Vans Combi - plaster version[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21141" align="aligncenter" width="456"] Chris Miller Vans Combi plaster version[/caption] The Vans Combi contests were held every spring and continued to grow. The contest is now considered the High Holy Day for bowl riding enthusiasts. Vans has a live webcast that is seen all over the world. To place well at the Vans Combi contest is considered a major achievement in a skateboarders career. [caption id="attachment_21136" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Vans Combi Refurbishing 2010[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21143" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Vans Combi - Refurbished 2010[/caption] Fast Forward. 2010. Vans decided to refurbish the Combi pool. Some alterations were made to the shape and a new surface was put onto the pool. New coping and tiles were placed onto the entire pool as well. The Combi refurbishing made the pool much more 'user friendly' and an entirely new crew of young skaters began competing and riding the Combi on a regular basis. Lines that Steve Alba, Chris Miller and others had laid down years before in the original Pipeline Combi pool, were mimicked and copied... Trick combinations put down by Rune Glifberg and Bucky Lasek were usurped as well. [caption id="attachment_21137" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Josh Rodriguez[/caption] The young upstarts failed to consider a simple time-honored truth. Glory gotten on the backs of others, is no glory at all. Etiquette would often be lacking. One year during practice sessions,  I watched groms brazenly drop in and snake Bucky, Salba and Omar. They shook their heads in annoyance. I bet that when Bucky, Salba and Omar were young, they would've never dreamed of snaking one of the greats. It simply wasn't done. [caption id="attachment_21139" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Combi Contest Morning[/caption] The Combi contests have evolved in the past few years. There has been a changing of the guard in a way. The format has been changed. Pro, Masters and Legends divisions separate the riders... big money drew some skaters out of a sleepy, big bellied 'retirement' and the hunger for Vans cash, accolades and Vans Combi Banner credentials started watering down the pure punk-ass debacle that once was the Vans Combi Contest. We'll see where it goes... for now, I'll sit back and watch my favorite skateboarders draw lines and throw themselves around all day. The energy level in that building, on that day, during that venue is consistently crazy. It is insane. I'll take insane over mundane any day. Thank you to MRZ and William Sharp for the images. Skate- Ozzie [caption id="attachment_21138" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Eddie Elguera[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: "High Holy Day"-well put.

item.excerpt:encoded: Chris Miller Vans Combi plaster version

item.title: VANS Combi 2016
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: Vans Combi Contest. It was a full scale assault on the mind and body this year... I've written more words about this contest than virtually any other. History. Longevity. Participants. Legends. It's all here under one roof. One day. Chaos. Random highlights included- Austin Poynter going higher than anyone... ever. Chris Russell destroying another board on another disaster. He does that and his punk points are at such a level, they won't be eclipsed anytime soon. [caption id="attachment_21158" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Austin Poynter[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21152" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chris Russell[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21151" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Chris Russell[/caption] Bucky Lasek's first run out of the gate was not for the weak-hearted opponent. The riders in his heat must've wished they were in a different building that day. His first six walls were ferocious and he didn't let up. Pedro Barros- good grief. His speed was unmatched. I saw him go as high as Lincoln Ueda usually goes... and that is saying something. Pedro has raw, brutal power. Kiko Francisco has a backside ollie that is beautiful to witness. It looks like he fell out of a skylight in the ceiling or something. He's like fourteen years old too... imagine the day when he's gained some meat and potatoes on his body. He'll need a bigger bowl. [caption id="attachment_21168" align="aligncenter" width="430"] Bucky Lasek[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21155" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Bucky Lasek[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21154" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pedro means it![/caption] [caption id="attachment_21153" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Pedro Barros[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21170" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Lance Mountain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21156" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Kiko Francisco[/caption] Steve Caballero was polished perfection. Eddie Elguera once again showed why he's a Legend in every way imaginable. Great lines and technicality were evident. Christian Hosoi was water flowing through the bowl. His runs were great. Zach Miller held some lines together in fluid form. Alex Perelson put some serious walls together and put in a good performance. [caption id="attachment_21165" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Alex Perelson[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21159" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Christian, El Gato and Losi[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21164" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Duane Peters[/caption] Chris Miller ran into difficulty during some seriously fast lines and found himself fending off some ultra-hungry opponents. One particular opponent was Lance Mountain. Lance came out swinging. He fought like he had extra arms. Few could stand against him and not marvel at what he threw down. It was the game changer. Lance ended the night with a top red banner spot. [caption id="attachment_21160" align="aligncenter" width="523"] Lance Mountain[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21163" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Tony Alva[/caption] [caption id="attachment_21162" align="aligncenter" width="584"] Darren Navarette[/caption] Pedro Barros ate up his division though Bucky Lasek, Cory Juneau and Trey Wood were nipping at his ankles. Darren Navarette  grabbed the Masters Division with strong powerful skating and ended the day with a big smile and some cash. Pat Ngoho ended the contest with three complete runs, fluid stylish skating and placed --once again--rather lower than he deserved. Open your eyes guys... It was an overwhelming contest. Mind. Body. Soul. Always is and probably always will be. Pro- 1- Pedro Barros 2- Cory Juneau 3- Bucky Lasek Masters- 1- Darren Navarette 2- Bruno Passos 3- Jed Fuller Legends- 1- Lance Mountain 2- Steve Caballero 3- Chris Miller Thank you to Vans for everything, thank you to all of the riders, thank you to Orlando Welsh, Chris Ortiz and Anthony Acosta for the images. Skate - Ozzie

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Awesome ass shit! i'm so late comin to the party. Thnx Ozzie for always posting the good shit brah!

item.title: TA - Grant Brittain
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded: The first time I saw Tony Alva in person was at the Ocean Festival at the Del Mar Fairgrounds in 1974. He and the other Z-flex riders showed up and blew minds, mine included. They skated like we did and this sighting put Tony Alva at the top in my book. This is five years before I ever picked up a camera and probably ten years before I ever shot a photo of him. When I finally shot a photo of Tony Alva at the Gonzales pool, I felt like I had reached a pivotal moment in my career by photographing the most important skater of all time.

item.title: TA - Lucia
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
I met Tony briefly in Malibu, before embarking on a trip down to Scorpion Bay in Baja Mexico. I went with Brian Logan and Ozzie Ausband in May 2014. We had planned a two week adventure doing what we all love to do: surf, skate and take photos. Brian drove and the rest of us piled in the van and we headed south straight after the Skateboarding Hall of Fame that year. It took two days to get down there driving through salt flats, being mostly off road, at least for the later part of the trip. Once we arrived, we situated ourselves on the surf point eagerly awaiting the swell the next day. Tony had his quiver of surfboards from his Alva line which I had the pleasure to ride. They were perfectly made boards for the surf we were getting and so much fun! Tony could surf these boards with his eyes closed. He made them work effortlessly like he did on his skateboards, walking the nose of a five foot board and gliding with style through the waves on offer. It was such a pleasure to see.
Most nights we cooked up food and ate around the campfire talking the night away, a group of passionate people who had achieved a lot so far in life. We all had become well connected friends. When the swell became small Tony would go skate and rip at a local pool he managed to sniff out and tear apart. Some days we would take the 4 x 4 and go explore, take photos and mess around between us all. Tony was a kid at heart and always saw the bright side of life! We scored great waves on this trip and had some great jamming out sessions with Tony playing his bass guitar.  It was great fun working with Tony, he loved the camera and was always willing to work with me well on any ideas I had. Thanks Tony! A pleasure.

item.title: TA - Raul
item.dc:creator: bluetileoz
item.content:encoded:
Tony Alva and I came from different zip codes. I could tell he was suspicious of me at the beginning.  He was thinking, “Who is this guy? What does he know about skateboarding?” Tony was justified. I was an “outsider” and didn’t know the skateboard scene.  He was right to wonder if we could create “some magic.”  Tony was already an icon in the skateboarding scene.  I was a photographer who was deeply influenced at that time by the lighting stylings of Guy Bourdin, a famous French fashion photographer.  I was just starting out and was excited I could incorporate my lighting ideas with this client, a skateboard company.  They seemed disparate but I feel they were successful because they fused a raw talent with an aggressive lighting style that was not widely seen or used.   I worked with the graphic designer, Eric Munson, and together we were able to shoot what we felt would be exciting with no to answer to. We just delivered an ad every month.  What freedom!

After the initial shoot, I could tell that Tony thought I was okay. As we later went along and talked about what we had in mind for subsequent shoots, Tony was more accepting even when they seemed off the wall. Hell, we weren’t sure how they were going to turn out either. As with most of our shoots, we started out with an idea and they took on a life of their own. I loved the first ad and was inspired to continue to push for fresh work.  As you can see, some of the shot locations didn’t have any relation to skateboarding but they were always exciting graphically.  

Its been a while since we did those ads and I can look back on that period fondly. Times seemed innocent and I’m happy that I was a small part of that skateboard lore. I felt very strongly about these ads that I entered them in advertising and design competitions. I was disappointed that they didn’t win any gold medal but I also know they were ahead of their time.  Ads from that period didn’t look like our ads.

After that period, I worked on both coasts: LA and NY.  I went on to work for Andy Warhol at Interview Magazine, Time Magazine, Esquire, Rolling Stone, etc.  I’ve also worked for many record companies and shot a ton of music groups.  I also worked for many fashion accounts like: Joe Boxer, J Crew, Allure Magazine, NY Times, Glamour, etc. More recently, I’ve won a national award doing architectural photography.   Now, I’m most excited by my new photographic work: New Abstraction.  New Abstraction is the title of a recently published book.
